headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the quarterly earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this point.Now I'll turn the meeting over to Sir Rich Kinder, Executive Chairman of Kinder Morgan.
componenttext:
Welcome to the quarterly earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this point.
Now I'll turn the meeting over to Sir Rich Kinder, Executive Chairman of Kinder Morgan. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Sean, and welcome to the KMI first quarter investor call.Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's earnings release and this call include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Refo
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Sean, and welcome to the KMI first quarter investor call.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's earnings release and this call include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. We encourage you to read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and use of non-GAAP financial measures set forth at the end of our earnings release as well as review our latest filings with the SEC for a list of risk factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those in such forward-looking statements.
I'll start the call and before I turn it over to our CEO Steve Kean and our CFO Kim Dang, I'd like to give you a quick overview of our strategy at KMI. The first point I would make is that this quarter's results again demonstrate that we remain a strong generator of cash even in these chaotic times for the energy sector. Second, as we've said previously and at our meeting in January, we do not anticipate any requirement to access the equity markets for the foreseeable future. We also do not see any requirement to access the debt markets for the foreseeable future, except for rollovers in years subsequent to 2016. We've again reduced our expansion CapEx. Steve will take you through that for 2016 and we expect that trend to continue in subsequent years through both high grading our projects and entering into selective joint ventures. We expect to fund the necessary CapEx out of our cash flow and continue to improve our debt-to-EBITDA ratio thereby preserving and strengthening our investment-grade balance sheet. As our cash flow achieves those objectives funding our CapEx and strengthening our balance sheet, we will obviously, have excess cash, which we will then use to either raise our dividend, purchase our shares, offer new projects and/or acquisitions but only if they are solidly accretive to our distributable cash flow per share.
And with that, I'll turn it over to Steve.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Rich. I'm going to hit on 3 topics before giving you some segment highlights for the quarter. First, an update to our capital projects and our expected growth spend for 2016 and update on our outlook for the balance of 2016 and some thoughts
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Rich. I'm going to hit on 3 topics before giving you some segment highlights for the quarter. First, an update to our capital projects and our expected growth spend for 2016 and update on our outlook for the balance of 2016 and some thoughts on our counterparty credit risk.
With respect to the capital update, we announced today reduction in our project backlog of $4.1 billion. So from $18.2 billion down to $14.1 billion. The 2 biggest adjustments are the removal of Palmetto Pipeline project, which is a reduction of $550 million and the market portion of the NED project, which is a reduction of $3.1 billion. With respect to NED, we worked very hard, this is our Northeast Direct project serving -- that would have served New England markets. We worked very hard to get customer commitments on the project and while many of our LDC customers did sign-up, we did not receive enough contractual commitments from electric customers to make the project viable. So we will fulfill our obligation to consult with our customers over the next 30 days or so but this project is not economic so we're moving it from the backlog. In both cases NED and Palmetto, based on all the facts we believe, this is the right outcome for our investors. To be specific, the return on the NED Project, at the level of commitments that we have, would be less than 6% unlevered after-tax. That's clearly not viable and we are far better off having that cash available for other uses whether that's continued and even accelerated delevering, other investment opportunities or returning value to shareholders. We value our New England customers and continue to believe, along with many others, that additional capacity is needed in the region but we'll have to look for other ways to serve some part of those needs. We did get there on this one and the action we're taking is undeniably the right call for our investors. We previously wrote off, I'll remind you, our NED supply project and we never had that one in the backlog.
On the Palmetto Pipeline. Essentially, the Georgia legislature prevented us from getting imminent domain and also prevented us from getting other state permits. We were making good progress with land acquisition even without imminent domain but we needed other permits, which Georgia has now put a moratorium on. We needed environmental permits for example, which they've now put a moratorium on until mid-2017. So as a result, we are not moving forward with Palmetto. We have some other small adjustments to the backlog, including putting about $160 million for the projects in service during the quarter. We had some cost changes, which netted to a reduction of $254 million in the overall backlog and we have some other scope additions and removals, which essentially offset each other.
So looking at the bigger picture on our capital projects spend, we continue to high grade our capital investments to ensure that we're securing our investment-grade credit metrics and maximizing the returns we get for the capital that we do deploy. We're aiming to reduce spend, improve returns and selectively joint venture projects where that makes sense. We reduced our expected 2016 spend by an additional $400 million to $2.9 billion. So that compares to the $3.3 million that we projected in January for 2016, which in turn was $900 million down from the $4.2 billion that we projected in our preliminary 2016 guidance, which we sent out last December. So we continue to work through our backlog and high-grade where we're spending our capital.
With respect to joint ventures. As we discussed at the January conference, we'd be pursuing these where they made sense. That is, where we can share the capital spending obligation on a particular project with a third-party, get paid a reasonable value for having originated the opportunity, et cetera. Those processes are competitive and confidential so if we're only going to be able to give you limited details but the summary is that the process is going well and we currently expect to achieve results -- the results that we built in to our plan. We're also taking care to not be dependent on any 1 transaction. These processes can be unpredictable and we will be in a position to back away from a given transaction if acceptable value does not materialize.
Overall, as we complete projects and further high-grade the backlog, as Rich mentioned, we will free up cash that we can use to reduce debt, return cash to investors in the form of buybacks and dividends or invest in attractive projects or acquisition or some combination of those.
Now for the 2016 outlook update. We have looked at the potential impacts for the remainder of 2016 due to continued weakness in the sector. We now estimate on a full-year basis for 2016 a negative impact of about 3% to the EBITDA that we showed in January but because of our ongoing efforts to high grade our capital spend and to pursue the joint ventures where it makes sense, we expect to meet our investment-grade credit metrics notwithstanding the 3% reduction. That 3% EBITDA reduction translates into a 4% reduction in DCF. Yes, as the year goes on, we will try to mitigate that negative but we are not assuming in this outlook any dramatic turnaround for our producer customers by the end of the year as some analysts have predicted.
Now we're not happy about any negative to plan but I think when you put this in the context of a dramatic production declines particularly in the Eagle Ford, which is down 28% on oil from its peak and 15% on gas and credit weaknesses, our business is really diversified and insulated from the full brunt of the weakness in the producing sector.
So here are the 2 main contributors. A little under half of the deterioration is attributable to lower Eagle Ford volumes and those flow through both our Midstream group in the gas business unit and also in our products group. And again, what this is all comparing to our original outlook. So this is not a year-over-year look. This is a -- versus our January outlook that we presented at the conference. So a little under half attributable to the Eagle Ford, another 20% is attributable to the coal customer bankruptcies. So there is -- there are a lot of other pieces and Kim will take you through some additional details, but those are the 2 big chunks contributing to the degradation of the forecast.
So while the current year outlook for North American engine production is experiencing weakness, we're still bullish on the longer-term. We believe that we'll continue to see more of our North American energy needs, met by North American energy production that will grow our exports. We've already been growing refined products, natural gas to Mexico. I think we'll continue to see growth in natural gas and natural gas liquids exports. And those long-term trends are good for North American energy midstream companies like Kinder Morgan.
Okay, the third general topic is counterparty credit. We've been monitoring counterparty credit very closely, but beyond monitoring we've been taking action. We've been calling on collateral, putting other credits quarter arrangements in place. A few points about our particular circumstances. Given our diverse business mix, we've got a very broad and diverse customer base. We've got producer customers, of course, but we also have integrated energy companies, gas and electric utilities and industrial users of our services. We're not exposed to any single sector, commodity or service. That diversified our exposure, which reduces our risk. Our Top 25 customers constitute 44% of our revenue and of that revenue, 85% is investment-grade. Of our total revenue, about 75% is investment-grade or has substantial credit support and 86% is rated B or better. In our business, real exposure is more complicated than simply looking at our customers ratings. In many cases, the rights our customers hold are valuable to third parties or essential to the revenue-generating activities of those customers and therefore, will be needed on an ongoing basis by the customer or in the worst case, a debtor in possession of bankruptcy or a subsequent purchaser. We analyze all of those factors in mitigation to get to our credit concern list. Our identified credit concern list amounts to about 5% of revenue and about half of that is mitigated by credit support or underlying resale value of the capacity that the customers hold. And those numbers, that 5% and that half of 5% include Peabody, the Peabody bankruptcy which we're now reflecting. So the going forward number is less than that. We're reflecting Peabody -- the Peabody bankruptcy in our forecast update.
So the segments -- a few highlights looking at the first quarter of 2016 to Q1 of 2015. The overall summary is this: on an earnings before DD&A and certain items basis, 3 of our 5 units basis grew year-over-year; gas was up 4%; Products Pipelines was up 17%; Terminals was up 2%; Kinder Morgan Canada would have been up year-over-year but for the effect of the weakening Canadian dollar and CO2 was down 21% as a result of lower commodity prices and some lower production.
On Natural Gas Pipelines. We had very strong performance on TGP and the contributions from our Hiland Midstream acquisition. So we split the Hiland acquisition between our Midstream business units in gas and our Products Pipelines for the Double H pipeline. So contributions from really, really strong performance on TGP and the contribution from our Hiland midstream acquisition that we made in the first quarter of last year. Those 2 things more than offset weakness in our Midstream assets and in our Western pipelines. The Midstream weakness is largely gathering the processing in the Eagle Ford and on a year-over-year basis, gathering in the Haynesville.
In the West, year-over-year growth on our EPNG system was more than offset by weakness in Cheyenne Plains, WIC, CIG and Trans Colorado as the fundamentals for basis pipes out of the Rockies continues to degrade.
Natural gas needs for transportation and storage services we believe should grow over the medium and long-term as power generation exports, including LNG and exports to Mexico and pet-chem and industrial demand continue to grow. Over the last 2 years, the gas group has entered into new and firm -- new and pending firm transport capacity commitments totaling 8.2 Bcf and I think importantly about 1.8 Bcf that was existing previously unsold capacity. And we currently estimate that we move about 38% of the natural gas consumed in the United States on our pipelines.
Moving to the Products segment. The 17% year-over-year growth in segment earnings was driven by growth in KMCC. That's our crude and condensate pipeline on the Eagle Ford and the full quarter operation of the splitter, the first splitter in the Houston ship channel. We also saw a good refined products transportation growth 2.3% increase year-over-year. And while Eagle Ford volumes have declined over all and we are projecting some decline on our assets as we look forward, we have seen the volumes grow on our KMCC pipeline as projects have come on and we think that's due to the pipes in a great position. It's serving a great part of that market. It has good upstream and downstream connectivity and good contracts. Now we think we've just started to see some flattening in that pipeline but if you think about what's happening in the Eagle Ford overall, what we've done on this pipe is essentially dramatically grow our market share out of the basin on that pipe.
CO2. We saw earnings before DD&A declined 20% year-over-year to $223 million for the quarter. Production net to our interest was down 7% and I will point out, SACROC was down but Jesse, you can confirm this, but I think we had our highest quarter probably in the fourth quarter of 2014 at SACROC and then our next highest was the first quarter of 2015. So very strong quarter in 2015 that we're comparing to our 2016 performance.
The CO2 group has -- well, I'll also mention price. The weighted average realized price has declined about 18% year-over-year, and of course, that's a big part of the explanation for the downturn on a year-over-year basis. The CO2, on the bright side, CO2 group has been very diligent at reducing costs and husbanding our capital to the very highest available return opportunities. And I will say perhaps somewhat counterintuitively, third-party demand for CO2 under our arrangements with them has stayed strong. We're roughly flat year-over-year on CO2, notwithstanding the deterioration in commodity prices.
Moving to Terminals. Terminals was up 2% year-over-year. Growth in this business came from expansions and acquisitions, which slightly more than offset the weakness in our bulk business and that being driven primarily by bankruptcies of our coal customers. Most of our liquids terminal businesses and refined projects and we've continued to see high utilization and generally good pricing on rollovers and renewals there. And we continue to have a very strong outlook for the great liquids terminals positions that we built in the Houston Ship Channel and Edmonton.
Kinder Morgan Canada. The Trans Mountain expansion project. So again, this is under long-term contracts with customers. The 3-key areas of focus for us remain getting the NEB recommended order and the cabinet level ordering counsel from the federal process, consultation and accommodation with First Nations and thirdly, satisfaction of the B.C. government's 5 conditions. We're making progress on all 3. With respect to the NEB, we got our draft additions last August. We believe that they're manageable but we did seek some important changes, particularly around the time required to approve certain portions of the build. We now have the outline of the further process to be conducted by the federal government during the order and Council process, which is expected to result in a final order. They've scheduled the final order for December 20 of this year. We're making good progress in meeting the consultation and accommodation obligations we have at the First Nations and we've added mutual benefit agreements that bring us to a number -- a majority of the bands that are most directly affected by the project actually supporting the project.
On the 5 conditions. We're still working on those. We are engaged actively with the B.C. government on those. The B.C. government is also going to be conducting an environmental review under their provincial process. We expect that both of those things will be concluded within the same time frame of the federal process. Maybe not the same day, but within the same general time frame and we have this project in the backlog and we are aiming for a 2019 completion -- end of 2019 completion.
And that's it for the segment updates. With that, I'll turn it over to Kim.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Steve. Today, we're declaring a dividend of $0.125 per share. That's consistent with our budget and the guidance we gave you at December of last year. But most importantly, we generated $954 million of DCF in excess of our dividend, which as
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Steve. Today, we're declaring a dividend of $0.125 per share. That's consistent with our budget and the guidance we gave you at December of last year. But most importantly, we generated $954 million of DCF in excess of our dividend, which as Steve and Rich pointed out, insulates us from the challenging Capital Markets and significantly enhances our credit profile.
Now let me explain what I mean when we say significantly enhances our credit profile. If you compare our coverage ratio, and that's DCF divided by the dividend, in the first quarter of last year, which was 1.2x versus the 4.4x in the first quarter of this year, we have significantly more retained cash flow, approximately $750 million. And therefore, we have no Capital Markets risk to getting equity raised. In addition, our previous funding policy was to fund our expansion CapEx, 50% equity and 50% debt. Now we're using 100% retained cash flow. And therefore, our balance metrics will improve more quickly than under our prior funding model.
Before we get to DCF, let me point out a couple of things on our GAAP income statement. You will see that revenues, net income available to common shareholders and earnings per share are down. As I say many quarters, we do not believe that these measures or changes in these measures are necessarily a good predictor of our performance. We have some businesses where revenues and expenses fluctuate with commodity prices but margin generally does not. In addition, these numbers can be impacted by noncash, nonrecurring accounting issues or what we call certain items. For example, if you look at revenues. Revenues are down $402 million or 11%. However, if you strip out the certain items with the primary certain item impacting revenues being the CO2 and the mark-to-market on our other hedges, revenues would be down $316 million. When you compare the $316 million to the $359 million reduction in cost of goods sold, gross margin is actually up. And again, that's largely because we have some businesses where both revenues and expenses fluctuate with commodity prices.
With respect to net income. If you strip out the certain items, and I'll go through those with you in a minute, net income before certain items was $446 million compared to $445 million for the same period in 2015 or essentially flat. EPS before certain items, and here when you do EPS, earnings is defined as net income to common shareholders, so after the payment of the preferred, EPS before certain items was $0.18 versus the $0.12 that you see on the page for the first quarter of 2016 compared to $0.20 in the first quarter of 2015. So while stripping out certain items from earnings does help, we still believe that the best indicator of our performance is the cash we generate, which we measure as distributable cash flow and distributable cash flow per share.
So let's turn to the second page of the financials, which I really will give you a clear picture of our performance. We generated total DCF for the quarter of $1.233 billion versus the $1.242 billion for the comparable period in 2015. Therefore, total DCF was down approximately $9 million. So essentially flat between the 2 periods. The segments were up by $28 million, as Steve mentioned, or 1% with the increases in natural gas and products, which combined for an increase of $85 million, slightly offsetting the $58 million reduction in CO2, which was driven largely by lower crude price. The $28 million increase in the segment was offset by a $39 million increase in our preferred stock dividends. If you remember, we issue the preferred stock in the fourth quarter of last year. Now there are other moving parts but if you take the $28 million from the segments, offset by the $39 million, that gives you a decrease of $11 million versus the decrease in DCF that I mentioned of $9 million. So that gets you almost all of the change.
DCF per share in the quarter was $0.55 versus $0.58 for the first quarter of last year. DCF per share was down slightly due to the additional shares we issued during 2015 to finance our growth projects and maintain our balance sheet. Therefore, despite an almost 30% decline in commodity prices versus the first quarter of last year, our performance was relatively flat and we believe that this demonstrates the resiliency of our cash flows generated by a large diversified platform of primarily fee-based assets.
There are a couple of certain items in the quarter that I want to highlight for you. Certain items in the quarter totaled $235 million loss on a pretax basis but $132 million loss on an after-tax basis. $170 million of the pre-taxed loss was driven by the write-off of costs associated with the NED market and the Palmetto Projects, which as Steve mentioned, have also been removed from the backlog. $85 million was associated with losses on asset disposals and impairments in 4 of our business segments with the most significant items being in CO2 and Terminal. And CO2 was primarily associated with the write-off of the CO2 recapture plan due to the lack of expected volumes. And in Terminals, it was due to lost business at 3 of our bulk terminals. We also -- there's certain tax benefit of $103 million and that's primarily just the tax impact of the certain items at approximately 35%.
As Steve mentioned in his comments, we currently expect EBITDA for the year to be approximately 3% below our budget and DCF to be approximately 4% below. Now for the first quarter, we did better than that with EBITDA about 2% below our budget and DCF about 1% below our budget but we believe our outlook is consistent with the current environment and produce our decisions and we are not assuming any improvement.
Now let me give you a little more granularity on expected segment performance for the full year versus our budget. We expect Natural Gas Pipelines to come in approximately 2% below its budget, primarily as a result of lower volumes mainly in the Eagle Ford. The other factor impacting our Natural Gas for the full year is delay on our EEC SNG pipeline expansion project as a result, of the FERC certificate being about 3 months later than we anticipated. CO2 is expected to end the year on its budget. We expect prices to be essentially in line with our $38 per barrel on our budget and cost savings to offset any weakness in oil production or CO2 volume.
We expect Terminals to end the year approximately 4% below its budget, primarily due to the impact of the Peabody bankruptcy. We currently expect products to be about 6% below its budget primarily due to lower crude and condensate volumes on KMCC, Double H and Double Eagle. Right now, we are projecting KMC to be slightly below its budget for the full year due to higher book taxes. But remember the book taxes, while they impact the segment, have no impact on EBITDA or DCF.
With respect to interest, cash taxes, G&A and sustaining CapEx. Now on a combined basis, those items are expected to come in slightly positive to budget or said another way, generate a favorable variance. With the positive interest and sustaining CapEx more than offsetting the negatives on G&A and cash taxes. The negative variance on G&A is driven by lower capitalized overhead as a result of the lower expansion capital that Steve mentioned and interest expense expected to be lower than budget due to lower LIBOR rates.
And with that, I'll move to the balance sheet. We ended the quarter with debt of $41.555 billion and EBITDA for the trailing 12 months was about $7.4 billion, which results in a debt-to-EBITDA of about 5.6x, consistent with where we ended the year last year. And as Steve mentioned, we still expect to end 2016 at 5.5x consistent with our budget. That was up in the quarter, an increase in debt of about $330 million since the end of last year. So let me reconcile that for you.
We generated DCF in the quarter, as I mentioned 1 minute ago, of $1.233 billion. We spent about $700 million in CapEx. We spent about $245 million roughly on acquisitions, with almost all of that being associated with the BP acquisition; and we contributed about $44 million to equity investments. So about $900 million -- a little -- $990 million roughly attributable to our expansion CapEx program.
We paid dividends of $279 million and then there were working capital and other items that were used at roughly $300 million. When you look at the use of working capital, about -- over $150 million of that was associated with accrued interest. Now when I give you the DCF figure of $1.233 million, that has 3 months of accrued interest in it but we make interest payments twice a year. We make them primarily in the first quarter -- in the third quarter, and so we make cash interest payments in the first quarter attributable to 6 months. So you have a working capital use associated with that incremental 6 months of cash going out the door, which is different from the 3 months of accrual within DCF.
The other working capital use in the quarter was primarily associated with property tax and there's probably about $100 million associated with that. Again, we have about 3 months of property tax accrual in the quarter. By the time you get to the end of the year, you have 12 months of accrual but a lot of our property tax payments are made for the full year in January. And therefore, relative to DCF, you have a working capital use in the quarter. In future quarters, you'll have a working capital source. And that gets you to about the $330 million increase in debt.
And so with that, I'll turn it back to Rich.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you -- as part of the guidance reduction, what were the different drivers there? If you could walk through that just one more time for us, that would be helpful.
componenttext: I was just wondering if you -- as part of the guidance reduction, what were the different drivers there? If you could walk through that just one more time for us, that would be helpful.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I'll start with the 2 big pieces and then Kim has some additional detail. But as I said, about -- just a little under half of it, a little under 50% of the reduction is attributable to lower Eagle Ford volumes than what we had in the plan. So
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I'll start with the 2 big pieces and then Kim has some additional detail. But as I said, about -- just a little under half of it, a little under 50% of the reduction is attributable to lower Eagle Ford volumes than what we had in the plan. So as I talked about volumes been up year-over-year but versus what we had in the plan, we had lower Eagle Ford volumes. And that impact -- that's trying to sum up everything. So that is on our Eagle Ford gathering system itself, on our DK, Heather line and the processing facility. It's also volumes that we're entering into our taxes Intrastate system that we expected to be able to move on that system and collect transport fees. So it's kind of end to end almost on the Eagle Ford volumes through our Texas assets. The other place where we had exposure to the Eagle Ford volumes is in our projects pipelines where we have the KMCC pipe line and the splitter. And we expected the splitter in our plan to run a little bit above its contract minimums. We have good contracts with good protection there. It's running -- we're expecting to just kind of to run at the minimum, which are pretty good. It's a pretty high percentage of the capacity of the facility but we have budgeted a little bit more there. And KMCC, we expect we're now going to start to see some volume metric decline on that. Again, that's all versus planned. So that's a little -- if you just say -- and look there are a lots of different ways to rack up these numbers. But that's -- those factors, the Eagle Ford volumes as they impact 2 of our business units, amount to about half, a little less than half of the adjustment. The other -- another 20% is attributable to the coal company bankruptcy. So those are the 2 very big pieces.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then as far as the decision to take anything off now versus later, can you just walk through the timing to it? And then also just, if you will, look into high-grade the outgrowth CapEx backlog, are there any other items that are kind of
componenttext: That's great. And then as far as the decision to take anything off now versus later, can you just walk through the timing to it? And then also just, if you will, look into high-grade the outgrowth CapEx backlog, are there any other items that are kind of coming under closer scrutiny that you could point us towards? Or do you feel like where the backlog is now is a good place for where you want to be?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the first point and I want to separate that a little bit from the high-grade discussion because look we did it all on NED. We pursued customers hard. We pursued accruals hard. In the end, the customer commitments just weren't there. Now that ma
componenttext: Yes. So on the first point and I want to separate that a little bit from the high-grade discussion because look we did it all on NED. We pursued customers hard. We pursued accruals hard. In the end, the customer commitments just weren't there. Now that makes the project economic not surprisingly and that's why I wanted to specify the return for you. It's apparent. It's objectively apparent that the project is not economically viable project at that customer sign-up level. So we said at the conference we're going to make a big push in the first quarter to try to get customer commitments in and sell-down some of the equity to customers. Not a lot of takers at that return as you might expect and so we put on a hard push to try to get done and it's just not forthcoming. We had 1 significant perspective customer who determined to put their volume someplace else. And that was a significant negative for the project. So that's how we got to that decision in the time that we're talking about now. But I want to go back and underscore again from an investor standpoint, in light of that return, we are a lot better off with that $3.1 billion back in our pockets and being put to some other use. The project wasn't going to produce a return that would be required to make it viable because again, the contracts weren't there were better off having the money back I think if you look through the rest of the backlog, my guess is we'll find some bits and pieces there that will either save some money on or we may change the timing of a little bit. Still think those are high probability projects though and ones that you want to build-out and do and they contribute to our DCF per share growth that we're aiming to achieve by building it out.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to underscore. The average -- the Year 1 EBITDA multiple on the projects and the backlog, excluding CO2 so as we said on CO2 we look at the projects of the time we enter into them and explore a curve at that time and we target at least a 15% unle
componenttext: And just to underscore. The average -- the Year 1 EBITDA multiple on the projects and the backlog, excluding CO2 so as we said on CO2 we look at the projects of the time we enter into them and explore a curve at that time and we target at least a 15% unlevered after-tax return. But on the non-CO2 projects, the average Year 1 multiple EBITDA multiple is 6.7x.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then one last one if I could. Just kind of curious how you guys think of the high levels now as far as with the back log standing at $14 billion, the size of the entity as it is right now, what type of EBITDA growth do you guys see yourselves being ab
componenttext: And then one last one if I could. Just kind of curious how you guys think of the high levels now as far as with the back log standing at $14 billion, the size of the entity as it is right now, what type of EBITDA growth do you guys see yourselves being able to achieve? Is or anything different than what you guys have communicated historically as far as kind of base growth at this business can throw off?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: One very simple way to look at it is to take the 6.7 multiple off the $14.1 billion and divide that by the number of shares outstanding. And you can see what that works out to be. And it's a $0.70, $0.75 per share.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, just a follow-up on the discussion on CapEx. When I look at it for 2016, you've now revised it lower again which I guess, is good in this environment. You also mentioned that in terms of pulling NED out on how you're focusing on returns an
componenttext: First question, just a follow-up on the discussion on CapEx. When I look at it for 2016, you've now revised it lower again which I guess, is good in this environment. You also mentioned that in terms of pulling NED out on how you're focusing on returns and I think you've made a general comment about just trying to high-grade returns and so forth. The change this year, how much is related just do the removal of the NED and Palmetto versus -- or have there been any improvements in costs. Are you able to beat up your contractors a little bit for -- to improve returns? And then I was wondering if you could also talk about on a -- I guess, on a Delta basis, what the impact would be of the removal of NED and Palmetto on the 2017 budget. I realized that obviously, that's not been presented but just with the Delta of what you would have expected to spend on those 2 projects in 2017?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't have a 2017 CapEx numbers. I think Palmetto and speaking with respect to the backlog, so Palmetto was about $550 million and of course NED was about 3.3. So that explains most of the backlog reduction on the CapEx front. It's a mix of things.
componenttext: Yes, I don't have a 2017 CapEx numbers. I think Palmetto and speaking with respect to the backlog, so Palmetto was about $550 million and of course NED was about 3.3. So that explains most of the backlog reduction on the CapEx front. It's a mix of things. We had some spend for NED in there but we don't really have construction spend for NED in 2016. So that would not have been a huge component of the 3.1. And Palmetto was primarily a land acquisition and maybe the start off constructions was not just those it was all so we got cost reductions. We had other projects that were moved as we said at the beginning of the year we made some JV assumptions as well.

componenttext: We have 1 project, the timings moved out also so it's 1 fairly bit.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the cost reductions, is that something that we can see more of on a go-forward basis? I mean, it's interesting you use to the language of improving returns or is that totally about high grading?
componenttext: So the cost reductions, is that something that we can see more of on a go-forward basis? I mean, it's interesting you use to the language of improving returns or is that totally about high grading?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a number of things. So we have seen -- so a lot of our focus now is on build-outs of our existing network and we have seen some improvement in returns partly because we've made some scope refinements and other cost reductions that call it more market
componenttext: It's a number of things. So we have seen -- so a lot of our focus now is on build-outs of our existing network and we have seen some improvement in returns partly because we've made some scope refinements and other cost reductions that call it more market-oriented that it's costing less to do things now on a more pleated environment and we've also added customers to some of our expansions. One example I'm thinking of his our Texas Intrastate. So we're marching -- so in other words, were trying to march returns up by doing those 3 things: optimizing scope, reducing costs and adding revenue.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then I was just wondering if you could turn to spend a little bit I mean, obviously, you took an ED out because of returns issue. At this stage right now, is Trans Mountain at risk for the same thing regardless of what happens on the improval pr
componenttext: Okay, and then I was just wondering if you could turn to spend a little bit I mean, obviously, you took an ED out because of returns issue. At this stage right now, is Trans Mountain at risk for the same thing regardless of what happens on the improval process or are the returns that you expect -- at your latest update, does it look -- is it close to your return hurdles or well above your return hurdle and I was wondering if you could comment about some of the comments that the Canadian government made last week with respect to the Pacific guidelines. Do you do that as a positive? Or do you just sort of continue your focus as is?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, huge, huge difference between NED and Trans Mountain. Trans Mountain is under contract. That's an enormous difference. We were fighting to get NED under contract and didn't get there. Trans Mountain has the contracts in place. 20 year contracts for 9
componenttext: Yes, huge, huge difference between NED and Trans Mountain. Trans Mountain is under contract. That's an enormous difference. We were fighting to get NED under contract and didn't get there. Trans Mountain has the contracts in place. 20 year contracts for 93% of the volume and the other 7% is on a 15 year contract. So long-term contracts and look, the overall picture, I mean, it's -- the overall picture in Canada is notwithstanding very, very difficult netbacks out there right. They're taking a very long view and their finishing out projects that there well into and the oil stands become a very stable source of production. It's not like the shales where it ramps -- you get a high ramp up in the beginning and then it falls off so there's an actual projection of increase in production in Canada. At the same time, that the transport options outside of Canada are becoming more limited. So our customer still want to do this project and we do too and the returns are good. Switching to the, I guess, public opinion or the governmental outlook, I would say just very broadly that the tone of the comments in the public arena up there are improving. I think that there is a recognition that getting the Canadian national resources to points where they can be extra ported and no longer dependent upon so lead the U.S. market is a good thing across Canada. And that's starting to show up as people are being constructive about, okay, we need to approve project. We want to approve them with -- we want to have the right conditions in the right process around that approval but if -- there's been a switch I think toward a momentum toward getting the project approved. Now I'll say that with an important caveat. We don't know what their conditions or ultimately going to be in the end, and we'll have to make an assessment of that when they're all in. We certainly have a good handle on what the NED proposed conditions are going to look like but we don't know what if any other conditions may be oppose. So we'll have to watch for that may be very carefully. But we've had good returns, good underlying customer to support contractual support and improving tone I think in the public sector debate.

So you generally aim for a higher return.

And so it's still too early to give anything it's too specific. I think that 1 general observation is that the NED Project had scale. And so the tariff was better likely than what smaller project development tariffs would be. So it's not likely to -- it's not going to be something that's going to add up in the end from an NDP size projects. It's going to be bits and pieces out there.

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a fair assessment. I mean, we'll just have to work with our -- particularly, our LDC customers and see what we can do on expansion in bits and pieces and existing PGP system and see for supplementals [indiscernible] but clearly there's need bo
componenttext: Yes, that's a fair assessment. I mean, we'll just have to work with our -- particularly, our LDC customers and see what we can do on expansion in bits and pieces and existing PGP system and see for supplementals [indiscernible] but clearly there's need both in the near term and ultimately we believe in the long-term in the region but we'll just try to scale up with that demand as it develops.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good color. And then as a follow-up on that one, this uptick partner question not KMI specific but Northeast infrastructure. Any comments that you care to put out there in terms of projects that are needed but contrasted against producer balance she
componenttext: Okay. Good color. And then as a follow-up on that one, this uptick partner question not KMI specific but Northeast infrastructure. Any comments that you care to put out there in terms of projects that are needed but contrasted against producer balance sheet and the ability to kind of back stop those projects. Do you see any issues over the next 2 or 3 years in terms of get gas out of the basin?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's obviously, harder for producers to commit and we're seeing that in our business to commit to large expansions to move gas out of the basin. I think on the other side of the other end of the pipe, I mean, we think and a lot of other thir
componenttext: Well, I think it's obviously, harder for producers to commit and we're seeing that in our business to commit to large expansions to move gas out of the basin. I think on the other side of the other end of the pipe, I mean, we think and a lot of other third-parties have pointed out that the new England market needs national gas and new needs should the gas. So we think that need is already there. But there is a regulatory process that has to get sorted out there for how the power part of the business is going to procure the needs for their generating assets. And that's been a work in progress. It hasn't -- and who knows when they ultimately get that resolved. So there's definitely less produce or push activity for anything large. And we think on the demand side, infrastructure is still needed. But they've got to come to terms on how they can get contracted for.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I'm not sure I want to get into that customers particularly thinking or choice process the main. I think the main thing from our standpoint is we needed that and we needed the additional sign up. And the insight into why we didn't, I get it. We don't think it has anything to do with quality of the project. It's a good quality project. I think it relates to it something we close the last answer with, which is that the process is up there but just has not fully formed in a way that will allow the electric generation for in on a long-term basis to get approved and costs passed through. So I think those are the 2 things that really kept us from really going where we needed to go on the electric part of the business not because there was inferiority in our proposal.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's clearly lower activity. I mean, I think the rig count there is 40% below what we were looking at and thinking about in October. And so it doesn't mean that it can't come back at some point. There's an oil window, there's an NGL window and all of this
componenttext: It's clearly lower activity. I mean, I think the rig count there is 40% below what we were looking at and thinking about in October. And so it doesn't mean that it can't come back at some point. There's an oil window, there's an NGL window and all of this is associated production. The gas is coming out as associated gas. But I think that takes commodity price recovery for people to come back and start deploying rigs and complete wells and the rest of it.

componenttext: Yes, oil is down 28% from its peak, gas 15% and so they're big declines I think again KMCC's resilience has been surprising and has been really driven if you see this in the Bakken 2 that there are some places that there is still some activity going on and that's still cap that KMCC and relatively off the volume levels comparatively. But the overall basin is in decline and will be until there's price recovery that draws the rigs back out.

With regard to this common theme of being focused for have equity holders here and, obviously, recognizing the ability to fund the 100% off with cash for the next few years that being on top of the priority list. headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well let me answer the first question first. And that is we remain consistent with what we said previously that as we promised the rating agencies that we would be in the range of 5.5x going down to 5x debt-to-EBITDA and we would anticipate achieving the
componenttext: Well let me answer the first question first. And that is we remain consistent with what we said previously that as we promised the rating agencies that we would be in the range of 5.5x going down to 5x debt-to-EBITDA and we would anticipate achieving the bottom end of that range on a going forward basis. With regard to the second thing. That will be a decision that we'll make as that cash flow comes to fruition. And at that time, we'll just look at all the factors and see what makes sense. I think it's an enviable position to be in I feel that way is the largest shareholder. And we'll look at it if it makes sense to buy back shares at that time. We'll buy it back. I can tell you that for the price where it is today, at $19, we would buy it back. But we'll see what the price is and see what the market looks like and whether we benefit our shareholders in a better way by buying back our shares or by receive the dividend. But we'll have the capacity for either one if we want to do that one we get more funding of our capital projects done and once we get our balance sheet in the shape that we want to get it in.

componenttextpreview: Yes, interestingly, we're kind of on the net positive right now. We went through a process on our Hiland Midstream assets of -- I think the easiest way to think about it is we have a new deal to enable us to hook up more production up there and that was a
componenttext: Yes, interestingly, we're kind of on the net positive right now. We went through a process on our Hiland Midstream assets of -- I think the easiest way to think about it is we have a new deal to enable us to hook up more production up there and that was advantageous to producers as well as to us. We fixed our fees sent to commodity exposure off and producer wanted that. Wanted to have the commodity upside. But the bottom line for us is we improved our position on a 2016 basis and improved our fee recovery for on those really renegotiating contracts. So we're up so far this year. Now other customers will approach us in the gas group occasionally on contract restructurings. So far, we haven't had to do anything that we didn't want to do meaning finding something that had mutual benefit, finding incremental revenues that we could -- I'm sorry, incremental volumes that we could put on. At the same time we made some concession that they wanted. So I think they've been generally win-win situations, Tom. So I think it -- a pretty good story so far for us.

componenttext: We've got a -- we pulled a lot of collateral in and we've also done some other alternatives things. componenttext: And so they circulated for interagency comment. What happened essentially is FERC put together all of the -- on the same time line, all of the certificate discussion. So we ended up with that delay. We spent a lot of time with those agencies. We think we've addressed -- we think that the concerns are largely addressed and that's the part of the process that they're in now. componenttext: Not sure I can give you one of the latter other than to emphasize what Rich said, which is a lot of fair amount of competition for people wanting to invest in these. We're maintaining flexibility. We think that the JVs that were pursuing do make sense and they do make sense in 2 ways. One is getting someone else to share the capital burden at the development heart of it but also we believe that we'll see a nice promote, nice compensation, if you will, for the -- for having originated the project and that helps boost our return on the capital that we do deploy. So in other words, we think the ones that we're pursuing makes sense and we can expect to continue to pursue them.

componenttextpreview: I think they're being cautious about their next move. I think they want to see generally -- they're wanting to see some additional recovery in some additional stability in that recovery. I also think that as a group, they've made themselves very, very fle
componenttext: I think they're being cautious about their next move. I think they want to see generally -- they're wanting to see some additional recovery in some additional stability in that recovery. I also think that as a group, they've made themselves very, very flexible. I mean, they are updating their outlook and a decision it's no longer in annual process it seems like it's a biweekly process looking at things which suggests that when they do decide to turn things back up, they'll be able to turn them back up relatively quickly. But look, as I said before, people signing up for a long-term multi-hundred million dollar, a billion dollar infrastructure on the producer side, I just don't think that's in the cards in the near term.

componenttext: We have capital going to work there right now we just elevated the return criteria to as Kim said, 15% unlevered after-tax or better. We actually approved a project today that had a 43% return. These are small. The capital program on CO2 is now just a little over $200 million but we continue to approve small program spends in the CO2 group. And I think the easiest way to think about it, Becca is where we bought an existing plot that's up and running and so what we're doing is using share facilities maybe adding an injector injecting a current producing well to an ejector, drilling a new producing well we've got all the new facilities all the central facilities in place. The incremental -- the return on the incremental capital spend that we make is still attractive. Now if you're talking about a brand-new CO2 flood and get those started, that's a ways off. I think you need to see a fair amount of oil price recovery before you start to see that 50, 55. You need to see significant oil price recovery before you start to see that.

componenttext: On the interest expense is that the fair value accounting? Okay. So Becca, when we -- that has to be a certain recurring item that happens every quarter. When we acquire other companies and assume a there debt, we have to fair value that debt. And once we fair value that debt, then the interest expense that we recognized is not the same as the interest expense that is on the note and the interest expense that we pay. And so we classify the difference as a certain item.

componenttext: Let me lay out what the process is. So in the -- will be beginning on -- we have we're looking at costs right now. But we'll have our final conditions and know what all of our obligations are going to be. We think December or January, right? I mean, it's December for the federal process to be continued and I think about that same time frame we'll understand where we are with British Columbia. And then after that, we owe our customers an updated cost estimates so you're talking about your question on timing that's really kind of a first quarter off next year event. We don't have an update on the 6.8 because we're still evaluating what we think the projects are going to cost us. The project is going to costs us and it's going to be a little bit dependent on the conditions. I think a couple of things. One is that there is some cost pressure. The Canadian dollar has weakened relative to U.S. dollar. A lot of goods and services are provided in U.S. dollar terms. So there's been some pressure there. There have been some conditions that we've agreed to and that have added over time, which put some pressure on. But I think in the -- at the end of the day, what matters is do the customers want the project. And we still have very strong interest from our shippers in the project. And we even have interest from shippers who are not currently our customers -- potential customers who are not currently shippers on the project. So we talk about this all the time. But I think this is still a project that our customers want.

componenttext: Well let me tell you kind of I think that the rating agencies based on our conversations with them are comfortable with our credit rating and our credit outlook. And what we said is we are going to use that cash flow to fund our CapEx and to improve our balance sheet, and until we get that balance sheet improved to the 5.0 target, we're not going to do other things with that cash flow. So we will, absent our cash flow going away, which as we said every year for the last 18 years that we have very stable fee-based cash flow, we will have that cash flow. We will improve our leverage metrics. And once that happens, then we'll look at our uses for our cash.
