componenttext: Just on Elba, can you just walk us through the milestones that we should be looking for? And I think you said that you pushed out some of the timing on the CapEx for that -- for this project this year?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The big upcoming milestone is May when we expect to get our FERC certificate. And a milestone that just recently passed that we -- I think mentioned in the investor conference is we -- well, and it's announced publicly, so our contract with IHI. So t
componenttext: Yes. The big upcoming milestone is May when we expect to get our FERC certificate. And a milestone that just recently passed that we -- I think mentioned in the investor conference is we -- well, and it's announced publicly, so our contract with IHI. So they'll be our engineering procurement and construction contractor. That's a good milestone for us to get behind us that takes care of a lot of the construction risks. So we're looking for our FERC authorization upcoming in the next month, and we have our EPC contract behind us.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what do you need still left on the FERC certificate? You have the EEA, I think, but what's left exactly?
componenttext: And what do you need still left on the FERC certificate? You have the EEA, I think, but what's left exactly?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So they circulate it for interagency comments. And we had hoped that -- and in fact, Kim mentioned the delay in -- that the impact of the delay on are Elba Express and SNG expansions that are hurting the Southeast pipeline-- the South pipeline group in 20
componenttext: So they circulate it for interagency comments. And we had hoped that -- and in fact, Kim mentioned the delay in -- that the impact of the delay on are Elba Express and SNG expansions that are hurting the Southeast pipeline-- the South pipeline group in 2016. What happened essentially is FERC put together all of the -- on the same time line all of the certificate discussions. So we ended up with that delay as those projects were dragged into the overall Elba conversation, I guess, you'd say. What they're doing right now is they're getting interagency commentary. We've spent a lot of time with those agencies. We think we've addressed -- that we think their concerns are largely addressed. And that's the part of the process that they're in now. So we do expect to get a 7(c) certificate in May.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then if I can just ask, just again just coming back to the JVs, it sounds like you're still pushing forward there even though you've dropped the backlog a lot. I guess at some point, we are going to run into a lack of growth potentially,
componenttext: Okay, great. And then if I can just ask, just again just coming back to the JVs, it sounds like you're still pushing forward there even though you've dropped the backlog a lot. I guess at some point, we are going to run into a lack of growth potentially, given delays in Trans Mountain and whatnot. What -- how are you thinking philosophically about that? Do you back off of that if anything else falls out of the backlog, wanting to JV these projects. And then if you could give us a sense of the returns that your JV partners would look for on an unlevered basis?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not sure I can give you one of the latter other than to emphasize what Rich said, which is there's a lot of interest out there, fair amount of competition for people wanting to invest in these. We're maintaining flexibility. We think that the JVs that we'
componenttext: Not sure I can give you one of the latter other than to emphasize what Rich said, which is there's a lot of interest out there, fair amount of competition for people wanting to invest in these. We're maintaining flexibility. We think that the JVs that we're pursuing do make sense and making sense in 2 ways. One is getting someone else to share the capital burden on the development end of it, but also we do believe that we'll see a nice promote, nice compensation, if you will, for the -- for having originated the project. And that helps boost our return on the capital that we do deploy. So we -- in other words, Ted, I think we think that these make -- the ones that we're pursuing makes sense, and we expect to continue to pursue them.

componenttext: Not to beat a dead horse with regards to the JV funding. componenttext: Yes. We never really included -- we did attempt to get JV partners on NED, but we never really included that in our outlook. As I said at the conference, we had kind of 2 placeholder numbers, 2 placeholder JV opportunities. And it won't be -- it won't match perfectly what we had in the original outlook in terms of which ones we pursue. But we expect to meet our targets for what the JVs will do for us this year in terms of our capital -- our reduced capital spend.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in terms of juicing the returns on the CapEx you do spend because of your -- value you get from originating the projects with JV partners, do you see this simply taking projects already earning 15% plus and juicing it all the more or do you see
componenttext: Okay. And in terms of juicing the returns on the CapEx you do spend because of your -- value you get from originating the projects with JV partners, do you see this simply taking projects already earning 15% plus and juicing it all the more or do you see it taking projects that initially may not have been up to those standards but can be pushed to those standards with the JVs?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think we first start by looking at what we need to do for our balance sheet metrics, but we do keep an eye on what the longer-term impact of the JV decision is. And we are picking projects that I think are attractive returns and that other
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think we first start by looking at what we need to do for our balance sheet metrics, but we do keep an eye on what the longer-term impact of the JV decision is. And we are picking projects that I think are attractive returns and that other people will find to be attractive returns. But we think that we can make better use of the capital that comes in from their participation in the JV, meaning them buying into the project and funding the CapEx. We can redeploy that in many of the ways that Rich mentioned better. So I think it's kind of  pulls things as you were saying.

componenttext: Okay. Okay, great. And then I'm just curious, you've brought the CapEx number down to $2.9 billion. Is the bias here to reduce the CapEx budget more or, I mean, do you think that's -- you're going to go forward here around this level?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we believe this is a reasonable estimate here, but we will keep looking at it. And ideally, what we'd like to do, John, is keep finding ways to save costs, improve scope, add customers to projects to boost returns. But we'll continue to look at it
componenttext: I think we believe this is a reasonable estimate here, but we will keep looking at it. And ideally, what we'd like to do, John, is keep finding ways to save costs, improve scope, add customers to projects to boost returns. But we'll continue to look at it to improve it. We are authorizing small additional projects. They're very small. They have very good returns. They kind of build offs on our existing network. But this number reflects all of that, along with the reductions that we just -- that we've been talking about on the call. But I -- so I think this is a reasonable estimate. There's the possibility of taking a little bit more out of it, but this is a reasonable estimate to use.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, as far as taking a little bit more out of it, I mean, do you think that's going to come more from project deferrals or more cost reductions? How are you thinking there?
componenttext: Okay. I mean, as far as taking a little bit more out of it, I mean, do you think that's going to come more from project deferrals or more cost reductions? How are you thinking there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it will be more within the project. In other words, we look at the project and it gets delayed or deferred or we find a cost saving in it.
componenttext: I think it will be more within the project. In other words, we look at the project and it gets delayed or deferred or we find a cost saving in it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with crude oil prices improving here off -- obviously off mid-quarter, they're up -- we're up about 50% or so. I mean, how are -- what's your read on customer mood now? I mean, is it cautiously optimistic, people still resisting project pro
componenttext: Okay. And then with crude oil prices improving here off -- obviously off mid-quarter, they're up -- we're up about 50% or so. I mean, how are -- what's your read on customer mood now? I mean, is it cautiously optimistic, people still resisting project proposals or what's the read-through you guys are getting?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that they're being cautious about their next move. I think they want to see -- generally, they're wanting to see some additional recovery and see some stability in that recovery. I also think that as a group, they've made themselves very, very fle
componenttext: I think that they're being cautious about their next move. I think they want to see -- generally, they're wanting to see some additional recovery and see some stability in that recovery. I also think that as a group, they've made themselves very, very flexible. I mean, they are updating their outlook and updating their decision-making. It's no longer an annual process. It seems like it's a biweekly process or something now as they're looking at things, which suggests that when they do decide to turn things back up, they'll be able to turn them back up relatively quickly. But look, as I said before, people signing up for a long-term multi-hundred million dollar or billion dollar infrastructure on the producer side, I just don't think that that's in the cards in the near term.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are -- we have capital going to work there right now. We've just elevated the return criteria to, as Kim said, 15%, unlevered after tax or better. We actually approved a project today that had a 43% return. These are small. The capital program on CO2 i
componenttext: We are -- we have capital going to work there right now. We've just elevated the return criteria to, as Kim said, 15%, unlevered after tax or better. We actually approved a project today that had a 43% return. These are small. The capital program on CO2 is now just a little over $200 million, but we continue to approve small program spends in the CO2 group. And I think that the easiest way to think about it, Becca, is where we've got an existing flood that's up and running. And so what we're doing is using shared facilities, maybe adding an injector, converting a current producing well to an injector, drilling a new producing well. If we've got all the other facilities, all the central facilities in place, the incremental -- the return on the incremental capital spend that we make is still attractive. Now if you're talking about a brand-new CO2 flood and getting one of those started, that's a ways off. I think you need to see a fair amount of oil price recovery before you start to see that $50, $55. But you need to see significant oil price recovery before you start to see that.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the interest expense, is that the fair value accounting? Okay. So Becca, when we -- and that should be a recurring certain item that happens every quarter. When we acquire other companies and assume their debt, we have to fair value that debt. And once
componenttext: On the interest expense, is that the fair value accounting? Okay. So Becca, when we -- and that should be a recurring certain item that happens every quarter. When we acquire other companies and assume their debt, we have to fair value that debt. And once we fair value that debt, then the interest expense that we recognize is not the same as the interest expense that is on the note and the interest expense that we pay. And so we classify the difference as a certain item.

And it's just part of our normal process to -- I mean, we've amped it up a little bit here. But I mean, it's just part of a normal review process to look for those. But they're not huge. They may be material to an individual project but not huge in the overall scheme of things. But I think we'll keep finding them.

componenttext: Let me lay out what the process is. So in the -- we'll be getting -- again we have -- we're looking at costs right now. But we'll have our final conditions and know what all of our obligations are going to be. We think December or January, right? I mean, it's December for the federal process to conclude. And I think again about in that same time frame, we'll understand where we are with British Columbia. And then after that, we owe our customers an updated cost estimate. So you're talking about your question about timing, that's really a kind of a first quarter of next year event. We don't have an update on the $6.8 billion [ph] because we're still evaluating what we think the projects are going to cost us, and it will be a bit dependent upon the conditions. I think a couple things. One is that there is some cost pressure. The Canadian dollar has weakened relative to the U.S. dollar. A lot of the goods and services are provided in U.S.-dollar terms. So there's been some pressure there. There have been some conditions that we've agreed to and that have been added over time, which has put some pressure on. But I think in the -- at the end of the day, what matters is do the customers want the project? And we still have very strong interest from our shippers in the project, and we even have interest from shippers who are not currently customers -- potential customers who are not currently shippers on the project. So we talk about this all the time, but I think this is still a project that our customers want.

componenttext: Well, let me tell you kind of -- I think that the rating agencies based on our conversations with them are current -- are comfortable with our current rating and our current outlook. And I think at this point, we are funding 100% equity because we are using cash flow. And what we've said is we are going to use that cash flow to fund our CapEx and to improve our balance sheet. And until we get that balance sheet improved to the 5.0 target, we're not going to do other things with that cash flow. So we will, absent our cash flow going away, which as we've said every year for the last 18 years that we have very stable fee-based cash flow, we will have that cash flow. We will improve our leverage metrics. And once that happens, then we'll look at other uses for our cash.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the quarterly earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this point. Now I'll turn the meeting over to your host, Mr. Rich Kinder, Executive Chairman of Kin
componenttext:
Welcome to the quarterly earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this point. 
Now I'll turn the meeting over to your host, Mr. Rich Kinder, Executive Chairman of Kinder Morgan. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Laura and welcome to our call. As always, before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's earnings release and this call include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 an
componenttext:
Okay, thank you, Laura and welcome to our call. As always, before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's earnings release and this call include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. We encourage you to read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and use of non-GAAP financial measures set forth at the end of our earnings release as well as review our latest filings with the SEC for a list of risk factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those in such forward-looking statements. 
Let me begin by just making very few introductory comments before turning the call over to our CEO, Steve Kean, and our CFO, Kim Dang. First of all, the operating results for both the second quarter and year-to-date are very consistent with Kim's guidance, which she shared with you on our Q1 call and which were in our Q1 earnings release. And I think this demonstrates once more that our assets are consistent generators of strong cash flow even in these times of volatility. 
Several specific events have happened since our last call, mostly positive. First of all, the National Energy Board of Canada recommended approval of our Trans Mountain expansion project. This is an important step. But we still need an Order in Council and that decision is expected in December of this year. 
We also entered into joint ventures. As you know, with Southern Company, on our SNG natural gas system and with Riverstone on our UTOPIA Pipeline Project. And have also divested an additional approximate $175 million of non-core assets. These steps allow us to significantly improve our balance sheet with the expectation of now ending this year, 2016, at about 5.3x debt-to-EBITDA, which is an improvement from the 5.5x budget. In addition, we're also reducing our future need for expansion CapEx and all of this is getting us measurably closer to being able to return significant additional cash to our shareholders through either increasing the dividend or buying back shares. I can assure you we will continue on this flight path as we work to maintain and strengthen our balance sheet while at the same time, preparing to deliver increased value to our shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Steve.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, thanks. I'm going to update on capital and counterparty credit and then hit on some additional segment highlights and trends that we're seeing. On the capital update, we've been talking for several quarters now about high grading the backlog an
componenttext:
All right, thanks. I'm going to update on capital and counterparty credit and then hit on some additional segment highlights and trends that we're seeing. On the capital update, we've been talking for several quarters now about high grading the backlog and how we do that. That consists of making sure that we are attending to our balance sheet but also ensuring that we grow our DCF per share through the investments that we're making at attractive returns and that we are now funding out of the excess cash flow that we generate without needing to access the capital market. 
The high grading includes select joint ventures on assets and projects. The UTOPIA JV shows that we can originate high-value midstream projects that are valued by investors. On SNG, we are entering a JV with our largest customer and a transaction which brings value to that asset with specifically identified opportunities and is accretive in the medium term. We have trimmed some projects in the backlog where they don't make sense from a return standpoint or in today's commodity price environment. And we've also made scope and cost savings improvement and, in some cases, deferred cost on some projects that we are proceeding with. One example of this improvement is in the gas group in this quarter. And part of the reduction in the backlog is due to this. We renegotiated the contract with the customer. The result of that renegotiation was a reduction in our capital spend for that project, a boosted return, acceleration of the in-service data and a proportion of the revenues and we freed up some capacity that we believe we can resell. Meanwhile, the customer got the benefit of the lower cost, longer-term [indiscernible] for [indiscernible]. We're going to continue to work on additional opportunities within our backlog and in addition to our current projects. 
The results of these efforts is a backlog which now has an EBITDA multiple of 6.5x CapEx, that's excluding CO2 projects which tend to have a higher return but are more commodity price sensitive. We now expect to spend discretionary capital of $2.8 billion in 2016, which is down from $2.9 billion last quarter that we estimated for the year, and down $500 million from the plan for the year. Our backlog is now $13.5 billion, down to $14.1 billion. And as a function of projects going into service, the UTOPIA JV, the project renegotiation that I mentioned and that is again some project decision. So in short, we are making good progress and doing what we told you we would do and that progress is on the balance sheet as well as positioning us to grow our DCF per share. 
On customer credit, we continue our extreme focus throughout our commercial and corporate organization. In the past quarter, credit default amounted to about 0.3, 0.3% of budgeted revenue annualized and most of that is associated with the Peabody bankruptcy which equates to the first 2 weeks of the quarter. Without that, we would be well under 0.1%. And again, putting our situation in perspective, we're a broadly diversified midstream company, we've got a strong and diversified customer base, which includes integrated energy majors, utilities and end users. So the credit fixture is stabilizing. 
Now for some of the segment highlights and trends. Overall, and I compare it to a year-over-year basis to segment earnings before DD&A and certain items is down $31 million or 2% from Q2 of 2015 to Q2 of '16. CO2 -- so $31 million down -- CO2 by itself is down $59 million due to lower prices primarily and lower production. Even though CO2 is making plan due to surprise improvements and good performance on the cost savings front. 
Compared to the last -- the same quarter last year, GAAP is down 1% while terminals and products are 4% and 8%, respectively. So broad themes on our year to year performance. We continue -- number 1, we continue to see strong demand for natural gas across our network, transport volumes are up 5% year-over-year. We're getting good terms on storage, transportation and sales renewals in our business. 
Power burn on our pipe is up 8% year-over-year. And recall that power burn was up 16% from Q2 of '14 to '15. So there's strong compounding growth coming from the power sector. For the first time ever, gas is making up a larger share of the fuel for power generation and coal. That's been true year-to-date for 2016 and very close in 2015. In the last, most recent quarter, Q2 of '16, 35% of generation came from gas versus 27% from coal. Gas exports are up [indiscernible]. Exports to Mexico have grown to 3.3 Bcf a day and 3/4 of that volume moves on Kinder Morgan pipes. We continue to believe and will see the need for natural gas transportation storage services growing as the demand in the power sector, power generation sector, industrial sectors continues to grow, along with export demand for Mexico and LNG. 
The product pipelines we're getting the benefit year-over-year of higher volumes on KMDC and Cochin and the startup on the second splitter unit in the Houston Ship Channel. 
In terminals, we are seeing the benefit of new liquids capacity coming online. And remember, liquids makes up a little better than 3/4 of our segment earnings before DD&A in this business and we're also seeing increased utilization of that expanded capacity. So more capacity online and higher overall utilization of that capacity. 
The second quarter was a record-setting quarter of throughput on our liquids terminals. 
On the bulk side, while coal volumes is down year-over-year, other bulk volumes are partially offsetting that declines, particularly in petco and metals. We also renewed our steel handling arrangement with Nucor for 10 years with some value enhancements in that new deal. Overall, in the bulk part of the business, the entire year-over-year change can be explained by the coal bankruptcy. 
The negatives affecting the business on a year-over-year basis are, of course, lower commodity prices, which affected directly in the enhanced oil recovery part of CO2 and indirectly in our gathered volumes of gas and crude and condensates. But even with oil prices and gas prices that are lower year-over-year by 18% and 26%, respectively, we're showing durable performance from our portfolio. 
Lastly, an update on our Trans Mountain expansion. This continues to be a 2 steps forward, 1 step back development. I'll start with the fundamentals. What we consistently hear from our producer customers in Canada is that they're counting on this project to get built. Putting the recent fires aside in Alberta, production continues to grow and take away capacity projects continue to be behind this demand. Oil prices have hurt Alberta for sure. But from the perspective of our expansion, the supply and demand fundamentals for take away capacity are good. With the list of the federal review process, as Rich mentioned, we have our ENB recommendation, finding the project to be in the public interest and the federal government is undertaking its further consultation process with the objective of final decision in December this year. We've made great progress with communities along the route, have agreements to support for a majority of the most directly affected First Nations stand. We are actively engaged with the B.C. government on the satisfaction of their five conditions and we are making very good progress there. We are going to be actively working with contractors over the summer on the always challenging work on cost and final scope of the project. 
Finally, before turning over to Kim for the financials, I'm going to point out, you probably noticed that the release is in a slightly different format than usual. What we're doing is showing GAAP measures with equal or greater prominence further [ph] recent SEC guidance as a public company. As always, we'll continue to show you all the numbers, including the non-GAAP measures that we use in our management of the business. This is the business format we'll show going forward. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Kim.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Let me start by reiterating three overall financial points that Rich mentioned to you that we believe you should take over from this call. Number 1, as Rich said, our full-year guidance does not change from the updated guidance we gave you
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Let me start by reiterating three overall financial points that Rich mentioned to you that we believe you should take over from this call. Number 1, as Rich said, our full-year guidance does not change from the updated guidance we gave you last quarter. We continue to expect that EBITDA will be about 3% below budget and DCF will be approximately 4% below budget. 
To be consistent with the guidance we gave you last quarter, this guidance does not include the impact of the SNG JV which we anticipate will close in the late third or early fourth quarter. 
Secondly, we expect to end the year at 5.3x debt-to-EBITDA, which is down from our budget guidance and [indiscernible] the guidance we gave you last quarter, largely as a result of our balance sheet improvement efforts. When you analyze the EBITDA impact from the SNG transaction, we expect that the full-year impact would be slightly higher than the 5.3x. 
And third, our debt-to-EBITDA target is still around 5x. And once we've reach that level, we will decide how to return value to shareholders and we're not committing to a specific method at this time. 
Our dividend today. We are declaring a dividend of $0.125 per share consistent with our budget and the guidance we gave you at December of last year. 
Looking at our GAAP income statement, you will see that revenues are down significantly. As I say in many quarters, we do not believe that revenue or the changes in revenues are necessarily good predictors of our performance. We have some businesses where revenues and expense fluctuate with commodity prices but margin generally does not. Which is why you also see a large change across the sales during the quarter. 
In addition, our GAAP numbers can be impacted by noncash, nonrecurring accounting entries for what we call certain items. 
So if you turn to the second page of numbers, which shows our Bcf for the quarter and year-to-date, I believe you'll get a better picture of our performance. We generated total DCF for the quarter of 1.05 billion, versus 1.095 billion for the comparable period in 2015. Therefore, total DCF was down about 45 million or 4%. The segments were down approximately 31 million or 2% with a $59 million decrease in CO2 offsetting increases in terminals and products. The $31 million decrease in the segment was partially offset by $23 million decrease in G&A and interest expense. If you net out the $39 million increase in our preferred stock dividend, you get a DCF variance [ph] of $47 million versus the $45 million that we show on the page. There are a bunch of other moving parts but that gives you the main one. 
DCF per share was $0.47 in the quarter versus $0.50 for the second quarter of last year or down $0.03, with about $0.02 associated with the DCF variance that I just walked you through and about $0.01 due to the additional shares that we issued during 2015 to finance our growth projects and maintain our balance sheet. Therefore, despite approximately 20% decline in commodity prices versus the second quarter of last year, our performance was down approximately 4%. 
We believe these results demonstrate the resiliency of our cash flows generated by a large diversified platform, primarily fee-based assets. 
Certain items in the quarter were relatively small, income of approximately $8 million. But let me describe a couple of them that you wouldn't have seen before so we'll make sure you know what they are. We had a contract early termination revenue, which is $39 million of income, which was associated with a customer buying out of its source contract on one of our Texas Interstate storage fields. We also had a $21 million in legal and environmental reserves and that was primarily related to settlement of our over tenure litigation matter with the City of San Diego. 
Now let me give you a little bit more granularity on our expected performance for the full year versus our budget. We expect natural gas pipeline to come in approximately 2% below its budget, primarily as a result of the lower volumes in our midstream group and a 4.5 months in-service delay on our EEC SNG pipeline expansion as a result of a delay in receiving our FERC certificate. 
CO2 is expected to end the year on its budget. And essentially here, what's happening is we have some price help in cost savings that are offsetting a little bit lower oil in CO2 volumes than we budgeted. We currently expect terminals to end the year at about 4% below its budget, primarily due to the impact of the coal bankruptcy. We expect products to end the year approximately 5% below its budget due to lower crude and condensate volume on KMCC, Double H and Double Eagle, lower rates in our SSPP pipeline and the sale of our Parkway pipeline. Right now, we're projecting KMCC to be essentially on budget. 
On the expense side, interest, cash taxes, G&A and sustaining CapEx on a combined basis are expected to come in positive versus budget, or said another way, generate a favorable variance, primarily as a result of lower interest. 
And with that, I will move to the balance sheet. 
On the balance sheet, we ended the quarter with $41.3 billion in debt. That is an increase in debt of about $97 million since the end of last year and is a decrease in debt versus where we ended the first quarter of about $234 million. So let me reconcile that for you. 
DCF in the quarter, as I mentioned a moment ago, was $1.05 billion. We spent about 800 -- a little under $870 million on expansion CapEx and contributions to equity investments. We distributed or paid dividends of about $279 million. We have-- we received proceeds from asset divestitures and JVs of about $220 million and then working capital and other items was a source of cash of about $110 million. 
Year-to-date, we generated $2.28 billion in distributable cash flow. We spent about $1.88 million on expansion capital, on acquisitions and on contributions to equity investments with the only significant acquisition being the acquisition of the BP terminals in the first quarter. We paid dividends of $558 million and we have proceeds from asset divestitures and JVs of $220 million and then we had working capitals used of about $160 million, that gets you to the $97 million increase in debt year-to-date. 
We ended the quarter at about 5.6x debt-to-EBITDA, which is consistent where we ended last year and consistent where we ended the first quarter. And as we have mentioned a couple of times on the call, we expect to end the year at 5.3x debt-to-EBITDA. 
So with that, I'll turn it back to Rich.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Kristina Kazarian from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Kristina Kazarian from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I know you guys, just last week, so sorry for doing it again, but I think I'm getting a lot of questions. Can you guys just help me recap the profile of assets you'd be up for JV-ing? So I know you talked about Elba. Any thoughts on timeframe to that?
componenttext: So I know you guys, just last week, so sorry for doing it again, but I think I'm getting a lot of questions. Can you guys just help me recap the profile of assets you'd be up for JV-ing? So I know you talked about Elba. Any thoughts on timeframe to that? And then TMX is the largest stand-alone project in the backlog. So would you be up for doing anything in any way on this one?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we have not been talking about specific JVs other than what we -- what's kind of been as a placeholder, right, when we announced our plans for the year. And there are competitive reasons for doing that. We want to -- we don't want to be beholding
componenttext: Yes. So we have not been talking about specific JVs other than what we -- what's kind of been as a placeholder, right, when we announced our plans for the year. And there are competitive reasons for doing that. We want to -- we don't want to be beholding to any 1 particular transaction. We've got some commercial considerations and competitive considerations around counter parties that we are working with there. So we're not identifying, for you, the whole list of things that we would be considering. But I think it's safe to say that we would look at and evaluate, if we could make it work, just about anything on our backlog that is separable, that we think we can extract good value for and that we can get promoted on and boost our return on it. And we'll have kind of the full list. Now a lot of the things that are in our backlog are things that are components of our existing network, our existing asset base. And so those are a lot harder. The other thing I would point out is, and this was part of our strategy in maintaining some flexibility on what we would work on and what we could've done, we've gotten so far already this year. We've gotten to a point where we brought our debt-to-EBITDA metric down to 5.3x which is better than where we'd expected to end the year. So I know that's not a definitive answer on here's the list of things that we look at doing. That's the kind of characteristics of things that we look at doing and we made great progress on it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. On TMS, can you remind us what the next steps would be if we get the Order of Council on December?
componenttext: That's helpful. On TMS, can you remind us what the next steps would be if we get the Order of Council on December?

componenttext: Yes. So there is another process going on which is the B.C. Environmental Assessment or the Environmental Certificate, I guess, you would call it, which we believe will be close in time to when the federal decision comes out. Maybe it lags by a month or so. That's another requirement. And again, we're working through the B.C. conditions by-process which is the premier statement of conditions that you would like to see in order to sanction a project, right, and we are making good progress on those negotiations.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then last one for me, it's an asset level one. Can you talk a little bit more about the gathered volume number? Was this kind of in-line with what you guys are thinking post 1Q, especially in the Eagle Ford? And then the same thing on that incr
componenttext: Right. And then last one for me, it's an asset level one. Can you talk a little bit more about the gathered volume number? Was this kind of in-line with what you guys are thinking post 1Q, especially in the Eagle Ford? And then the same thing on that increasing power demand being up so much?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on -- I would say, first on the gathered volumes. We made some good progress during this quarter, maybe a little bit at the end of last quarter in terms of signing and we would sign 6 or 7, I think 6, with existing shippers and 7 with the new shipper
componenttext: Yes, on -- I would say, first on the gathered volumes. We made some good progress during this quarter, maybe a little bit at the end of last quarter in terms of signing and we would sign 6 or 7, I think 6, with existing shippers and 7 with the new shipper, kind of incentive agreements, to try to bring volumes to our system above the contract minimum. So we lost some volumes on our Eagle Ford system that we are now getting back by entering into these arrangements. So it's probably a little bit worse than what we would've been shooting for, hoping for. But I think we've taken the right steps during the quarter to get some volumes incented back on the system. And so I look for improvements here. Yes, and then on power. We were watching to kind of see how power generation would play out. I think I'll say in [indiscernible] is here too, a little surprised on the upside on the year-over-year improvement when you think about how big of a leap we had last year. Now if you look at the year-to-date number, it's not quite as strong because we have that weak winter. And so Q1 was actually down a bit. But if you looked on a Q2-to-Q2 basis, after having a very, very robust growth from '14 to '15, we saw growth on top of that -- of 8%. And here, I'm just talking about our system. So 8% on top of that 16% that we saw before which I think was very strong. And I think bodes well. We had another data point there, as we had 5 of our 6 biggest days for power generation on the SNG system happened in the last 45 days. 5 of our biggest, 5 of the 6 biggest.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to clarify, I guess, your response to Kristina's question about the JV income of assets. So I'm to understand the backlog correctly, if there's a project that is basically a brownfield expansion to an existing asset, that makes it more difficult to pull off a JV but not impossible but more likely to happen on something that is more discreet, is that a fair way to think about it?

componenttext: That's a good way to think about it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then if I remember your call from last week, you sort of indicated that [indiscernible] SNG asset sale [indiscernible] you took an operating asset and then entered that into a JV. That seemed more of a one-off type of thing and not to really thi
componenttext: Okay, and then if I remember your call from last week, you sort of indicated that [indiscernible] SNG asset sale [indiscernible] you took an operating asset and then entered that into a JV. That seemed more of a one-off type of thing and not to really think about that on a go-forward basis. Does that apply to your CO2 business? Or is that one segment that you would actually consider JV-ing or outright selling?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we said last week, I mean at general. It's not going to make a lot of sense for us in general to be selling interests in up and running assets. That tends to be an expensive way to raise capital. It was -- I would characterize it as a somewhat uni
componenttext: Yes, as we said last week, I mean at general. It's not going to make a lot of sense for us in general to be selling interests in up and running assets. That tends to be an expensive way to raise capital. It was -- I would characterize it as a somewhat unique opportunity in the SNG case, because what we had there is our largest customer, our great power market in the Southeast U.S. and some specifically identified and agreed to opportunities that we can jointly pursue in this JV that, again, somewhat unusual for such a transaction would actually make the sale of an interest in an existing asset accretive in the medium term. I think that's a fairly unique situation. We had, as Kim mentioned in some of her updates on the cash numbers, proceeds from other asset sales that we did. And again, they are, I think, we've had a few others. They're somewhat exceptional. And it's either a case where  it's really a case where the customer on the asset or a third party has a much higher value, or places a higher strategic value on the underlying asset. Parkway was an example. There were some others, smaller examples during the quarter. We sold a small transfix facility which we were essentially just doing spot business through and really not making much of anything on it. We had a third-party who was interested in doing more with that asset. And so again, I think those are exceptional cases. But where we see them, we go get them.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I can follow up with some financial related questions. I guess, first of all, the credit market has been a lot more generous on issuers lately versus a couple of months ago. Has there been any thoughts to prefunding some of the upcoming maturitie
componenttext: Okay. If I can follow up with some financial related questions. I guess, first of all, the credit market has been a lot more generous on issuers lately versus a couple of months ago. Has there been any thoughts to prefunding some of the upcoming maturities? And I was wondering if you can also walk us through the -- a delta on maintenance CapEx, kind of seems light. Is it seasonal? Or is this part of your efforts to continue taking some costs out of this structure?

componenttext: Sure. On the debt side, you're right. I mean, we could issue tenure [ph] bonds right now at sub [ph] 4%. So very attractive market. We do not have any need to access the capital markets during 2016. We will continue to evaluate whether it might make economic sense to prefund 2017. Obviously, we're going to be -- what we expect later in the year, we'll be getting proceeds from the SNG transaction and so you had to take that into account as well. On the CapEx, it's the savings CapEx, we're going to come in, we think, probably about within 1% of our budget on sustaining CapEx. And so it is just, it's really -- we are running at a positive variance year-to-date versus our budget. But that's almost entirely timing.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it is timing of the work. We're still planning to do the work. We are getting some cost savings. But we also plan to get the cost savings. So it's relatively modest beyond what we budgeted for. And as always, the work that we've identified, that w
componenttext: Yes, so it is timing of the work. We're still planning to do the work. We are getting some cost savings. But we also plan to get the cost savings. So it's relatively modest beyond what we budgeted for. And as always, the work that we've identified, that we're doing for compliance and safety, we are focused on getting done and will get done in the year.

componenttext: Brandon, I think you're right. It does -- it puts us in a position of being more patient and selective as we look at any other opportunities really, for the balance of the year. So again, that's why we're very pleased with the progress that we've made here in the first half of the year and the fact that it does put us in a position to be more selective about what we want to do going from here.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That said, we are not sitting on our hands. We'll be looking at all opportunities. And again, it's our intent to get back as quickly as we can judiciously done to the point where we can return more money to our shareholders. That's our intent. We've been
componenttext: That said, we are not sitting on our hands. We'll be looking at all opportunities. And again, it's our intent to get back as quickly as we can judiciously done to the point where we can return more money to our shareholders. That's our intent. We've been saying that since we made our decision on the dividend last December. And I'm just enormously proud of the job that Steve and the whole team have done of getting us this far. There is more to come and we're working on it.

componenttext: Just a follow-up on that last question. So at this level of $220 million or so investment in the EUR business, what's your current yield and what ongoing decline rate we should expect going forward on oil volumes?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, not necessarily expecting an ongoing decline rate. I mean, what we do in this business is we're looking at deploying capital that gets us an attractive return on the incremental barrels that we are producing that is associated with that capital spend
componenttext: Yes, not necessarily expecting an ongoing decline rate. I mean, what we do in this business is we're looking at deploying capital that gets us an attractive return on the incremental barrels that we are producing that is associated with that capital spend. And so that's kind of how we look at each of our investments here. We don't aim to necessarily [indiscernible] where the returns, keep production flat or grow it slightly. We really make those decisions on each individual capital investment in the development programs that we spend money on at CO2.

componenttextpreview: We have our contract with Shell. We have a FERC 7C [ph] certificate that we received in June, June 1. And what we're waiting on to receive there is we've got to get through the rehearing process and we're hearing profile, I guess, 30 days after we got our
componenttext: We have our contract with Shell. We have a FERC 7C [ph] certificate that we received in June, June 1. And what we're waiting on to receive there is we've got to get through the rehearing process and we're hearing profile, I guess, 30 days after we got our certificate. So there's, the hearing process that we're going through now, that should take 60 days from the date of that filing. And we still need that. We've got to get through that process.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones for me. The first, with regards to your comments around enhancing shareholder value. I'm just curious and I recognize its hypothetical. But I'm just curious, how the impact of the conversion of the preferred to common shares might influe
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones for me. The first, with regards to your comments around enhancing shareholder value. I'm just curious and I recognize its hypothetical. But I'm just curious, how the impact of the conversion of the preferred to common shares might influence your preference on which measure of equity value enhancement that you choose first, meaning, if it's a share repurchase to manage some of that incremental dilution or maybe it's a bit more of a balanced approach?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we've said, and Kim is very clear on it, we get to [indiscernible] which is our target. Then I think we'll look at what's the most opportune, expedient way of returning value to our shareholders. And we're not trying to judge in advance.
componenttext: Well, I think as we've said, and Kim is very clear on it, we get to [indiscernible] which is our target. Then I think we'll look at what's the most opportune, expedient way of returning value to our shareholders. And we're not trying to judge in advance. We won't do it just to avoid the potential dilution of the conversion of the fret. We'll look at where it make sense to buyback shares or increase the dividend. Again, we need to emphasize, we are running at a $2 DCF rate and we're pleased that the stock is rallied post the announcement on SNG, the $22 range. But that's still about a 9% yield on DCF. So we look at that and still amazed that it's that high.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate the color, Steve. One quick one for you. Just with regard to the Northeast. The expectation there possibly regarding TGP working with customers possibly expanding that system beyond what's stated and scaling it up with the developments
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate the color, Steve. One quick one for you. Just with regard to the Northeast. The expectation there possibly regarding TGP working with customers possibly expanding that system beyond what's stated and scaling it up with the developments that have transpired since the close of Q1, has anything changed there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We continue to talk to customers. But there's nothing definitive there, Darren. I mean, we are -- the need for gas in the Northeast is real, it's present. And we still think that there is, there are capacity needs. We'll talk to our customers and cont
componenttext: No. We continue to talk to customers. But there's nothing definitive there, Darren. I mean, we are -- the need for gas in the Northeast is real, it's present. And we still think that there is, there are capacity needs. We'll talk to our customers and continue to work with them on finding something that makes sense. Nothing of the same scale as [indiscernible] but perhaps something else. In the meantime, we are expanding TCP like mad. I mean, we're bringing gas down from the Marcellus and Utica down to the new market area, if you will, at the South, the Gulf Coast for LNG exports, we go to Mexico as well and in serving demand down here in Texas as well as power plant laterals, couple of other projects. So we are actively investing in TGP but no update, really, on Northeast utility customer contract.

componenttext: Yes, so first, on B.C., as I said, I think, Ian and the team have been making very good progress there. And I assume you're referring to the energy business through Bennett's comments here recently reported in Bloomberg. We think that the environment overall, I would say, is improving. And we are making progress in getting matters worked out with B.C. But we're not there yet. Still working on it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that again, hypothetically, from a JV perspective, I mean, the more of these kinds of things that we are able to resolve and get behind us, the more value there is to a potential investor. But again, we're not -- we've got nothing active going on
componenttext: I think that again, hypothetically, from a JV perspective, I mean, the more of these kinds of things that we are able to resolve and get behind us, the more value there is to a potential investor. But again, we're not -- we've got nothing active going on on the project. It's 100% ours right now. But I think whether it's 100% ours or ultimately whether there is a partner getting these things taken care of from a regulatory and political standpoint is very helpful.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going back to the 6.5x capital to EBITDA multiple you put in the press release, which is now down from the 7.5x you spoke at the Analyst Day. Can you just walk us through the details of how you got from 7.5 to 6.5? I'm assuming that's taking net out of
componenttext: So going back to the 6.5x capital to EBITDA multiple you put in the press release, which is now down from the 7.5x you spoke at the Analyst Day. Can you just walk us through the details of how you got from 7.5 to 6.5? I'm assuming that's taking net out of backlog but what are the other ways that you're bringing that multiple down on invested capital?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really kind of all the items that I listed out there. We've had some contracts restructured. We've had some projects that being the largest one, largest single one that had below-average returns compared to the overall backlog that have come out. W
componenttext: That's really kind of all the items that I listed out there. We've had some contracts restructured. We've had some projects that being the largest one, largest single one that had below-average returns compared to the overall backlog that have come out. We've also looked for ways to make on all of our projects if there's scope improvements that we could make, cost reductions that we can take on occasionally, pushing capital out to closer in time when the projects coming in service, all of those things helped return the -- improve the returns in the multiple on the existing project base.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And now with the new project base, can you just remind us how much of these projects actually have take-or-pay type of components or how much of them depend on volumes that were outside of your control thinking of terminals or other places?
componenttext: Okay. And now with the new project base, can you just remind us how much of these projects actually have take-or-pay type of components or how much of them depend on volumes that were outside of your control thinking of terminals or other places?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the majority are going to be under contracts with customers. And let's see, on our -- I mean, on a percentage basis, I guess, essentially what you can do is exclude the CO2 portion of it. And generally, everything else is going to be under contract.
componenttext: Yes, the majority are going to be under contracts with customers. And let's see, on our -- I mean, on a percentage basis, I guess, essentially what you can do is exclude the CO2 portion of it. And generally, everything else is going to be under contract.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And so then, I guess, just stepping back here, you're earning 6.5x multiple returns, which certainly, very good returns. At what point do you say, that's enough on asset sales, JVs, et cetera? Does this backlog is too good, we actually don't
componenttext: Okay, great. And so then, I guess, just stepping back here, you're earning 6.5x multiple returns, which certainly, very good returns. At what point do you say, that's enough on asset sales, JVs, et cetera? Does this backlog is too good, we actually don't want to give this up.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, look, the backlog and the projects that we're going to be bringing on are part of our effort to improve our DCF per share. So we're going to keep -- but that doesn't mean that we won't keep trying to find ways to optimize the scope and do other
componenttext: Yes, well, look, the backlog and the projects that we're going to be bringing on are part of our effort to improve our DCF per share. So we're going to keep -- but that doesn't mean that we won't keep trying to find ways to optimize the scope and do other things that are going to boost returns. Going forward, we've said fairly high -- look, we're in a get self funding world right now. And so we'll continue to look for incremental product opportunities. But we raised our return criteria to something, again, that's all -- it always varies on any individual project depending on the risks and rewards. But we've kind of used that as a rule of thumb of [ph] 15% of levered after tax return. So we continued to look for those projects and have authorized several along the way through the year. But we look to boost returns on what we have. But -- and we'll raise our return threshold as we look at incremental capital investment.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can just sneak one more on Trans Mountain. Any update on your views on the costs there to meet the 100 -- 7 conditions now that you had some time ago to go through them. Just remind us if you have any ability, if there was a cost were highe
componenttext: Okay. And if I can just sneak one more on Trans Mountain. Any update on your views on the costs there to meet the 100 -- 7 conditions now that you had some time ago to go through them. Just remind us if you have any ability, if there was a cost were higher, to pass those costs to the customers?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're working on the cost right now and working with our contractors right now and kind of will be over, really, over the course of the summer. And look, contractors always want more than what we want to pay them. And we're going to be pushing back hard o
componenttext: We're working on the cost right now and working with our contractors right now and kind of will be over, really, over the course of the summer. And look, contractors always want more than what we want to pay them. And we're going to be pushing back hard on that process over the course of the summer to try to keep talks down and under control. Once we arrive at a cost that we turn over to our shippers and our final estimate, which will read sometime early next year, or maybe later this, maybe late this year, Ian, [indiscernible], okay, then, we have flow-through protection on certain identified, uncontrollable costs and that includes things, that's once we've set the price, right, the cost has been set. And that includes things like the First Nations cost, steel costs, one of the more complex spreads through the mountain and then the last 40 miles -- 40-kilometer -- 40 kilometers in the Lower Mainland.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Faisel Khan from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is from Faisel Khan from Citigroup.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions. First, I just want to go back to some of the answers around the gathered volumes, the -- I was a little bit confused. So you've gone from roughly 3.5 DCF a day in gathered volumes, down to below 3 a day. And I think Steve, what you're say
componenttext: A few questions. First, I just want to go back to some of the answers around the gathered volumes, the -- I was a little bit confused. So you've gone from roughly 3.5 DCF a day in gathered volumes, down to below 3 a day. And I think Steve, what you're saying is that's basically it. A lot of that was sort of volumes above and beyond MPC and now you're saying that that's going to stabilize going forward?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what happens in the basin will drive a lot of that, right? I mean, starting to see some people come back to the Eagle Ford. But you not only had to come back, you had to bring a lot of rigs back in order to see that flatten back out and start to inc
componenttext: Well, what happens in the basin will drive a lot of that, right? I mean, starting to see some people come back to the Eagle Ford. But you not only had to come back, you had to bring a lot of rigs back in order to see that flatten back out and start to increase. And frankly, I don't think the basin is at that point yet. And so most of what we have been focusing on is where we lost some volumes to third parties, we're trying to incent those to come back to the system rather than just collecting the deficiency charges from those customers. And as I said, I think, we've made good progress over the course of the quarter in doing that. But by the -- the over -- so long as the overall basin is declining, we're -- what we're doing is fighting off decline and trying to stay above that decline rate, if you will. but I don't know if -- it depends on whether the basin decline starts to slow, I think, and level out. And now, I'll point out to, because we haven't talked about Highland. We actually had year-over-year and over budget improvement on our Highland gathering assets in North Dakota. A lot of that was due to, also, restructuring of contracts and primarily migrating them from percent of proceeds to fee base, which gives us both greater stability but also happen to have a beneficial impact on this year's earnings. So we'll talk a lot about Eagle Ford. In the Haynesville, we've done an arrangement to try to incent a current customer to do some drilling. And there, what we've done is we've divided, if you will, the contract between what's already under contract to us and new or incremental wells and providing discounts there to try to incent some drilling. But again, the overall gathering picture is primarily driven by what the overall basin picture is.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, but I mean, but to go from 3.5 to under 3 in 2 quarters is pretty extreme. I mean, is that level of decline going to continue until the end of the year?
componenttext: Okay, but I mean, but to go from 3.5 to under 3 in 2 quarters is pretty extreme. I mean, is that level of decline going to continue until the end of the year?

componenttext: I think, we may see some decline but it won't be at that rate.

componenttext: Okay, got you. And then on the Eagle Ford volumes that you talked about, that's just on the liquids side, the 3 -- going from 3 44 down to 3 04, that's what you're talking about there. Was there another mix of gas volumes you are talking about within the gathered volumes?

componenttext: There are significant gas gathered volumes in the Eagle Ford as well from our Eagle Ford gathering systems. And the assets that we acquired from Copano. And those are factored into our overall gas gathering volumes that we report on the numbers page.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That make sense on the GOP side. Then on the CO2 production volumes. I just want to go back to a question that was asked before. So the 15% decline in volumes year-over-year, that's not the natural decline rate, if I [indiscernible] the number corre
componenttext: Okay. That make sense on the GOP side. Then on the CO2 production volumes. I just want to go back to a question that was asked before. So the 15% decline in volumes year-over-year, that's not the natural decline rate, if I [indiscernible] the number correctly. I mean, I thought that the CO2 if you're not spending a lot of capital in SACROC and [indiscernible] that volumes might decline by about maybe mid-single digits based on how much CO2 you're injecting in the [indiscernible], the 15% seems like a lot.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jesse. No, it's not a natural decline. As Steve said earlier, we had a record quarter in half year in '15 based on a very successful infill program. The candidates are not as prolific in the area at the moment. So that's really the driver period to p
componenttext: It's Jesse. No, it's not a natural decline. As Steve said earlier, we had a record quarter in half year in '15 based on a very successful infill program. The candidates are not as prolific in the area at the moment. So that's really the driver period to period. It's the success of that particular infill project.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So what is the natural decline to feel from here on out, if you could give me a best guesstimate?
componenttext: Okay. So what is the natural decline to feel from here on out, if you could give me a best guesstimate?

componenttextpreview: Yes, it's probably more along the 6% to 9%, depending on the area in the field.
componenttext: Yes, it's probably more along the 6% to 9%, depending on the area in the field.

componenttext: Okay, understood. Last question for me, just on the asset sale program. Are -- there was some trade publication used that you were in the market to sell the Jones Tanker business. Is that still an asset that is on the market? Or have you pulled that asset from the market?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So one more if I could. The drive to get big returning capital to shareholders as quickly as possible, I'm just wondering, because have a lot of -- you have announced a lot of asset sales already. Just wondering, do you risk sort of going, raising t
componenttext: Okay. So one more if I could. The drive to get big returning capital to shareholders as quickly as possible, I'm just wondering, because have a lot of -- you have announced a lot of asset sales already. Just wondering, do you risk sort of going, raising too quickly to return capital back to shareholders and maybe on retaining assets that may have sort of better value over the longer term. So I'm just trying to understand, so that balance between asset sales and returning capital back to shareholders over a certain time period?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it is certainly a balancing process and we're certainly not going to sell anything that doesn't make sense strategically for us. And that's why for the most part, and Steve has explained I think very clearly, the thought behind the joint ven
componenttext: Well, I think it is certainly a balancing process and we're certainly not going to sell anything that doesn't make sense strategically for us. And that's why for the most part, and Steve has explained I think very clearly, the thought behind the joint venture with Southern company on SNG. But beyond that, our effort has been concentrated on new projects where we could bring somebody in who would reward us with the efforts we've made on those projects thus far and participate heads up on this on a going forward basis. So I think we're trying to balance this very carefully and we're not going to rush into anything that doesn't make sense strategically. We're obviously in this for the very long term.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Craig Scheer from Brothers.
componenttext: Our next question is from Craig Scheer from Brothers.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got three questions here. The first, pretty quick, on the fall to 6.5x, what I think was a guided 6.7x CapEx EBITDA on the remaining non-CO2 growth CapEx. Is that mostly on the efficiencies and that gas pipeline project restructuring? Or were monetized pr
componenttext: Got three questions here. The first, pretty quick, on the fall to 6.5x, what I think was a guided 6.7x CapEx EBITDA on the remaining non-CO2 growth CapEx. Is that mostly on the efficiencies and that gas pipeline project restructuring? Or were monetized projects and the completed Magnolia tanker at a higher multiples?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Magnolia would've been there all along. So really, it's -- it is the contract restructuring. It's the UTOPIA JV. Those are probably being the 2 main contributors to it. But also, we have, as I said, we've look for ways to cut spend or reduce scope
componenttext: I think Magnolia would've been there all along. So really, it's -- it is the contract restructuring. It's the UTOPIA JV. Those are probably being the 2 main contributors to it. But also, we have, as I said, we've look for ways to cut spend or reduce scope where we have the opportunity to do so without and enhance returns as a result. Those are probably 2 of the biggest single component.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And kind of a bigger picture here. I know the balance sheet repair and having the flexibility to return money to shareholders is foremost in your mind. But of course, if you had to make a choice and you had unlimited ability to reinvest at 6.
componenttext: Okay, great. And kind of a bigger picture here. I know the balance sheet repair and having the flexibility to return money to shareholders is foremost in your mind. But of course, if you had to make a choice and you had unlimited ability to reinvest at 6.5x EBITDA, certainly, that would be preferable than returning money to shareholders. Currently, excluding CO2 and [indiscernible], I think you have about $10 billion of proportional spend now from '16 to 2020 and over half of that is Trans Mountain. How would you handicap the prospects for this fee-based outstanding growth CapEx inventory to materially fill in and expand over the next couple of years?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, as Rick said, were trying to balance. The 2 things were trying to accomplish here. One is we want to get our debt-to-EBITDA down into the vicinity of 5x, okay? The other thing we want to do is grow the DCF per share. And that involves investi
componenttext: Well, again, as Rick said, were trying to balance. The 2 things were trying to accomplish here. One is we want to get our debt-to-EBITDA down into the vicinity of 5x, okay? The other thing we want to do is grow the DCF per share. And that involves investing in projects, as we've described, and getting good returns for the capital that we do deploy. And we're doing this in a context of being self funding. So we are trying to make sure that we are dedicating our capital that we have to the best returns we can get and not be in a position where we had to access the capital market -- where we have to access the capital market. So those are really the things we are balancing. We remain focused on getting the balance sheet in order and then improving our DCF per share. And we believe following that course will allow us to be in a position to return cash to shareholders. I think if you look at what our opportunities and it remains to be seen what the total investment opportunity is going to be out there. But I think there's a very reasonable case, right, a reasonable scenario where we're in a situation where we are generating significantly more cash, particularly as these projects come online, more cash than we are investing. And when we are in that position, we're going to be also in a position to either, as we said multiple times, either further delever the balance sheet or return value to shareholders in the form of buybacks or increase the dividends. And as we get closer in time too, that we'll be evaluating which one of those approaches is the best way for maximizing -- to maximize shareholder value.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. I guess what I'm trying to get at is, that there's a much higher value proposition potential. And that is if you get close to 5x net debt to EBITDA towards the end of next year and you have this flexibility and [indiscernible] issue 10-year [p
componenttext: Understood. I guess what I'm trying to get at is, that there's a much higher value proposition potential. And that is if you get close to 5x net debt to EBITDA towards the end of next year and you have this flexibility and [indiscernible] issue 10-year [ph] debt at sub 4%, if you could fund the half the cost of your growth CapEx at 6.5x with cheap debt, you would have enormous amounts of free cash flow to both fund the growth CapEx and return to shareholders. And I guess I'm trying to get a sense, if you think that having additional projects in line with the attractive inventory you currently have, I mean, there's a point you have over $20 billion of inventory. Do you think that there's prospects over the next 2, 3 years to start to recharge that?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, look, that's a possibility and that is absolutely something we would look at. But again, the place we're trying to maintain ourselves right now is not to have to access the capital market. It doesn't mean that on the right terms and conditions, we would.

componenttext: Okay, okay, and I think just final question for you. I don't mean to beat the dead horse. But I want to revisit sort of the balancing act that you spoke about with [indiscernible] and Craig's efforts or comments around sort of the deleveraging efforts versus capital deployment opportunities. If you recognize that you don't need to access to capital markets. But I'm just wondering, at what point, what are the conditions under which you would? But if the, I get the effort around JVs on in fill projects is seemingly the most attractive thing, particularly as the party can bring something to that other than just capital. You obviously have sustained asset sales. But it's kind of tricky when you're selling underlying cash flow and utilizing some of the NOL balance. So I'm just curious the goal around deleveraging -- where does that's -- where and when and if equity issuance will play into that?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think [indiscernible] at this level, we don't want to issue equity. And so, I think right now, we're going to live within our cash flow. And I think that as we look out in [indiscernible], we want to do projects. So we want to do projects that hav
componenttext: Well, I think [indiscernible] at this level, we don't want to issue equity. And so, I think right now, we're going to live within our cash flow. And I think that as we look out in [indiscernible], we want to do projects. So we want to do projects that have good returns on them. And so if they have good returns, we think that will be value creating to our investors. And so if we can do projects at 6.5x EBITDA, then that is going to be a priority. But as we look out in time and we look at the backlog that we have and we look at the potential opportunities that there may be, we see that there's probably going to be cash flow in excess of the capital projects once the balance sheet is repaired. And so that's why we're saying, once the balance sheet is repaired, then, at that point in time, we will be in the position to return value to shareholders through share repurchases or dividends because we think there will be some projects. Don't get me wrong. But we just think that the cash flow that we will have will exceed that amount of project.
