headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the quarterly earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this point. Now I'll turn the meeting over to your host, Mr. Rich Kinder, Executive Chairman of Kin
componenttext:
Welcome to the quarterly earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this point. 
Now I'll turn the meeting over to your host, Mr. Rich Kinder, Executive Chairman of Kinder Morgan. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Laura, and welcome to our call. As always, before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's earnings release and this call include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 a
componenttext:
Okay, thank you, Laura, and welcome to our call. As always, before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's earnings release and this call include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. We encourage you to read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and use of non-GAAP financial measures set forth at the end of our earnings release as well as review our latest filings with the SEC for a list of risk factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those in such forward-looking statements. 
Let me begin by just making very few introductory comments before turning the call over to our CEO, Steve Kean; and our CFO, Kim Dang. First of all, the operating results for both the second quarter and year-to-date are very consistent with Kim's guidance, which she shared with you on our Q1 call and which were in our Q1 earnings release. And I think this demonstrates once more that our assets are consistent generators of strong cash flow even in these times of volatility. 
Several specific events have happened since our last call, mostly positive. First of all, the National Energy Board of Canada recommended approval of our Trans Mountain expansion project. This is an important step. But we still need an Order in Council, and that decision is expected in December of this year. 
We also entered into joint ventures. As you know, with Southern Company on our SNG natural gas system and with Riverstone on our Utopia pipeline project. And have also divested an additional approximate $175 million of noncore assets. These steps allow us to significantly improve our balance sheet with the expectation of now ending this year, 2016, at about 5.3x debt-to-EBITDA, which is an improvement from the 5.5x budget. In addition, we're also reducing our future need for expansion CapEx and all of this is getting us measurably closer to being able to return significant additional cash to our shareholders through either increasing the dividend or buying back shares. I can assure you we will continue on this flight path as we work to maintain and strengthen our balance sheet while at the same time, preparing to deliver increased value to our shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Steve.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, thanks. I'm going to update on capital and counterparty credit and then hit on some additional segment highlights and trends that we're seeing. On the capital update, we've been talking for several quarters now about high grading the backlog
componenttext:
All right, thanks. I'm going to update on capital and counterparty credit and then hit on some additional segment highlights and trends that we're seeing. 
On the capital update, we've been talking for several quarters now about high grading the backlog and how we do that. That consists of making sure that we are attending to our balance sheet, but also ensuring that we grow our DCF per share through investments that we're making at attractive returns, and that we are now funding out of the excess cash flow that we generate without needing to access the capital market. 
The high grading includes select joint ventures on assets and projects. The Utopia JV shows that we can originate high-value midstream projects that are valued by investors. On SNG, we are entering a JV with our largest customer and a transaction which brings value to that asset through specifically identified opportunities and is accretive in the medium term. We have trimmed some projects in the backlog where they don't make sense from a return standpoint or in today's commodity price environment. And we've also made scope and cost savings improvement and, in some cases, deferred cost on projects that we are proceeding with. One example of this improvement is in the gas group in this quarter. And part of the reduction in the backlog is due to this. We renegotiated the contract with the customer. The result of that renegotiation was a reduction in our capital spend for that project, a boosted return, acceleration of the in-service date of a portion of the revenues, and we freed up some capacity that we believe we can resell. Meanwhile, the customer got the benefit of the lower-cost, longer-term solution for its need. We're going to continue to work on additional opportunities within our backlog and in addition to our current projects. 
The results of these efforts is a backlog which now has an EBITDA multiple of 6.5x CapEx. That's excluding CO2 projects which tend to have a higher return, but are more commodity price sensitive. We now expect to spend discretionary capital of $2.8 billion in 2016, which is down from $2.9 billion last quarter that we estimated for the year, and down $500 million from our plan for the year. Our backlog is now $13.5 billion, down from $14.1 billion. And as a function of projects going into service, the Utopia JV, the project renegotiation that I mentioned, and that is again some project decision. So in short, we're making good progress and doing what we told you we would do, and that progress is on the balance sheet as well as positioning us to grow our DCF per share. 
On customer credit, we continue our extreme focus throughout our commercial and corporate organization. In the past quarter, credit default amounted to about 0.3 -- 0.3% of budgeted revenue annualized and most of that is associated with the Peabody bankruptcy which equates to the first 2 weeks of the quarter. Without that, we would be well under 0.1%. And again, putting our situation in perspective, we're a broadly diversified midstream company, we've got a strong and diversified customer base, which includes integrated energy majors, utilities and end users. So the credit picture is stabilizing. 
Now for some of the segment highlights and trends. Overall, and I compare it to a year-over-year basis to segment earnings before DD&A and certain items is down $31 million or 2% from Q2 of 2015 to Q2 of '16. CO2 -- so $31 million down -- CO2 by itself is down $59 million due to lower prices primarily and lower production. Even though CO2 is making plan due to surprise improvements and good performance on the cost-savings front. 
Compared to last -- the same quarter last year, GAAP is down 1% while terminals and products are 4% and 8%, respectively. So broad themes on our year-to-year performance. We continue -- number one, we continue to see strong demand for natural gas across our network, transport volumes are up 5% year-over-year. We're getting good terms on storage, transportation and sales renewals in our business. 
Power burn on our pipe is up 8% year-over-year. And recall that power burn was up 16% from Q2 of '14 to '15. So there's strong compounding growth coming from the power sector. For the first time ever, gas is making up a larger share of the fuel for power generation and coal. That's been true year-to-date for 2016 and very close in 2015. In the last, most recent quarter, Q2 of '16, 35% of generation came from gas versus 27% from coal. Gas exports are up on our system, too. Exports to Mexico have grown to 3.3 Bcf a day and 3/4 of that volume moves on Kinder Morgan pipes. We continue to believe, and we're seeing the need for natural gas transportation storage services growing as the demand in the power sector, power generation sector, industrial sectors continues to grow, along with export demand from Mexico and LNG. 
The Products Pipelines we're getting the benefit year-over-year of higher volumes on KMCC and Cochin and the start-up on the second splitter unit in the Houston Ship Channel. 
In Terminals, we are seeing the benefit of new liquids capacity coming online. And remember, liquids makes up a little better than 3/4 of our segment earnings before DD&A in this business, and we're also seeing increased utilization of that expanded capacity. So more capacity online and higher overall utilization of that capacity. The second quarter was a record-setting quarter for throughput on our liquids terminals. 
On the bulk side, while coal volumes is down year-over-year, other bulk volumes are partially offsetting that declines, particularly in petcoke and metals. We also renewed our steel handling arrangement with Nucor for 10 years with some value enhancements in that new deal. Overall, in the bulk part of the business, the entire year-over-year change can be explained by the coal bankruptcy. 
The negatives affecting the business on a year-over-year basis are, of course, lower commodity prices, which affected directly in the enhanced oil recovery part of CO2 and indirectly in our gathered volumes of gas and crude and condensates. But even with oil prices and gas prices that are lower year-over-year by 18% and 26%, respectively, we're showing durable performance from our portfolio [indiscernible]. 
Lastly, an update on our Trans Mountain expansion. This continues to be a "2 steps forward, 1 step back" development. I'll start with the fundamentals. What we consistently hear from our producer customers in Canada is that they're counting on this project to get built. Putting the recent fires aside in Alberta, production continues to grow and take-away capacity projects continue to be behind the demand. Oil prices have hurt Alberta for sure. But from the perspective of our expansion, the supply and demand fundamentals for take-away capacity are good. We're in the midst of the federal review process, as Rich mentioned, we have our NEB recommendation, finding the project to be in the public interest and the federal government is undertaking its further consultation process with the objective of final decision in December this year. We've made great progress with communities along the route, have agreements to support for a majority of the most directly affected First Nations stand. We are actively engaged with the B.C. government on the satisfaction of their 5 conditions, and we are making very good progress there. We are going to be actively working with contractors over the summer on the always-challenging work on cost and final scope of the project. 
Finally, before turning over to Kim for the financials, I'm going to point out that you probably noticed the release is in a slightly different format than usual. What we're doing is showing GAAP measures with equal or greater prominence for the recent SEC guidance to public company. As always, we'll continue to show you all the numbers, including the non-GAAP measures that we use in our management of the business. The business of format we'll show going forward. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Kim.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Steve. Let me start by reiterating 3 overall financial points that Rich mentioned to you that we believe you should take away from this call. Number one, as Rich said, our full year guidance has not change from the updated guidance we gave y
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Steve. Let me start by reiterating 3 overall financial points that Rich mentioned to you that we believe you should take away from this call. Number one, as Rich said, our full year guidance has not change from the updated guidance we gave you last quarter. We continue to expect that EBITDA will be about 3% below budget and DCF will be approximately 4% below budget. 
To be consistent with the guidance we gave you last quarter, this guidance does not include the impact of the SNG JV which we anticipate will close in the late third or early fourth quarter. Secondly, we expect to end the year at 5.3x debt-to-EBITDA, which is down from our budget guidance and the guidance we gave you last quarter, largely as a result of our balance sheet improvement efforts. When you annualize the EBITDA impact from the SNG transaction, we expect that the full year impact would be slightly higher than the 5.3x. And third, our debt-to-EBITDA target is still around 5x. And once we've reach that level, we will decide how to return value to shareholders, and we're not committing to a specific method at this time. 
On our dividend. Today, we're declaring a dividend of $0.125 per share consistent with our budget and the guidance we gave you in December of last year. 
Looking at our GAAP income statement, you will see that revenues are down significantly. As I say in many quarters, we do not believe that revenue or the changes in revenues are necessarily good predictors of our performance. We have some businesses where revenues and expense fluctuate with commodity prices, but margin generally does not. Which is why you also see a large change in cost of sales during the quarter. In addition, our GAAP numbers can be impacted by noncash, nonrecurring accounting entries for what we call certain items.
So if you turn to the second page of numbers, which shows our DCF for this quarter and year-to-date, I believe you'll get a better picture of our performance. We generated total DCF for the quarter of $1.05 billion versus $1.095 billion for the comparable period in 2015. Therefore, total DCF was down about $45 million or 4%. The segments were down approximately $31 million or 2% with a $59 million decrease in CO2 offsetting increases in terminals and products. The $31 million decrease in the segment was partially offset by $23 million decrease in G&A and interest expense. If you net out the $39 million increase in our preferred stock dividend, you get a DCF variance of $47 million versus the $45 million that we show on the page. There are a bunch of other moving parts, but that gives you the main one. 
DCF per share was $0.47 in the quarter versus $0.50 for the second quarter of last year or down $0.03, with about $0.02 associated with the DCF variance that I just walked you through and about $0.01 due to the additional shares that we issued during 2015 to finance our growth projects and maintain our balance sheet. Therefore, despite approximately 20% decline in commodity prices versus the second quarter of last year, our performance was down approximately 4%. We believe these results demonstrate the resiliency of our cash flows generated by a large diversified platform, primarily fee-based assets. 
Certain items in the quarter were relatively small, income of approximately $8 million. But let me describe a couple of them that you wouldn't have seen before, so we'll make sure you know what they are. We had a contract early-termination revenue, which is $39 million of income, which was associated with a customer buying out of its source contract on one of our Texas Intrastate storage fields. We also had a $21 million in legal and environmental reserves, and that was primarily related to settlement of our over 10-year litigation matter with the city of San Diego. 
Now let me give you a little bit more granularity on our expected performance for the full year versus our budget. We expect natural gas pipeline to come in approximately 2% below its budget, primarily as a result of the lower volumes in our midstream group and a 4.5 months in-service delay on our EEC/SNG pipeline expansion as a result of a delay in receiving our FERC certificate. 
CO2 is expected to end the year on its budget. And essentially here, what's happening is we have some price help and cost savings that are offsetting a little bit lower oil in CO2 volumes than we budgeted. We currently expect terminals to end the year about 4% below its budget, primarily due to the impact of the Coal bankruptcy. We expect products to end the year approximately 5% below its budget due to lower crude and condensate volume on KMCC, Double H and Double Eagle, lower rates on our SSPP pipeline and the sale of our Parkway Pipeline. Right now, we're projecting KMC to be essentially on budget. 
On the expense side, interest, cash taxes, G&A and sustaining CapEx on a combined basis are expected to come in positive versus budget, or said another way, generate a favorable variance, primarily as a result of lower interest. 
And with that, I will move to the balance sheet. On the balance sheet, we ended the quarter with $41.3 billion in debt. That is an increase in debt of about $97 million since the end of last year and is a decrease in debt versus where we ended the first quarter of about $234 million. So let me reconcile that for you. 
DCF in the quarter, as I mentioned a moment ago, was $1.05 billion. We spent about 800 -- a little under $870 million on expansion CapEx and contributions to equity investments. We distributed or paid dividends of about $279 million. We have -- we received proceeds from asset divestitures and JVs of about $220 million, and then working capital and other items was a source of cash of about $110 million. 
Year-to-date, we generated $2.28 billion in distributable cash flow. We spent about $1.88 on expansion capital, on acquisitions and on contributions to equity investments with the only significant acquisition being the acquisition of the BP terminals in the first quarter. We paid dividends of $558 million and we have proceeds from asset divestitures and JVs of $220 million and then we had working capitals used of about $160 million to get you to the $97 million increase in debt year-to-date. 
We ended the quarter at about 5.6x debt-to-EBITDA, which is consistent where we ended last year and consistent where we ended the first quarter. And as we have mentioned a couple of times on the call, we expect to end the year at 5.3x debt-to-EBITDA. 
So with that, I'll turn it back to Rich.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and Laura, if you will open the lines, we'll take any questions that may arise.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Kristina Kazarian from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I know you guys, just last week, so sorry for doing it again, but I've been getting a lot of questions. Can you guys just help me recap the profile of assets you'd be up for JV-ing? So I know we've talked about Elba. Any thoughts on time frame to that?
componenttext: So I know you guys, just last week, so sorry for doing it again, but I've been getting a lot of questions. Can you guys just help me recap the profile of assets you'd be up for JV-ing? So I know we've talked about Elba. Any thoughts on time frame to that? And then TMX is the largest stand-alone project in the backlog. So would you be up for doing anything in any way on this one?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we have not been talking about specific JVs other than what we put kind of been as a placeholder, right, when we announced our plans for the year. And there are competitive reasons for doing that. We want to -- we don't want to be beholding to any
componenttext: Yes. So we have not been talking about specific JVs other than what we put kind of been as a placeholder, right, when we announced our plans for the year. And there are competitive reasons for doing that. We want to -- we don't want to be beholding to any 1 particular transaction. We've got some commercial considerations and competitive considerations around counterparties that we're working with there. So we're not identifying for you the whole list of things that we would be considering. But I think it's safe to say that we would look at and evaluate, if we could make it work, just about anything on our backlog that is separable, that we think we can extract good value for and that we can get promoted on and boost our return on. I mean, we'll have kind of the full list. Now a lot of the things that are in our backlog are things that are components of our existing network, our existing asset base. And so those are a lot harder. The other thing I would point out is, and this was part of our strategy in maintaining some flexibility on what we would work on and what we could have done, we've gotten so far already this year. We've gotten to a point where we brought our debt-to-EBITDA metric down to 5.3x, which is better than where we'd expected to end the year. So I know that's not definitive answer on here's the list of things that we look at doing. That's the kind of characteristics of things that we look at doing, and we made great progress on it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. On TMX, can you remind me what the next steps would be if we get the Order of Council (sic) [ Order In Council ] in December?
componenttext: That's helpful. On TMX, can you remind me what the next steps would be if we get the Order of Council (sic) [ Order In Council ] in December?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So there is another process going on which is the B.C. environmental assessment or the environmental certificate, I guess, you would call it, which we believe will be close in time to when the federal decision comes out. Maybe it lags by a month or so. That's another requirement. And again, we're working through the B.C. conditions 5 process which is the premier statement of conditions that you would like to see in that in order to sanction a project, right, and we are making good progress on those negotiations.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then last one for me, it's an asset-level one. Can you talk a little bit more about the gathered volume number? Was this kind of in line with what you guys are thinking post 1Q, especially in the Eagle Ford? And then the same thing on that incr
componenttext: Right. And then last one for me, it's an asset-level one. Can you talk a little bit more about the gathered volume number? Was this kind of in line with what you guys are thinking post 1Q, especially in the Eagle Ford? And then the same thing on that increase in power demand number being up so much?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on -- I would say, first on the gathered volumes. We made some good progress during this quarter, it may be a little bit at the end of last quarter in terms of signing, and we'd sign 6 or 7, I think 6, with existing shippers and 7 with the new shippe
componenttext: Yes, on -- I would say, first on the gathered volumes. We made some good progress during this quarter, it may be a little bit at the end of last quarter in terms of signing, and we'd sign 6 or 7, I think 6, with existing shippers and 7 with the new shipper of kind of incentive agreements, to try to bring volumes to our system above the contract minimum. So we lost some volumes on our Eagle Ford system that we are now getting back by entering into these arrangements. So it's probably a little bit worse than what we would have been shooting for, hoping for. But I think we've taken the right steps during the quarter to get some volumes and send it back on the system. And so I look for improvements here. Yes, and then on power, we were watching to kind of see how power generation would play out. I think I'll say, and Tom Martin is here, too, a little surprised to the upside on the year-over-year improvement when you think about how big of a leap we had last year. Now if you look at the year-to-date number, it's not quite as strong because we have that weak winter. And so Q1 was actually down a bit. But if you look on a Q2-to-Q2 basis, after having a very, very robust growth from '14 to '15, we saw growth on top of that -- of 8%. And here, I'm just talking about our system. So 8% on top of that 16% that we saw before which I think was -- is very strong, and I think bodes well. We had another data point there, as we had 5 of our 6 biggest days for power generation on the SNG system happened in the last 45 days. 5 of our biggest, 5 of the 6 biggest.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to clarify, I guess, your response to Kristina's question about you JV-ing of assets. So I'm to understand the backlog correctly, if there's a project that is basically a brownfield expansion to an existing asset, that makes it more difficult to pull off a JV, but not impossible, but more likely to happen on something that is more discreet. Is that a fair way to think about it?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good way to think about it.
componenttext: That's a good way to think about it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I remember your call from last week, you sort of indicated that the SNG asset sale, in fact, that you took in operating asset and then entered that into a JV. That seemed more of a one-off type of thing and not to really think about that
componenttext: Okay. And then if I remember your call from last week, you sort of indicated that the SNG asset sale, in fact, that you took in operating asset and then entered that into a JV. That seemed more of a one-off type of thing and not to really think about that on a go-forward basis. Does that apply to your CO2 business? Or is that one segment that you would actually consider JV-ing or outright selling?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we said last week, I mean, in general, it's not going to make a lot of sense for us, in general, to be selling interests in up and running assets. That tends to be an expensive way to raise capital. It was -- I would characterize it as a somewhat
componenttext: Yes. As we said last week, I mean, in general, it's not going to make a lot of sense for us, in general, to be selling interests in up and running assets. That tends to be an expensive way to raise capital. It was -- I would characterize it as a somewhat unique opportunity in the SNG case, because what we had there is our largest customer, a great power market in the Southeast U.S. and some specifically identified and agreed to opportunities that we can jointly pursue in this JV that, again, somewhat unusual for such a transaction would actually make the sale of interest in an existing asset accretive in the medium term. I think that's a fairly unique situation. We had, as Kim mentioned in some of her updates on the cash numbers, proceeds from other asset sales that we did. And again, they are, I think, we've had a few others. They're somewhat exceptional. And it's either a case where -- it's really a case where the customer on the asset or a third party has a much higher value or places a higher strategic value on the underlying asset. Parkway was an example. There were some others, smaller examples during the quarter. We sold a small -- a transmix facility, which we were essentially just doing spot business through and really not making much of anything on it. We had a third party who's interested in doing more with that asset. And so again, I think those are exceptional cases. But where we see them, we go get them.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. If I can follow up with some financial-related questions. I guess, first of all, the credit market has been a lot more generous on issuers lately versus a couple of months ago. Is it seasonal? Or is this part of your efforts to continue taking some costs out of this structure?

componenttext: Sure. On the debt side, you're right. I mean, we could issue 10-year bonds right now at sub 4%. So very attractive market. We do not have any need to access the capital market during 2016. We will continue to evaluate whether it might make economic sense to pre-fund 2017. Obviously, we're going to be -- what we expect later in the year, we'll be getting proceeds from the SNG transaction, and so you have to take that into account as well. On the CapEx -- the savings CapEx, we're going to come in, we think, probably about within 1% of our budget on sustaining CapEx. And so it is just, it's really -- we are running at a positive variance year-to-date versus our budget. But that's almost entirely timing.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it is timing of the work. We're still planning to do the work. We are getting some cost savings. But we also plan to get some cost savings. So it's relatively modest beyond what we budgeted for. And as always, the work that we've identified that w
componenttext: Yes, so it is timing of the work. We're still planning to do the work. We are getting some cost savings. But we also plan to get some cost savings. So it's relatively modest beyond what we budgeted for. And as always, the work that we've identified that we're doing for compliance and safety, we are focused on getting done and will get done in the year.

componenttext: That said, we're not sitting on our hands. We'll be looking at all opportunities. There is more to come, and we're working on it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, not necessarily expecting an ongoing decline rate. I mean, what we do in this business is we are looking at deploying capital that gets us an attractive return on the incremental barrels that we are producing that is associated with that capital spen
componenttext: Yes, not necessarily expecting an ongoing decline rate. I mean, what we do in this business is we are looking at deploying capital that gets us an attractive return on the incremental barrels that we are producing that is associated with that capital spend. And so that's kind of how we look at each of our investments here. We don't aim to necessarily -- with regard to returns, keep production flat or grow it slightly. We really make those decisions on each individual capital investment in the development programs that we spend money on at CO2.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, the -- I think in a broader brush, we've got deficiency, Steve, that are in play in many of these agreements, and we're not meeting the volumes associated with that, and so we anything that we can do to entice incremental volumes incrementally. headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean, I think -- generally, I think we believe that we're going to see really strong volumes, even as the burn gas prices through the third quarter. I think once we get latter part of September and we're still pushing $3 or upper $2, there may be som
componenttext: So I mean, I think -- generally, I think we believe that we're going to see really strong volumes, even as the burn gas prices through the third quarter. I think once we get latter part of September and we're still pushing $3 or upper $2, there may be some switching back. But certainly, not seeing any indication of that. It's the kind weather we're seeing right now and expect to see through August.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Darren Horowitz from Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Darren Horowitz from Raymond James.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones for me. The first, with regards to your comments around enhancing shareholder value. I'm just curious, and I recognize it's hypothetical. But I'm just curious how the impact of the conversion of the preferred to the common shares might i
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones for me. The first, with regards to your comments around enhancing shareholder value. I'm just curious, and I recognize it's hypothetical. But I'm just curious how the impact of the conversion of the preferred to the common shares might influence your preference on which measure of equity value enhancement that you choose first. Meaning, if it's a share repurchase to manage some of that incremental dilution or maybe it's a bit more of a balanced approach.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we've said, and Kim's been very clear on it, when we get the answer around 5, which is our target, then I think we'll look at what's the most opportune and expedient way of returning value to our shareholders. And we're not trying to judg
componenttext: Well, I think as we've said, and Kim's been very clear on it, when we get the answer around 5, which is our target, then I think we'll look at what's the most opportune and expedient way of returning value to our shareholders. And we're not trying to judge in advance. We won't do it just to avoid the potential dilution of the conversion of the fret. We'll look at as to whether it makes sense to buy back shares or increase the dividend. Again, we need to emphasize, we're running at a $2 DCF rate. And we're pleased that the stock has rallied here post the announcement on SNG, the $22 range, but that's still about a 9% yield on DCF. So we look at that and are still amazed that it's that high.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate the color. Steve, one quick one for you, just with regard to the northeast. The expectation there possibly regarding TGP working with customers possibly expanding that system beyond what's stated and scaling it up with the developments
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate the color. Steve, one quick one for you, just with regard to the northeast. The expectation there possibly regarding TGP working with customers possibly expanding that system beyond what's stated and scaling it up with the developments that have transpired since the close of Q1, has anything changed there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We continue to talk to customers, but there's nothing definitive there, Darren. I mean, we are -- the need for gas in the northeast is real, it's present, and we still think that there is -- there are capacity needs. We'll talk to our customers and co
componenttext: No. We continue to talk to customers, but there's nothing definitive there, Darren. I mean, we are -- the need for gas in the northeast is real, it's present, and we still think that there is -- there are capacity needs. We'll talk to our customers and continue to work with them on finding something that makes sense. Not at the same scale as NEB, but perhaps something else. In the meantime, we expanding TGP like mad. I mean, we are bringing gas down from the Marcellus and Utica down to the new market area, if you will, of the South, the Gulf Coast for LNG exports, ultimately going into Mexico as well and serving demand down here in Texas as well as power plant laterals, a couple of other projects. So we're actively investing in TGP, but no update, really, on northeast utility customer contracts.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeremy Tonet from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeremy Tonet from JPMorgan.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to look at -- talk about Canada first. And given that British Columbia isn't necessarily known to be the easiest place to do business, I'm just wondering if you had any reaction to -- a bit more thoughts on the reaction as far as what they've
componenttext: Just wanted to look at -- talk about Canada first. And given that British Columbia isn't necessarily known to be the easiest place to do business, I'm just wondering if you had any reaction to -- a bit more thoughts on the reaction as far as what they've said there recently with the TMX expansion. And does this enhance your ability to potentially kind of find JV partners here? Because it seems like this could be an ideal project to bring in a partner for.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so first, on B.C., as I said, I think, Ian and the team have been making very good progress there. And I assume you're referring to the energy business through Bennett's comments here recently reported in Bloomberg. We think that the environment over
componenttext: Yes, so first, on B.C., as I said, I think, Ian and the team have been making very good progress there. And I assume you're referring to the energy business through Bennett's comments here recently reported in Bloomberg. We think that the environment overall, I would say, is improving, and we are making progress in getting matters worked out with B.C. But we're not there yet. Still working on it. I think that, again, hypothetically, from a JV perspective, I mean, the more of these kinds of things that we are able to resolve and get behind us, the more value there is to a potential investor. But again, we're not -- we've got nothing active going on, on the project. It's 100% ours right now. But I think whether it's 100% ours, or ultimately, whether there is a partner, getting these things taken care of, from a regulatory and political standpoint, is very helpful.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks for that. And then just as far as the 5.3x leverage that you guys are targeting for year end right now, does that -- how much incremental asset sales or JVs does this bake in at this point?
componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks for that. And then just as far as the 5.3x leverage that you guys are targeting for year end right now, does that -- how much incremental asset sales or JVs does this bake in at this point?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing significant.
componenttext: Nothing significant.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ted Durbin from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ted Durbin from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going back to the 6.5x capital to EBITDA multiple that you put in the press release, which is now down from the 7.5x that you spoke about at the Analyst Day, can you just walk us through the details of how you got from 7.5 to 6.5? I'm assuming it's tak
componenttext: So going back to the 6.5x capital to EBITDA multiple that you put in the press release, which is now down from the 7.5x that you spoke about at the Analyst Day, can you just walk us through the details of how you got from 7.5 to 6.5? I'm assuming it's taking net out of backlog, but what are the other ways that you're bringing that multiple down on invested capital?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's really kind of all the items that I listed out there. We've had some contracts restructured. We've had some projects and that being the largest one -- largest single one that had below-average returns compared to the overall backlog that have co
componenttext: Yes, it's really kind of all the items that I listed out there. We've had some contracts restructured. We've had some projects and that being the largest one -- largest single one that had below-average returns compared to the overall backlog that have come out. We've also looked for ways to make on all of our projects if there is scope improvements that we can make, cost reductions that we can take on, and occasionally pushing capital out to closer in time when the project's coming in service. All of those things helped return the -- improve the returns in the multiple on the existing project base.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And now, with the new project base, can you just remind us how much of these projects actually have take-or-pay type of components or how much of them depend on volumes that maybe were outside of your control? I'm thinking in terminals or other plac
componenttext: Okay. And now, with the new project base, can you just remind us how much of these projects actually have take-or-pay type of components or how much of them depend on volumes that maybe were outside of your control? I'm thinking in terminals or other places.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the majority are going to be under contracts with customers. And let's see, on a -- I mean, on a percentage basis, I guess, essentially what you can do is exclude the CO2 portion of it. And generally, everything else is going to be under contract.
componenttext: Yes, the majority are going to be under contracts with customers. And let's see, on a -- I mean, on a percentage basis, I guess, essentially what you can do is exclude the CO2 portion of it. And generally, everything else is going to be under contract.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And so then, I guess, just stepping back here, you're earning 6.5x multiple returns, which is certainly very good returns. At what point do you say that's enough on asset sales, JVs, et cetera? This backlog is too good, we actually don't want
componenttext: Okay, great. And so then, I guess, just stepping back here, you're earning 6.5x multiple returns, which is certainly very good returns. At what point do you say that's enough on asset sales, JVs, et cetera? This backlog is too good, we actually don't want to, say, give this up.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, look, the backlog and the projects that we're going to be bringing on are part of our effort to improve our DCF per share, and so we're going to keep -- but that doesn't mean that we won't keep trying to find ways to optimize the scope and do o
componenttext: Yes, well, look, the backlog and the projects that we're going to be bringing on are part of our effort to improve our DCF per share, and so we're going to keep -- but that doesn't mean that we won't keep trying to find ways to optimize the scope and do other things that are going to boost returns. Going forward, we've said fairly high -- look, we're in a get self-funding world right now, and so we'll continue to look for incremental product opportunities. But we've raised our return criteria to something, again, that's all -- it always varies on any individual project depending on the risks and rewards. But we've kind of used it as a rule of thumb, 15% unlevered after tax return. So we continue to look for those projects and have authorized several along the way through the year, but we'll look to boost returns on what we have, but -- and we'll raise our return thresholds as we look at incremental capital investments.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could just sneak one more in on Trans Mountain, I guess any update on your views on the costs there to meet the 100 -- 57 conditions now that you've had some time to go through there. And just remind us if you'd have any ability to --
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just sneak one more in on Trans Mountain, I guess any update on your views on the costs there to meet the 100 -- 57 conditions now that you've had some time to go through there. And just remind us if you'd have any ability to -- if there was -- costs were higher, to pass those costs through to customers.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're working on the costs right now and working with our contractors right now and kind of will be over the -- really, over the course of the summer. And look, contractors always want more than what we want to pay them, and we're going to be pushing back
componenttext: We're working on the costs right now and working with our contractors right now and kind of will be over the -- really, over the course of the summer. And look, contractors always want more than what we want to pay them, and we're going to be pushing back hard on that process over the course of the summer to try to keep costs down and under control. Once we arrive at a cost that we turn over to our shippers and our final estimate, which will be sometime early next year or maybe later this -- it maybe late this year, Ian. Okay. Then, if we have flow-through protection on certain identified, uncontrollable costs, and that includes things that -- once we've set the price, right, once the cost has been set. And that includes things like the First Nations costs, steel costs, one of the more complex spreads through the mountain, and then the last 40 miles -- 40-kilometer -- 40 kilometers in the Lower Mainland.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Faisel Khan from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is from Faisel Khan from Citigroup.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions. First, I just want to go back to some of the answers around the gathered volumes. I was a little bit confused. So you've gone from roughly 3.5 DCF a day in gathered volumes, down to below 3 a day. And I think Steve, what you're saying is
componenttext: A few questions. First, I just want to go back to some of the answers around the gathered volumes. I was a little bit confused. So you've gone from roughly 3.5 DCF a day in gathered volumes, down to below 3 a day. And I think Steve, what you're saying is that, that's basically it. A lot of that was sort of volumes above and beyond MPC, and now you're saying that, that's going to stabilize going forward?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what happens in the basin will drive a lot of that, right? And I mean, we're starting to see some people come back to the Eagle Ford. But you not only had to come back, you had to bring a lot of rigs back in order to see that flatten back out and th
componenttext: Well, what happens in the basin will drive a lot of that, right? And I mean, we're starting to see some people come back to the Eagle Ford. But you not only had to come back, you had to bring a lot of rigs back in order to see that flatten back out and then start to increase. And frankly, I don't think the basin is at that point yet. And so most of what we have been focusing on is where we lost some volumes to third parties, we're trying to incent those to come back to the system rather than just collecting the deficiency charges from those customers. And as I said, I think we've made some good progress over the course of the quarter in doing that. But by the -- the over -- so long as the overall basin is declining, we're -- what we're doing is fighting off decline and trying to stay above that decline rate, if you will. But I don't know if -- it depends on whether the basin decline starts to slow and level out. Now I'll point out to -- because we haven't talked about Highland. We actually had year-over-year and over budget improvement on our Highland gathering assets in North Dakota. A lot of that was due to, also, restructuring of contracts and primarily migrating them from percent of proceeds to fee based, which gives us both greater stability, but also happened to have a beneficial impact on this year's earnings. So we've talked a lot about Eagle Ford. In the Haynesville, we've done an arrangement to try to incent a current customer to do some drilling. And there, what we've done is we've divided, if you will, the contract between what's already under contract to us and new or incremental wells and providing discounts there to try to incent some drilling. But again, the overall gathering picture is primarily driven by what the overall basin picture is.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But I mean, to go from 3.5 to under 3 in 2 quarters is pretty extreme. I mean, is that level of decline going to continue until the end of the year?
componenttext: Okay. But I mean, to go from 3.5 to under 3 in 2 quarters is pretty extreme. I mean, is that level of decline going to continue until the end of the year?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we may see some decline, but it won't be at that rate.
componenttext: I think we may see some decline, but it won't be at that rate.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And then the Eagle Ford volumes that you talk about, that's just on the liquids side, the 3 -- going from 3 44 down to 3 04, that's what you're talking about there. Or is there another mix of gas volumes you're talking about within the gath
componenttext: Okay, got you. And then the Eagle Ford volumes that you talk about, that's just on the liquids side, the 3 -- going from 3 44 down to 3 04, that's what you're talking about there. Or is there another mix of gas volumes you're talking about within the gathered volumes?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are significant gas gathered volumes in the Eagle Ford as well from our Eagle Ford gathering systems and the assets that we acquired from Copano. And those are factored into our overall gas gathering volumes that we've reported on the numbers page.
componenttext: There are significant gas gathered volumes in the Eagle Ford as well from our Eagle Ford gathering systems and the assets that we acquired from Copano. And those are factored into our overall gas gathering volumes that we've reported on the numbers page.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that makes sense on the G&P side. And then on the CO2 production volumes, I just want to go back to a question that was asked before. So the 15% decline in volumes year-over-year, that's not the natural decline rate in the field, if I remember c
componenttext: Okay. And that makes sense on the G&P side. And then on the CO2 production volumes, I just want to go back to a question that was asked before. So the 15% decline in volumes year-over-year, that's not the natural decline rate in the field, if I remember correctly. I mean, I thought that the CO2, if you're not spending a lot of capital in SACROC and Yates, that volumes might decline by about maybe mid-single digits based on how much CO2 you're injecting in the field, but 15% seems like a lot.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jesse. No, it's not a natural decline. As Steve said earlier, we were -- we had a record quarter and half year in '15 based on a very successful infill program. The candidates are not as prolific in the area at the moment, so that's really th
componenttext: Yes, this is Jesse. No, it's not a natural decline. As Steve said earlier, we were -- we had a record quarter and half year in '15 based on a very successful infill program. The candidates are not as prolific in the area at the moment, so that's really the driver period to period. It's the success of that particular infill project.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So what is the natural decline to feel from here on out, if you could give me a best guesstimate?
componenttext: Okay. So what is the natural decline to feel from here on out, if you could give me a best guesstimate?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's probably more along the 6% to 9%, depending on the area in the field.
componenttext: Yes, it's probably more along the 6% to 9%, depending on the area in the field.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. Last question for me, just on the asset sale program, are -- there was some trade publication used that you were in the market to sell the Jones Act tanker business. Is that still an asset that is on the market? Or have you pulled that a
componenttext: Okay, understood. Last question for me, just on the asset sale program, are -- there was some trade publication used that you were in the market to sell the Jones Act tanker business. Is that still an asset that is on the market? Or have you pulled that asset from the market?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, Faisel, we're not really talking about specific processes or assets for the reasons I've said earlier.
componenttext: And again, Faisel, we're not really talking about specific processes or assets for the reasons I've said earlier.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So one more, if I could. The drive to get big return of capital to shareholders as quickly as possible, I'm just wondering, is -- because have a lot of -- you've announced a lot of asset sales already, I'm just wondering, do you risk sort of going -
componenttext: Okay. So one more, if I could. The drive to get big return of capital to shareholders as quickly as possible, I'm just wondering, is -- because have a lot of -- you've announced a lot of asset sales already, I'm just wondering, do you risk sort of going -- racing too quickly to return capital back to shareholders and maybe not retaining assets that may have sort of better value over the longer term? So I'm just trying to understand, so that balance between asset sales and returning capital back to shareholders over a certain time period.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it is certainly a balancing process, and we're certainly not going to sell anything that doesn't make sense strategically for us. And that's why for the most part, and Steve has explained, I think, very clearly the thought behind the joint v
componenttext: Well, I think it is certainly a balancing process, and we're certainly not going to sell anything that doesn't make sense strategically for us. And that's why for the most part, and Steve has explained, I think, very clearly the thought behind the joint venture with Southern Company on SNG. But beyond that, our effort has been concentrated on new projects, where we could bring somebody in who would reward us for the efforts we've made on those projects thus far and participate, heads up with us, on a going-forward basis. So I think we're trying to balance this very carefully, and we're not going to rush into anything that doesn't make sense strategically. We're obviously in this for the very long term.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Craig Shere from Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: Our next question is from Craig Shere from Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got three questions here. The first, pretty quick, on the fall to 6.5x from what I think was guided 6.7x CapEx to EBITDA on the remaining non-CO2 growth CapEx, is that mostly on the efficiencies and that gas pipeline project restructuring? Or were monetiz
componenttext: Got three questions here. The first, pretty quick, on the fall to 6.5x from what I think was guided 6.7x CapEx to EBITDA on the remaining non-CO2 growth CapEx, is that mostly on the efficiencies and that gas pipeline project restructuring? Or were monetized projects and the completed Magnolia tanker at higher multiples?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think Magnolia would've been in there all along. So really, it's -- it is the contract restructuring. It's the UTOPIA JV. Those would probably be the 2 main contributors to it. But also, we have, as I said, we look for ways to cut spend or reduce sc
componenttext: No, I think Magnolia would've been in there all along. So really, it's -- it is the contract restructuring. It's the UTOPIA JV. Those would probably be the 2 main contributors to it. But also, we have, as I said, we look for ways to cut spend or reduce scope where we have the opportunity to do so without -- and enhance returns as a result. Those are probably 2 of the biggest single component.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And kind of a bigger picture here, I know the balance sheet repair and having the flexibility to return money to shareholders is foremost in your mind. But of course, if you had to make a choice and you had unlimited ability to reinvest at 6.
componenttext: Okay, great. And kind of a bigger picture here, I know the balance sheet repair and having the flexibility to return money to shareholders is foremost in your mind. But of course, if you had to make a choice and you had unlimited ability to reinvest at 6.5x EBITDA, certainly, that would be preferable to returning money to shareholders. Currently, excluding CO2 and CWIP, [ph] yes, I think you have about $10 billion of proportional spend now from '16 to 2020 and over half of that is Trans Mountain. How would you handicap the prospects for this fee-based outstanding growth CapEx inventory to materially fill in and expand over the next couple of years?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, as Rich said, were trying to balance things. The are 2 things we're trying to accomplish here. One is we want to get our debt-to-EBITDA down into the vicinity of 5x, okay? The other thing we want to do is grow the DCF per share. And that invo
componenttext: Well, again, as Rich said, were trying to balance things. The are 2 things we're trying to accomplish here. One is we want to get our debt-to-EBITDA down into the vicinity of 5x, okay? The other thing we want to do is grow the DCF per share. And that involves investing in projects, as we've described, and getting good returns for the capital that we do deploy. And we're doing this in a context of being self funding. So we are trying to make sure that we are dedicating our capital that we have to the best returns we can get and not be in a position where we have to access the capital market, where we have to access the capital market. And so those are really the things we are balancing. We remain focused on getting the balance sheet in order and then improving our DCF per share. And we believe, following that course will allow us to be in a position to return cash to shareholders. I think if you look at what our opportunities, and it remains to be seen what the total investment opportunity is going to be out there, but I think there's a very reasonable case, right, a reasonable scenario where we're in a situation where we're generating significantly more cash, particularly as these projects come online, more cash than we're investing. And when we're in that position, we're going to be also in a position to either -- as we've said multiple times, either further delever the balance sheet or return value to shareholders in the form of buybacks or increase the dividends. And as we get closer in time too, that we'll be evaluating which one of those approaches is the best way for maximizing -- to maximize shareholder value.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. I guess what I'm trying to get at is that there's a much higher value proposition potential. And that is if you get close to 5x net debt to EBITDA towards the end of next year and you have this flexibility and stability, can issue 10-year debt
componenttext: Understood. I guess what I'm trying to get at is that there's a much higher value proposition potential. And that is if you get close to 5x net debt to EBITDA towards the end of next year and you have this flexibility and stability, can issue 10-year debt at sub 4%. If you could fund the half the cost of all your growth CapEx at 6.5x with cheap debt, you would have enormous amounts of free cash flow to both fund growth CapEx and return to shareholders. And I guess I'm trying to get a sense if you think that having additional projects in line with the attractive inventory you currently have -- I mean, there was a point you had over $20 billion of inventory. Do you think that there's prospects over the next 2, 3 years to start to recharging that?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And look, that's a possibility, and that is absolutely something we would look at. But again, the place we're trying to maintain ourselves right now is not to have to access the capital market. So it doesn't mean that on the right terms and condition
componenttext: Yes. And look, that's a possibility, and that is absolutely something we would look at. But again, the place we're trying to maintain ourselves right now is not to have to access the capital market. So it doesn't mean that on the right terms and conditions, we wouldn't.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, last question. On CO2, I think for the entire segment, it was originally budgeted at $1.8 billion of growth CapEx over the 5-year plan. I think the forward strips in '16 and '17 are above your planned assumptions. The longer-term strips are still st
componenttext: Okay, last question. On CO2, I think for the entire segment, it was originally budgeted at $1.8 billion of growth CapEx over the 5-year plan. I think the forward strips in '16 and '17 are above your planned assumptions. The longer-term strips are still stubbornly low. Any reason to think about -- particularly with some of the volumes being less than originally anticipated, any reason to think about that spend over the 5 years coming in?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Five years coming in, meaning...
componenttext: Five years coming in, meaning...

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: They are falling, less than the 1.8.
componenttext: They are falling, less than the 1.8.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a matter of fact, we're up slightly from the 1.8 in the first Q. At the current strip, we have the 1.8 still fits. It works with the current strip.
componenttext: As a matter of fact, we're up slightly from the 1.8 in the first Q. At the current strip, we have the 1.8 still fits. It works with the current strip.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chris Sighinolfi from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chris Sighinolfi from Jefferies.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple quick follow-ups for me. I guess, Kim, starting with CO2 for a moment. You've been willing to give us some updates in prior calls on hedge book and activity. I'm just wondering if there's been any update on the hedge positions. If so, if you could just sort of update us as to where you stand.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, and then I think -- just final question from me. I don't mean to beat the dead horse, but I wanted to revisit sort of the balancing act that you spoke about with Faisel and then Craig's efforts -- or comments around sort of the deleveraging ef
componenttext: Okay. Okay, and then I think -- just final question from me. I don't mean to beat the dead horse, but I wanted to revisit sort of the balancing act that you spoke about with Faisel and then Craig's efforts -- or comments around sort of the deleveraging efforts versus capital deployment opportunities. Steve, recognizing that you don't need the access to capital markets, but I'm just wondering like at what point -- what are the conditions under which you would? But if the -- I get that the effort around JV-ing on in-flight projects is seemingly the most attractive thing, particularly if the party can bring something to that other than just capital. You've -- we've obviously seen the asset sales, but it's kind of tricky when you're selling underlying cash flow and utilizing some of the NOL balance. So I'm just curious, like the goal around deleveraging, where does -- where and when, and if equity issuance would play into that?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think at this price level, we don't want to issue equity. And so look, I think right now, we're going to live within our cash flow. And I think that as we look out in time, we want to do projects. So we want to do projects that have good returns o
componenttext: Well, I think at this price level, we don't want to issue equity. And so look, I think right now, we're going to live within our cash flow. And I think that as we look out in time, we want to do projects. So we want to do projects that have good returns on them. And so if they have good returns, we think that will be value creating to our investors. And so if we can do projects at 6.5x EBITDA, then that is going to be a priority. But as we look out in time and we look at the backlog that we have and we look at the potential opportunities that there may be, we see that there's probably going to be cash flow in excess of the capital projects once the balance sheet is repaired. And so that's why we're saying, once the balance sheet's repaired, then, at that point in time, we will be in the position to return value to shareholders through share repurchases or dividends because we think there will be some projects, don't get me wrong, but we just think that the cash flow that we will have will exceed that amount of project.
