componenttextpreview: Early July.
componenttext: Early July.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think split fairly evenly. I think it was certainly not a wholly June phenomenon.
componenttext: Yes. So I think split fairly evenly. I think it was certainly not a wholly June phenomenon.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean, I think -- generally, I think we believe that we're going to see really strong volumes, even at the current gas prices through the third quarter. I think once we get latter part of September and we're still pushing $3 or upper $2, there may be
componenttext: So I mean, I think -- generally, I think we believe that we're going to see really strong volumes, even at the current gas prices through the third quarter. I think once we get latter part of September and we're still pushing $3 or upper $2, there may be some switching back. But certainly, not seeing any indication of that at -- this kind of weather we're seeing right now and expect to see through August.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Darren Horowitz from Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Darren Horowitz from Raymond James.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones for me. The first, with regards to your comments around enhancing shareholder value. I'm just curious, and I recognize it's hypothetical, but I'm just curious how the impact of the conversion of the preferred to the common shares might i
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones for me. The first, with regards to your comments around enhancing shareholder value. I'm just curious, and I recognize it's hypothetical, but I'm just curious how the impact of the conversion of the preferred to the common shares might influence your preference on which measure of equity value enhancement you choose first. Meaning, if it's a share repurchase to manage some of that incremental dilution or maybe it's a bit more of a balanced approach.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we've said, and Kim's been very clear on it, when we get the answer around 5, which is our target, then I think we'll look at what's the most opportune and expedient way of returning value to our shareholders. And we're not trying to judg
componenttext: Well, I think as we've said, and Kim's been very clear on it, when we get the answer around 5, which is our target, then I think we'll look at what's the most opportune and expedient way of returning value to our shareholders. And we're not trying to judge in advance. We won't do it just to avoid the potential dilution of the conversion of the fret. [ph] We'll look at as to whether it makes sense to buy back shares or increase the dividend. Again, we need to emphasize, we're running at a $2 DCF rate. And we're pleased that the stock has rallied here post the announcement on SNG, to the $22 range, but that's still about a 9% yield on DCF. So we look at that and are still amazed that it's that high.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate the color. Steve, one quick one for you, just with regard to the northeast. The expectation there possibly regarding TGP working with customers, possibly expanding that system beyond what's stated and scaling it up. With the development
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate the color. Steve, one quick one for you, just with regard to the northeast. The expectation there possibly regarding TGP working with customers, possibly expanding that system beyond what's stated and scaling it up. With the developments that have transpired since the close of Q1, has anything changed there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We continue to talk to customers, but there's nothing definitive there, Darren. I mean, we are -- the need for gas in the northeast is real, it's present, and we still think that there is -- there are capacity needs [indiscernible] . We'll talk to our
componenttext: No. We continue to talk to customers, but there's nothing definitive there, Darren. I mean, we are -- the need for gas in the northeast is real, it's present, and we still think that there is -- there are capacity needs [indiscernible] . We'll talk to our customers and continue to work with them on finding something that makes sense. Not at the same scale as NEB, but perhaps something else. In the meantime, we expanding TGP like mad. I mean, we are bringing gas down from the Marcellus and Utica down to the new market area, if you will, of the South, the Gulf Coast for LNG exports, ultimately going into Mexico as well and serving demand down here in Texas as well as power plant laterals, a couple of other projects. So we're actively investing in TGP, but no update, really, on northeast utility customer contracts.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeremy Tonet from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeremy Tonet from JPMorgan.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to look at -- talk about Canada first. And given that British Columbia isn't necessarily known to be the easiest place to do business, I'm just wondering if you had any reaction to -- a bit more thoughts on the reaction as far as what they've
componenttext: Just wanted to look at -- talk about Canada first. And given that British Columbia isn't necessarily known to be the easiest place to do business, I'm just wondering if you had any reaction to -- a bit more thoughts on the reaction as far as what they've said there recently with the TMX expansion. And does this enhance your ability to potentially kind of find JV partners here? Because it seems like this could be an ideal project to bring in a partner for.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so first, on B.C., as I said, I think, Ian and the team have been making very good progress there. And I assume you're referring to the energy minister Bennett's comments here recently reported in Bloomberg. We think that the environment overall, I w
componenttext: Yes, so first, on B.C., as I said, I think, Ian and the team have been making very good progress there. And I assume you're referring to the energy minister Bennett's comments here recently reported in Bloomberg. We think that the environment overall, I would say, is improving, and we are making progress in getting matters worked out with B.C. But we're not there yet. Still working on it. I think that, again, hypothetically, from a JV perspective, I mean, the more of these kinds of things that we are able to resolve and get behind us, the more value there is to a potential investor. But again, we're not -- we've got nothing active going on, on the project. It's 100% ours right now. But I think whether it's 100% ours, or ultimately, whether there is a partner, getting these things taken care of, from a regulatory and political standpoint, is very helpful.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks for that. And then just as far as the 5.3x leverage that you guys are targeting for yearend right now, does that -- how much incremental asset sales or JVs does this bake in at this point?
componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks for that. And then just as far as the 5.3x leverage that you guys are targeting for yearend right now, does that -- how much incremental asset sales or JVs does this bake in at this point?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing significant.
componenttext: Nothing significant.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ted Durbin from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ted Durbin from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going back to the 6.5x capital to EBITDA multiple that you put in the press release, which is now down from the 7.5x that you spoke about at the Analyst Day, can you just walk us through the details of how you got from 7.5 to 6.5? I'm assuming it's tak
componenttext: So going back to the 6.5x capital to EBITDA multiple that you put in the press release, which is now down from the 7.5x that you spoke about at the Analyst Day, can you just walk us through the details of how you got from 7.5 to 6.5? I'm assuming it's taking net out of backlog, but what are the other ways that you're bringing that multiple down on invested capital?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's really kind of all the items that I listed out there. We've had some contracts restructured. We've had some projects, NEB being the largest one -- largest single one that had below-average returns compared to the overall backlog that have come o
componenttext: Yes, it's really kind of all the items that I listed out there. We've had some contracts restructured. We've had some projects, NEB being the largest one -- largest single one that had below-average returns compared to the overall backlog that have come out. We've also looked for ways to make on all of our projects if there is scope improvements that we can make, cost reductions that we can take on, occasionally pushing capital out to closer in time when the project's coming in service. All of those things helped return the -- improve the returns in the multiple on the existing project base.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And now, with the new project base, can you just remind us how much of these projects actually have take-or-pay type of components or how much of them depend on volumes that maybe were outside of your control? I'm thinking in terminals or other plac
componenttext: Okay. And now, with the new project base, can you just remind us how much of these projects actually have take-or-pay type of components or how much of them depend on volumes that maybe were outside of your control? I'm thinking in terminals or other places.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the majority are going to be under contracts with customers. And let's see, on a -- I mean, on a percentage basis, I guess, essentially what you can do is exclude the CO2 portion of it. And generally, everything else is going to be under contract.
componenttext: Yes, the majority are going to be under contracts with customers. And let's see, on a -- I mean, on a percentage basis, I guess, essentially what you can do is exclude the CO2 portion of it. And generally, everything else is going to be under contract.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And so then, I guess, just stepping back here, you're earning 6.5x multiple returns, which is certainly very good returns. At what point do you say that's enough on asset sales, JVs, et cetera? This backlog is too good, we actually don't want
componenttext: Okay, great. And so then, I guess, just stepping back here, you're earning 6.5x multiple returns, which is certainly very good returns. At what point do you say that's enough on asset sales, JVs, et cetera? This backlog is too good, we actually don't want to, say, give this up.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, look, the backlog and the projects that we're going to be bringing on are part of our effort to improve our DCF per share, and so we're going to keep -- but that doesn't mean that we won't keep trying to find ways to optimize the scope and do o
componenttext: Yes, well, look, the backlog and the projects that we're going to be bringing on are part of our effort to improve our DCF per share, and so we're going to keep -- but that doesn't mean that we won't keep trying to find ways to optimize the scope and do other things that are going to boost returns. Going forward, we've said fairly high -- look, we're in a self-funding world right now, and so we'll continue to look for incremental product opportunities. But we've raised our return criteria to something, again, that's all -- it always varies on any individual project depending on the risks and rewards. But we've kind of used as a rule of thumb, 15% unlevered after tax return. So we continue to look for those projects and have authorized several along the way through the year, but we'll look to boost returns on what we have, but -- and we'll raise our return thresholds as we look at incremental capital investments.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could just sneak one more in on Trans Mountain, I guess any update on your views on the costs there to meet the 100 -- 57 conditions now that you've had some time to go through there. And just remind us if you'd have any ability to --
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just sneak one more in on Trans Mountain, I guess any update on your views on the costs there to meet the 100 -- 57 conditions now that you've had some time to go through there. And just remind us if you'd have any ability to -- if there -- costs were higher, to pass those costs through to customers.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're working on the costs right now and working with our contractors right now and kind of will be over the -- really, over the course of the summer. And look, contractors always want more than what we want to pay them, and we're going to be pushing back
componenttext: We're working on the costs right now and working with our contractors right now and kind of will be over the -- really, over the course of the summer. And look, contractors always want more than what we want to pay them, and we're going to be pushing back hard on that process over the course of the summer to try to keep costs down and under control. Once we arrive at a cost that we turn over to our shippers in our final estimate, which will be sometime early next year or maybe later this -- or it may be late this year -- Ian? [indiscernible] Okay. Then, if we have flow-through protection on certain identified, uncontrollable costs, and that includes things that -- once we've set the price, right, once the cost has been set. And that includes things like the First Nations costs, steel costs, one of the more complex spreads through the mountain, and then the last 40 miles -- 40-kilometer -- 40 kilometers into Lower Mainland.[ph]

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Faisel Khan from Citigroup.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions. First, I just want to go back to some of the answers around the gathered volumes. I was a little bit confused. So you've gone from roughly 3.5 DCF a day in gathered volumes, down to below 3 a day. And I think Steve, what you're saying is
componenttext: A few questions. First, I just want to go back to some of the answers around the gathered volumes. I was a little bit confused. So you've gone from roughly 3.5 DCF a day in gathered volumes, down to below 3 a day. And I think Steve, what you're saying is that, that's basically it. A lot of that was sort of volumes above and beyond MPC, and now you're saying that, that's going to stabilize going forward?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what happens in the basin will drive a lot of that, right? And I mean, we're starting to see some people come back to the Eagle Ford. But you not only have to come back, you have to bring a lot of rigs back in order to see that flatten back out and
componenttext: Well, what happens in the basin will drive a lot of that, right? And I mean, we're starting to see some people come back to the Eagle Ford. But you not only have to come back, you have to bring a lot of rigs back in order to see that flatten back out and then start to increase. And frankly, I don't think the basin is at that point yet. And so most of what we have been focusing on is where we lost some volumes to third parties, we're trying to incent those to come back to the system rather than just collecting the deficiency charges from those customers. And as I said, I think we've made some good progress over the course of the quarter in doing that. But by the -- the over -- so long as the overall basin is declining, we're -- what we're doing is fighting off decline and trying to stay above that decline rate, if you will. But I don't know if -- it depends on whether the basin decline starts to slow and level out. Now I'll point out to -- because we haven't talked about Highland. We actually had year-over-year and over budget improvement on our Highland gathering assets in North Dakota. A lot of that was due to, also, restructuring of contracts and primarily migrating them from percent of proceeds to fee based, which gives us both greater stability, but also happened to have a beneficial impact on this year's earnings. So we've talked a lot about Eagle Ford. In the Haynesville, we've done an arrangement to try to incent a current customer to do some drilling. And there, what we've done is we've divided, if you will, the contract between what's already under contract to us and new or incremental wells and providing discounts there to try to incent some drilling. But again, the overall gathering picture is primarily driven by what the overall basin picture is.

componenttext: Okay. And that makes sense on the G&P side. And then on the CO2 production volumes, I just want to go back to a question that was asked before. So the 15% decline in volumes year-over-year, that's not the natural decline rate of the field, if I remember correctly. I mean, I thought that the CO2, if you're not spending a lot of capital in SACROC and Yates, that volumes might decline by about maybe mid-single digits based on how much CO2 you're injecting in the field, but 15% seems like a lot.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jesse. No, it's not a natural decline. As Steve said earlier, we were -- we had a record quarter and half year in '15 based on a very successful infill program. The candidates are not as prolific in the area at the moment, so that's really th
componenttext: Yes, this is Jesse. No, it's not a natural decline. As Steve said earlier, we were -- we had a record quarter and half year in '15 based on a very successful infill program. The candidates are not as prolific in the area at the moment, so that's really the driver period to period. It's the success of that particular infill project.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So what is the natural decline of the field from here on out, if you could give me a best guesstimate?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's probably more along the 6% to 9%, depending on the area in the field.
componenttext: Yes, it's probably more along the 6% to 9%, depending on the area in the field.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So one more, if I could. The drive to get the return of capital to shareholders as quickly as possible, I'm just wondering, is -- because have a lot of -- you've announced a lot of asset sales already, I'm just wondering, do you risk sort of going -
componenttext: Okay. So one more, if I could. The drive to get the return of capital to shareholders as quickly as possible, I'm just wondering, is -- because have a lot of -- you've announced a lot of asset sales already, I'm just wondering, do you risk sort of going -- racing too quickly to return capital back to shareholders and maybe not retaining assets that may have sort of better value over the longer term? So I'm just trying to understand, so that balance between asset sales and returning capital back to shareholders over a certain time period.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it is certainly a balancing process, and we're certainly not going to sell anything that doesn't make sense strategically for us. And that's why for the most part, and Steve has explained, I think, very clearly the thought behind the joint v
componenttext: Well, I think it is certainly a balancing process, and we're certainly not going to sell anything that doesn't make sense strategically for us. And that's why for the most part, and Steve has explained, I think, very clearly the thought behind the joint venture with Southern Company on SNG. But beyond that, our effort has been concentrated on new projects, where we could bring somebody in who would reward us for the efforts we've made on those projects thus far and participate, heads up with us, on a going-forward basis. So I think we're trying to balance this very carefully, and we're not going to rush into anything that doesn't make sense strategically. We're obviously in this for the very long term.

componenttext: Got three questions here. The first, pretty quick, on the fall to 6.5x from what I think was guided 6.7x CapEx to EBITDA on the remaining non-CO2 growth CapEx, is that mostly on efficiencies and that gas pipeline project restructuring? Or were monetized projects and the completed Magnolia tanker at higher multiples?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think Magnolia would've been in there all along. So really, it's -- it is the contract restructuring. It's the UTOPIA JV. Those would probably be the 2 main contributors to it. But also, we have, as I've said, we look for ways to cut spend or reduce
componenttext: No, I think Magnolia would've been in there all along. So really, it's -- it is the contract restructuring. It's the UTOPIA JV. Those would probably be the 2 main contributors to it. But also, we have, as I've said, we look for ways to cut spend or reduce scope where we have the opportunity to do so without -- and enhance returns as a result. Those are probably 2 of the biggest single components.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And kind of a bigger picture here, I know the balance sheet repair and having the flexibility to return money to shareholders is foremost in your mind. But of course, if you had to make a choice and you had unlimited ability to reinvest at 6.
componenttext: Okay, great. And kind of a bigger picture here, I know the balance sheet repair and having the flexibility to return money to shareholders is foremost in your mind. But of course, if you had to make a choice and you had unlimited ability to reinvest at 6.5x EBITDA, certainly, that would be preferable to returning money to shareholders. Currently, excluding CO2 and CWIP, [ph] yes, I think you have about $10 billion of proportional spend now from '16 to 2020 and over half of that is Trans Mountain. How would you handicap the prospects for this fee-based outstanding growth CapEx inventory to materially fill in and expand over the next couple of years?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, as Rich said, were trying to balance things. There are 2 things we're trying to accomplish here. One is we want to get our debt-to-EBITDA down into the vicinity of 5x, okay? The other thing we want to do is grow the DCF per share. And that in
componenttext: Well, again, as Rich said, were trying to balance things. There are 2 things we're trying to accomplish here. One is we want to get our debt-to-EBITDA down into the vicinity of 5x, okay? The other thing we want to do is grow the DCF per share. And that involves investing in projects, as we've described, and getting good returns for the capital that we do deploy. And we're doing this in a context of being self-funding. So we are trying to make sure that we are dedicating our capital that we have to the best returns we can get and not be in a position where we have to access the capital market; where we have to access the capital market. And so those are really the things we are balancing. We remain focused on getting the balance sheet in order and then improving our DCF per share. And we believe, following that course will allow us to be in a position to return cash to shareholders. I think if you look at what our opportunities, and it remains to be seen what the total investment opportunity is going to be out there, but I think there's a very reasonable case, right, a reasonable scenario where we're in a situation where we're generating significantly more cash, particularly as these projects come online, more cash than we're investing. And when we're in that position, we're going to be also in a position to either -- as we've said multiple times, either further delever the balance sheet or return value to shareholders in the form of buybacks or increase the dividend. And as we get closer in time too, that we'll be evaluating which one of those approaches is the best way for maximizing -- to maximize shareholder value.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. I guess what I'm trying to get at is that there's a much higher value proposition potential. And that is if you get close to 5x net debt to EBITDA towards the end of next year and you have this flexibility and still can issue 10-year debt at s
componenttext: Understood. I guess what I'm trying to get at is that there's a much higher value proposition potential. And that is if you get close to 5x net debt to EBITDA towards the end of next year and you have this flexibility and still can issue 10-year debt at sub 4%. If you could fund half the cost of all your growth CapEx at 6.5x with cheap debt, you would have enormous amounts of free cash flow to both fund growth CapEx and return to shareholders. And I guess I'm trying to get a sense if you think that having additional projects in line with the attractive inventory you currently have -- I mean, there was a point you had over $20 billion of inventory. Do you think that there's prospects over the next 2, 3 years to start to recharging that?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And look, that's a possibility, and that is absolutely something we would look at. But again, the place we're trying to maintain ourselves right now is not to have to access the capital market. So it doesn't mean that under the right terms and condit
componenttext: Yes. And look, that's a possibility, and that is absolutely something we would look at. But again, the place we're trying to maintain ourselves right now is not to have to access the capital market. So it doesn't mean that under the right terms and conditions, we wouldn't.

componenttext: Okay, thanks, Steve. componenttext: In '19, we won't start actual pipe construction until late summer of '17. So I would say that if you think about '18 and '19 as being the peaks, when logic would complete with a half year in '17, is the way to think about it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, and then I think -- just final question from me. I don't mean to beat a dead horse, but I wanted to revisit sort of the balancing act that you spoke about with Faisel and then Craig's efforts -- or comments around sort of the deleveraging effo
componenttext: Okay. Okay, and then I think -- just final question from me. I don't mean to beat a dead horse, but I wanted to revisit sort of the balancing act that you spoke about with Faisel and then Craig's efforts -- or comments around sort of the deleveraging efforts versus capital deployment opportunities. Steve, recognizing that you don't need the access to capital markets, but I'm just wondering like at what point -- what are the conditions under which you would? But if the -- I get that the effort around JV-ing on in-flight projects is seemingly the most attractive thing, particularly if the party can bring something to that other than just capital. You've -- we've obviously seen the asset sales, but it's kind of tricky when you're selling underlying cash flow and utilizing some of the NOL balance. So I'm just curious, like the goal around deleveraging, where does -- where and when, and if equity issuance would play into that?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think at this price level, we don't want to issue equity. And so look, I think right now, we're going to live within our cash flow. And I think that as we look out in time, we want to do projects. So we want to do projects that have good returns o
componenttext: Well, I think at this price level, we don't want to issue equity. And so look, I think right now, we're going to live within our cash flow. And I think that as we look out in time, we want to do projects. So we want to do projects that have good returns on them. And so if they have good returns, we think that will be value creating to our investors. And so if we can do projects at 6.5x EBITDA, then that is going to be a priority. But as we look out in time and we look at the backlog that we have and we look at the potential opportunities that there may be, we see that there's probably going to be cash flow in excess of the capital projects once the balance sheet is repaired. And so that's why we're saying, once the balance sheet's repaired, then, at that point in time, we will be in the position to return value to shareholders through share repurchases or dividends because we think there will be some projects, don't get me wrong, but we just think that the cash flow that we will have will exceed that amount of project.

componenttext: Thank you for standing by, and welcome to the quarterly earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Rich Kinder, the Executive Chairman of Kinder Morgan. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, May, and welcome to the Kinder Morgan Third Quarter Investor Call. As usual, before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's earnings release and this call includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Li
componenttext:
Thank you, May, and welcome to the Kinder Morgan Third Quarter Investor Call. As usual, before we begin, I'd like to remind you that today's earnings release and this call includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. We encourage you to read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements and use of non-GAAP financial measures set forth at the end of our earnings release as well as review our latest filings with the SEC for a list of risk factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those in such forward-looking statements. 
Before I turn it over to our CEO, Steve Kean; and our CFO, Kim Dang, let me make a couple of brief comments, one more industry-wide in nature and the other specific to KMI. 
Let's start with the industry-wide thought. We continue to be bullish on the prospects for North American energy, especially natural gas. And as the largest midstream energy company in North America, we believe we're well positioned in our existing businesses and with our backlog of growth projects. 
Fossil fuels and especially natural gas, which has now surpassed coal as the primary fuel source for power generation in the U.S., are going to be needed for a long, long time. I would add that natural gas is a key in reducing CO2 emissions in America. For example, despite a substantial increase in electric generation over the levels of 1993, the CO2 emissions from electric generation in 2015 were flat to those in 1993, largely as a result of the increased use of natural gas to generate that electricity. So natural gas is playing a major role in reducing emissions. But there have been recent controversies, as you all know, surrounding new pipeline projects and I'd like to offer my perspective. 
First, to the extent it becomes difficult to build new infrastructure that tends to make existing pipeline networks more valuable, and we obviously have a tremendous existing network. 
Second, while the protesters tend to get the headlines, it is still possible to build out new infrastructure. This quarter, for example, we completed an expansion on our Texas gas pipeline network. 
Third and maybe most importantly, I think, is to distinguish the permitting environment both geographically and jurisdictionally. There is a big difference, for example, between state-permitted projects where eminent domain is a function of state law and a federally certificated natural gas project. Ultimately, we realize that the environment is changing and we are adapting by building those changing circumstances into how we budget and plan our projects. 
Now to the comments specific to Kinder Morgan. During the third quarter, we substantially reduced our debt, and this positions us for long-term value creation. We are now ahead of our plan for 2016 year-end leverage. And as the Chairman and largest shareholder of the company, I'm very pleased with the progress we're making toward achieving our target leverage level of around 5x net debt-to-adjusted EBITDA. This will put us in a position to deliver substantial value to our shareholders through dividend increases, share repurchases, attractive growth projects or further debt reduction. 
Now because we get so many questions regarding these alternatives, let me expand a bit on this subject. Our current view leans towered increasing the dividend substantially while maintaining both greater coverage than in the past and a stronger balance sheet. That said, we'll obviously make the best economic decision at the time we reach that point, and we can't give you exact timing on when we will reach our target because there are numerous factors involved. But as I said, the message today is we're pleased with the progress to date. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Steve.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Rich. So I'll update on capital projects and counter-party credit and then hit on some segment highlights and trends. On the capital update, 2 of our larger projects, first on Trans Mountain. On that expansion, I'll start with the fundamen
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Rich. So I'll update on capital projects and counter-party credit and then hit on some segment highlights and trends. 
On the capital update, 2 of our larger projects, first on Trans Mountain. On that expansion, I'll start with the fundamentals. We consistently hear from producers in Canada and some refiners in the Northwest U.S. that they're counting on this project to get built. Production is expected to continue growing even though it's at a slower rate out of the oil sands, and takeaway capacity projects continue to lag the demand. Oil prices have hurt the oil sands, no question. But from the perspective of our expansion, the supply-and-demand fundamentals for new takeaway capacity are good. We're nearing the end of the federal review process right now. We have already the recommendation finding the project to be in a public interest, and the federal government has undertaken its further consultation process with the objective of a final decision in December of this year. We've made great progress with communities along the route and have agreements with the majority of the most directly affected First Nations bands. We're actively engaged with the BC government on the satisfaction of their 5 conditions. 
Finally, I'll note that we do believe that this project would make a very good candidate for bringing in other investors through a joint venture or other structure. It is an attractive project economically, and there is substantial interest in it. We believe that the project needs to write [ph] them through the review processes that are nearing a conclusion now. But following those reviews, assuming the outcomes of favorable or if the outcomes are favorable, we would look to syndicate this investment. We've got a lot of options here, including self-funding. So we're not committing to any one approach, but we do think it's worth exploring the options at the right time. 
On Elba, we have our 7(c) certificate from FERC. We got that in June. But the news is that we have received now our first significant notices to proceed from FERC just this week, and that's the authorization and follows the 7(c) that takes our implementation plan and gives us permission to go forward with construction. So we and Shell, our customer, are prepared for us to begin construction starting the 1st of November. 
With respect to the rest of our projects. We've been talking for several quarters now about high-grading the backlog. That's making sure that we're attending to our balance sheet and also ensuring that we grow value through investments at attractive returns that we can fund out of the cash flow that we generate. That is without needing to access the capital markets. This quarter, our backlog stands at $13 billion. That's down from $13.5 billion last quarter. We believe it's an attractive slate of projects projected 6.5x CapEx-to-EBITDA multiple. 87% of the backlog is for fee-based projects in our Pipelines and Terminals businesses. The changes from that $13.5 billion to the $13 billion, we put $600 million worth of projects into service during the quarter, including bringing on intrastate Texas gas crossover project that's in support of LNG in Mexico markets, taking delivery of 2 Jones Act vessels which are under charter, completing 2 smaller liquids terminal expansions, and we completed Phase I of our Tall Cotton enhanced oil recovery project. So $600 million went into service. We added a little over $200 million of projects in the quarter, $130 million of that in gas and $75 million in CO2 where we continue to see good returns even at current prices. If you look at the year-to-date numbers, we've added a little under $600 million, about $575 million, in new projects. Now that's been -- the backlog has been coming down. So that's been more than -- those additions have been more than offset by projects going into service and in project cancellations earlier in the year. But overall, I think what this shows you is we've been successful in doing what we set out to do. We have high-graded the backlog to strengthen our balance sheet and enabled the funding of our growth projects without needing to access capital markets while continuing to add projects where we find them at attractive returns. 
Turning to customer credit. We have a broad, diverse customer base with overall very good credit quality. We continue our extreme focus throughout our commercial and corporate organizations, active monitoring, calling for collateral, et cetera. And we've seen some stabilization in counter-party credit as our producer customers have been actively addressing their issues over the last few quarters. So in the past quarter, we were not impacted by any customer defaults. We had one customer file for bankruptcy, and the reorganized entity continued the contract with us. So no impact from customer defaults in the third quarter. 
So now turning to the segment for some highlights and trends there, starting with the GAAP measures. GAAP segment earnings were down $211 million for the quarter compared to the third quarter of 2015 primarily due to higher impairments in this quarter compared to the same quarter last year. Those were primarily comprised of a $350 million noncash impairment on our MEP investments, driven by the expectation of future lower contract rates and an approximately $84 million loss associated with the partial sale of SNG. 
If you look at segment earnings before DD&A and certain items, which is how we measure our performance, we're down $33 million or 2% quarter-to-quarter. CO2 is down $53 million year-over-year due to lower prices, $72 a barrel realized versus $74 in the third quarter of last year, and lower production. Nevertheless, we expect CO2 to make plan due to some price improvement versus our planned price and good performance on cost savings by that segment. 
Compared to the same quarter last year, gas is down 2% while Terminals and Products are up 22% and 7%, respectively. Overall, we think again that the quarter's performance demonstrates the resiliency of our cash flows even in difficult commodity price environments. 
Focusing on some of the broad trends affecting our business. First, in Natural Gas. We're seeing the demand-side developments that we anticipated. On our systems specifically, we're benefiting from increased demand for gas in the power sector, increased exports to Mexico and now, for the first time, increases due to LNG exports. 
On Kinder Morgan pipelines, power-driven gas demand was up 9% 3Q to 3Q from 6.5 Bcf last year to 7 Bcf this quarter. On a macro basis, gas is now overtaking coal, as Rich mentioned, as the fuel source for power generation. 
Mexico export demand on our pipelines grew by 6% year-over-year for the quarter and is up 15% on a comparable year-to-date number. We reached an average volume of 2.8 Bcf a day for the quarter, about 75% of total exports to Mexico.
We're in the early days of LNG export-driven demand. But even with the Sabine Pass outage in the last 2 weeks of the quarter, we experienced about 350 a day of LNG demand on our systems and much more to come there, we believe. 
Most of our $4 billion of backlog projects in the gas sector are directed at those 3 market trends plus one more, and that is the reversal projects on our TGP system to move more Marcellus and Utica gas to the South. 
Natural Gas, which is by far our largest segment, is kind of an 80-20 story, with approximately 80% of the budget segment earnings before DD&A attributable to transportation and storage, which benefits from the trends I just discussed; and the other 20% in gathering and processing. Our gathered volumes are down 17% to 18% year-over-year as a result of declines in the Eagle Ford, Oklahoma and the Bakken. 
Our Bakken midstream financial performance is up year-over-year and up versus planned, primarily due to contract restructuring earlier in the year. But overall, this business, outside of the take-or-pay commitments that we have, is dependent upon the recovery in those basins as gas demand grows and oil prices and, therefore, drilling recovers. 
We continue to believe that the need for natural gas transportation and storage capacity will grow as the demand trends that I talked about continue. And in the longer term, the gathering volumes flatten and turn up when we ultimately see recovery in the gas supply basins that we serve. 
In Products Pipelines, we're getting the benefit year-over-year of higher volumes. Refined products volumes are up 3% quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year and well above the growth in the EIA national numbers. Our crude and condensate volumes are up 6% year-over-year. Our NGL volumes are down 1%, primarily due to a plant -- a petrochemical plant turnaround by one of our customers. 
In Terminals, we're seeing the benefit of new liquids capacity coming online and increased utilization of that expanded capacity, so more capacity online and higher overall utilization. We also took delivery of 2 additional Jones Act vessels, which are under contract. Overall, the liquids portion of our Terminals business is over 75% of the segment earnings before DD&A before certain items. And the increased utilization we're seeing and the expansions we're bringing on are positives for that long-term outlook. 
With respect to the Jones Act vessels, we see medium-term market weakness there. We benefit from having charters in place for the vast majority of our vessels, and we have a modern fuel-efficient fleet that should be very competitive. But we expect some overcapacity in the market for the medium term, which will affect new charter rates and renewal rates until the overall U.S. fleet is right-sized from a capacity standpoint. 
On the bulk side, we're down slightly year-over-year, primarily, again, attributable to the coal vessels. 
In CO2, we had lower volumes year-over-year for the quarter, down 5%, with SACROC and gates [ph] down year-over-year; Katz, Goldsmith and Tall Cotton up year-over-year but below our plan. We also had strong NGL production of the segment, a record quarter, in fact, which is slightly higher than last year. And we also approved some new EOR development projects during the quarter and continue to find attractive return projects in this segment. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Kim for the financials.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Steve. Today, we're declaring a dividend of $0.125 per share, consistent with our budget and the guidance we gave you in December of last year. First, turning to the preliminary GAAP income statement. You will see that similar to the first
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Steve. Today, we're declaring a dividend of $0.125 per share, consistent with our budget and the guidance we gave you in December of last year. 
First, turning to the preliminary GAAP income statement. You will see that similar to the first 2 quarters of this year, revenues in the quarter are down significantly. As I say many quarters, we believe that revenue -- or the changes in revenue are not necessarily a good indicator of our performance. We have some businesses where revenues and expenses fluctuate with commodity prices but margin generally does not, which is why you also see a partially offsetting variance in cost of sales. 
In addition, both revenues and cost of sales can be impacted by noncash, sporadic accounting entries or certain items. The largest impact of the certain items on changes and revenues and cost of sales relates to the unrealized CO2 mark-to-market and hedging effectiveness impact on our change in revenues, which accounts for almost 40% of the $377 million change in revenues in the quarter. 
We had a net loss in the quarter of $227 million and a loss per share of $0.10 versus income of $186 million and earnings per share of $0.08 in the third quarter of last year, a reduction of $413 million and $0.18 a share. 
Now let me talk about what's driving that loss. We recorded a $230 million noncash after tax, and that's why that number is a little different from what Steve said because this is after-tax impairment on our MEP investment, driven by our expectations of lower future transportation contract rates and approximately a $350 million after-tax loss associated with the SNG transaction, most of which is noncash book tax expense. 
For those of you who are interested in how we can have such a large book tax expense on a relatively modest book loss when you would ordinarily expect a book tax benefit, I would be happy to explain later, but I'm not going to bore everybody with all the details at this point. Together, these 2 charges result in a net expense of $580 million and are the primary drivers of our $570 million in certain items for the quarter. So net income before certain items was a positive $343 million. The adjusted number in 2015 of -- was $345 million or down $2 million, essentially flat. EPS excluding certain items was $0.15 or down $0.01 versus the third quarter of 2015, so essentially flat when excluding certain items. 
Now let's turn to the second page of the financials, which shows our DCF for the quarter and year-to-date and is reconciled to our GAAP numbers in the earnings release. DCF is the primary financial measure on which management judges its performance. We generated total DCF for the quarter of $1.081 billion versus $1.129 billion for the comparable period in 2015, down $48 million or 4%. There are a lot of moving parts, but if you want a very simple explanation, it boils down to CO2 being down $53 million, primarily on lower commodity prices. But to take you through a more granular analysis, the segments were down by $33 million or 2%. As I previously mentioned, CO2 decreased $53 million and Natural Gas decreased about $18 million, with offsets -- those 2 segments were offset by increases in all of our other segments, with the largest dollar increase from the other segments coming from our Terminals segment. 
The Natural Gas segment would have been slightly positive if you exclude the impact of the SNG sale, which we sold a 50% interest in on September 1 of this year. Adding back an $11 million change in JV DD&A, which primarily reflects our increased interest in NGPL that we acquired in the fourth quarter of 2015, we add that back to the segment. The segment is now $33 million. The assets are really down about $22 million. This $22 million decrease was partially offset by $12 million benefit, i.e., lower expense when you combine G&A and interest expense. The $19 million in increased cash taxes, which is primarily driven by the fact that Citrus fully utilized its NOLs in 2015, is largely offset by an $18 million decrease in sustaining CapEx, a lot of which is cost savings. Netting out the $39 million increase in preferred stock dividends, you get to a DCF variance of $50 million versus the $48 million shown on the page. 
DCF per share was $0.48 in the quarter versus $0.51 for the third quarter of last year or down about -- down $0.03 per share, with about $0.02 associated with the DCF variance I just walked you through and about $0.01 due to the additional shares that were issued during 2015 to finance our growth projects and maintain our balance sheet. $0.48 in DCF per share results in $801 million in excess distributable cash flow above our $0.125 dividend for the quarter, and year-to-date, we've generated approximately $2.5 billion of excess distributable cash flow above our dividend. 
Now let me give you some details on our expected performance for the full year versus budget. Natural Gas Pipelines is expected to be approximately 5% below its budget due to the SNG transaction, lower volumes in our midstream group and a delay on our EEC/SNG pipeline expansion in service as a result of a delay in receiving our FERC certificate. If you exclude the impact of the sale of the 50% interest in SNG, we would have expected Natural Gas to be about 2% below its budget. So on an apples-to-apples basis, the 2% is consistent with what we told you last quarter for the Natural Gas Pipelines segment. 
CO2 is expected to end the year on its budget, consistent with the guidance we gave you last quarter. Some price help and cost savings are offsetting the lower-than-expected oil and CO2 volumes. 
We currently expect Terminals to end the year about 5% below its budget. That's slightly more than the 4% we discussed last quarter. The overall variance is due to the impact of the coal bankruptcies and lower throughput and ancillaries on some of our liquids terminals versus what we budgeted. Actually, throughput on our liquids terminals year-to-year, when you compare it to 2015, is actually up. It's just slightly lower than what we expected in our budget. 
We currently expect Products to end the year approximately 5% below its budget, consistent with the guidance we gave you last quarter, primarily due to lower crude and condensate volumes on KMCC, Double H and Double Eagle; lower throughput on KMST; and lower rates on our SFPP pipeline and as a result of the lost income due to the sale of Parkway. Consistent with last quarter, we are projecting KMC to be essentially on its budget. 
With respect to other items, interest, cash taxes, G&A and sustaining, on a combined basis for those items, we're expecting to come in lower than budget. Or said another way, they're expected to be a favorable variance, primarily as a result of lower interest and sustaining CapEx. Interest is expected to be approximately 4% below its budget. About half of those variance -- or over half of those variance is associated with the lower balance as a result of the SNG transaction, with the remaining variance driven primarily by lower rates. Sustaining CapEx is also expected to be approximately 4% lower than budget. 
Let me conclude with 2 overall financial points. On an apples-to-apples basis, our full year guidance has not changed from the updated guidance we gave you last quarter, when you exclude the impact from the 50% sale of SNG. We continue to expect that adjusted EBITDA will be about 3% below budget and DCF will be approximately 4% below budget. When you adjust for the 4-month impact of the 50% SNG sale, so not on an apples-to-apples basis with what we gave you last quarter, we expect EBITDA to be approximately 4% below budget. The DCF will also be approximately 4% below budget. DCF doesn't change versus SNG transaction versus no SNG transaction, given the interest rate savings -- 4% doesn't change, given the interest rate savings offset from the impact of the lost SNG EBITDA as we use all the proceeds from this transaction to reduce debt. 
And the second point is that we expect to end the year at 5.3x debt-to-EBITDA, which is also consistent with what we told you in the second quarter call. The 5.3 is down from our budget guidance of 5.5x, largely as a result of the SNG transaction. 
With that, I'll move to the balance sheet. When you look at total assets on the balance sheet, total assets are down $2.5 billion, and that's largely driven by the sale of the 50% interest in SNG. We ended the quarter with net debt of $39.25 billion, which is down $1.976 billion from the end of last year and down $2.073 billion from the second quarter. As I -- we ended the quarter at 5.3x debt-to-EBITDA, and as I said, that's where we would expect to end the year. The 5.3x is down from the 5.6x where we ended last year. 
Now to reconcile the change in debt for you for the quarter. As I said, debt is down $2.073 billion. We've generated DCF of $1.08 billion. We spent about $550 million in expansion CapEx, acquisitions and contributions to equity investments. We paid $280 million in dividends. We had proceeds from divestitures of about $1.43 billion, with the biggest being the SNG transaction. We also deconsolidated about $1.2 billion in debt as a result of the SNG transaction. And we also took $803 million of the cash that we received from that transaction and it is sitting in restricted cash, so in other current assets on our balance sheet. And we used that to pay debt on October 1. So that debt was not paid down as of 9/30 but has subsequently been paid down. And then we had $9 million of working capital and other items that was a use of cash. 
Year-to-date, the change in debt, $1.976 billion. So we've reduced debt by just under $2 billion. We've generated DCF of $3.36 billion. We had expansions, acquisitions and contributions to equity investments of $2.43 billion. We had -- we paid dividends of $839 million. We had proceeds from divestitures of $1.65 billion. We've deconsolidated $1.2 billion of SNG debt. We placed $800 million again into escrow, which is shown in restricted cash or other current assets on our balance sheet. Again, that paid down -- we used to pay down debt on October 1. And then we had working capital and other items that was a use of cash of about $168 million. And that gets you to the $1.976 billion reduction in debt. 
So with that, I'll turn it back over to Rich.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Kim. And with that, May, we will open the lines for questions.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Kim. And with that, May, we will open the lines for questions.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Kristina Kazarian from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Kristina Kazarian from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, appreciated the project updates. A quick -- couple of quick clarifications. On Utopia, any color on the judge's denial of your use of eminent domain? And maybe could you talk about what this means for that project? And then on Elba, appreciate the
componenttext: Steve, appreciated the project updates. A quick -- couple of quick clarifications. On Utopia, any color on the judge's denial of your use of eminent domain? And maybe could you talk about what this means for that project? And then on Elba, appreciate the November 1 date, but can you just remind me? Am I still going through the rehearing process? And what does that mean for that project going forward?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll start with Utopia. Yes, we had a Wood County judge, who, in interpreting the eminent domain statute, interpreted that our pipeline didn't qualify for eminent domain. We're appealing that. In fact, we filed the appeal last week. It's inconsisten
componenttext: Okay. I'll start with Utopia. Yes, we had a Wood County judge, who, in interpreting the eminent domain statute, interpreted that our pipeline didn't qualify for eminent domain. We're appealing that. In fact, we filed the appeal last week. It's inconsistent with what -- with other decisions, including appellate decisions that had been made in the state. So we think we're ultimately going to prevail on appeal there. Another -- there may be some other decisions that come out of Wood County that will be consistent with that, but we expect ultimately to prevail on appeal. Now we are going to -- we are in the process of evaluating what that means. We're 2/3 of the way through acquiring right-of-way already, separate and apart from what happened with that decision. So this is fairly recent news, and so we're sitting down and strategizing about how to go forward with the acquisition of the remaining right-of-way, what our legal strategy is going to be, et cetera. But that's what that decision was about. That's where we are in the project in terms of acquiring right-of-way and what we plan to do in terms of what we've already done in terms of appeal. On the Elba project, yes, we have -- we've reached agreement with Shell to proceed without the rehearing having been finalized. So we're ready to go. Our customers are ready to go. We are ready to go. We have our 7(c) already. As I've mentioned, we have the notice to proceed, which gives us the authority to go forward with construction even without a final order on rehearing. So we are proceeding and starting up November 1.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then just a quick follow-up for me, too. Rich mentioned the change in regulatory headwinds. Do you think there's a possibility for a change in tides to the positive year? What could be a driver for that? And if we don't see a change, what cou
componenttext: Perfect. And then just a quick follow-up for me, too. Rich mentioned the change in regulatory headwinds. Do you think there's a possibility for a change in tides to the positive year? What could be a driver for that? And if we don't see a change, what could be some other ways you adjust when thinking about new products going forward?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start with the latter part first. I mean, I think -- and Rich mentioned this on the adjustments. What we need to do is and we've been doing for months now is evaluating our project opportunities and having discussions with our customers that att
componenttext: Yes, I'll start with the latter part first. I mean, I think -- and Rich mentioned this on the adjustments. What we need to do is and we've been doing for months now is evaluating our project opportunities and having discussions with our customers that attempt to price and schedule in to our projects what is, no doubt, an enhanced regulatory burden for getting those projects through the permitting and approval process. So we have to make the appropriate adjustments. In terms of what can turn that around, again, this varies from place to place. I mean, we built our Texas pipeline over the summer effectively, and it's -- you have to go kind of place by place and kind of commodity by commodity to sort this out. But the bottom line is you need to fully take into account and we need to fully take into account the additional lengths and requirements that will be placed on the permitting process. So it's not that the whole world needs to change. This is a kind of a case-by-case consideration that you need to make. The other thing that can change the whole dynamic is, I think, increasingly, people will realize, those who don't already, that a big part of the answer to reduce CO2 emissions and cleaner power generation and compliance with the Clean Power Plan and things like that is enhanced -- is additional natural gas. And you don't get the additional natural gas without the additional gas infrastructure. So I think that's a driver that could potentially change some of that dynamic.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jeremy Tonet from JPMorgan. We'll move to the next question, and that is from Ms. Christine Cho from Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is from Jeremy Tonet from JPMorgan. We'll move to the next question, and that is from Ms. Christine Cho from Barclays.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to touch upon Elba. Regarding the rehearing, how should we think about expectations for this asset to be put into a JV? Do you want the final FERC order? Are you in talks with parties and just waiting for that? Or have talks sort of cooled now ju
componenttext: I wanted to touch upon Elba. Regarding the rehearing, how should we think about expectations for this asset to be put into a JV? Do you want the final FERC order? Are you in talks with parties and just waiting for that? Or have talks sort of cooled now just because it's not as urgent with leverage coming in better than your target for year-end?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Christine, we've talked -- we put -- or I'm sorry, we put Elba in as a placeholder kind of when we showed everyone our capital expenditure plans and everything at the beginning of the year, placeholder as a JV. We don't have the JV Elba. I think it i
componenttext: Yes. Christine, we've talked -- we put -- or I'm sorry, we put Elba in as a placeholder kind of when we showed everyone our capital expenditure plans and everything at the beginning of the year, placeholder as a JV. We don't have the JV Elba. I think it is a very amenable -- it is very amenable to a joint venture. It is a stand-alone asset investment, at least when it comes to the liquefaction facilities, and it's attractive. It's under a 20-year contract with Shell. We've got the ability to self-fund that or to JV it, but it is an attractive JV candidate. But again, we're not in a position where we have to do anything, in particular, with it. But we continue to explore options to JV assets, and that's one of the big variables and sort of what our plans are and how quickly we get to where we want to go. And Elba certainly is on the list of things that we can consider. I don't think the rehearing really bears on it that much one way or the other. I mean, I think in the context of FERC 7(c)s, it is often -- it's traditional for -- you get the 7(c) and you start construction when you get the notice to proceed without waiting for the rehearing. In this case, I would say we've got an extremely tight, extremely well reasoned, extremely thorough 7(c). They took extra time to get it out. And so we think it's going to withstand any rehearing or appeal, and so we're going to go ahead and get started.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great, that was helpful. And then moving over to Trans Mountain. I know we've got a couple of months before we hear from the Canadian government on this project. And I know earlier in the remarks, you said you're open to JVs. But how do you guys thi
componenttext: Okay. Great, that was helpful. And then moving over to Trans Mountain. I know we've got a couple of months before we hear from the Canadian government on this project. And I know earlier in the remarks, you said you're open to JVs. But how do you guys think about project financing in this project? Or would terms that usually come with project financing immediately rule that out? And by terms, I mean anything that would restrict how much cash you could pay out from the asset. Just curious as to how you think about that option.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we'll figure out what the structure is going to be first in terms of is it going to be a JV candidate, is it not going to be a JV candidate and what's the timing of it going forward, and then we'll figure out what the exact financing plan wo
componenttext: Well, I think we'll figure out what the structure is going to be first in terms of is it going to be a JV candidate, is it not going to be a JV candidate and what's the timing of it going forward, and then we'll figure out what the exact financing plan would be. But I wouldn't anticipate that we would put in structures that would make it difficult for us to get the cash out of the asset.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would you say you would lean towards having the asset kind of be off-balance sheet? Or that's kind of an afterthought?
componenttext: And would you say you would lean towards having the asset kind of be off-balance sheet? Or that's kind of an afterthought?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you're asking -- I think that the way -- we would look at it both ways, both having the leverage on our balance sheet and not having it on our balance sheet just to make sure that we are in an okay place even if the leverage was on our balance sheet.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then last one for me. Over the third quarter, we saw a big M&A announcement between 2 of your peers and then talks of another buyer trying to pick the interest of another company. Just curious as to what your view on the landscape is for
componenttext: Okay, great. And then last one for me. Over the third quarter, we saw a big M&A announcement between 2 of your peers and then talks of another buyer trying to pick the interest of another company. Just curious as to what your view on the landscape is for M&A in the U.S. and in Canada? And do you think we're finally going to see corporate M&A deals get done with everyone trying to fill in the holes of their portfolio and it also being increasingly more difficult to build new infrastructure like you said earlier, Rich? Or do you think it's just more fact specific?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's always pretty fact specific or situation specific. We continue to look for the opportunities. But in addition to being accretive to DCF, they kind of need to be accretive to leverage metrics. They still have to work from that standpoint. So it's a li
componenttext: It's always pretty fact specific or situation specific. We continue to look for the opportunities. But in addition to being accretive to DCF, they kind of need to be accretive to leverage metrics. They still have to work from that standpoint. So it's a little bit more difficult to get through the screens. But I think ultimately, there's going to be consolidation in this sector. If you look at the numbers and you look at how many players are out there and we would expect, ultimately, to be a participant in that.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Mr. Brian Gamble from Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Next question is from Mr. Brian Gamble from Simmons & Company.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kind of maybe just follow-up on the M&A discussion while we've got it. I think the sequel [ph] for C-Corp is a tough one to get through, lots of moving pieces with any combination that you may try to put together. But when you think about individual asset
componenttext: Kind of maybe just follow-up on the M&A discussion while we've got it. I think the sequel [ph] for C-Corp is a tough one to get through, lots of moving pieces with any combination that you may try to put together. But when you think about individual assets -- and Steve, you mentioned essentially the deleveraging of it. Given the assets that you guys have in place today, are there assets that if they were a deleveraging event in totality, you would consider divesting them? And unfortunately, I'm speaking specifically about CO2? But is getting something north of the leverage multiple enough to make an asset that isn't quite as core to your competencies a sellable item?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are unique considerations that surround everyone. As we've shown, making progress this year on our leverage metrics, we've considered non-core asset sales. We had a few of those. And the big transaction, of course, was SNG. And that was a bit unique
componenttext: There are unique considerations that surround everyone. As we've shown, making progress this year on our leverage metrics, we've considered non-core asset sales. We had a few of those. And the big transaction, of course, was SNG. And that was a bit unique circumstances. We're not generally in the business of selling cash flow and pipeline assets. But in that particular case, we have a partner who is bringing value, securing the asset but also bring incremental investment opportunities to the project. So it made a lot of sense for us to go ahead and do that. With respect to CO2 specifically, we like that business. It's a good business. We invest and get good returns on that business. It's a niche for us. We're not out chasing E&P and shale and offshore and things like that. We have CO2, which is a scarce commodity. And we have the infrastructure to get it delivered to EOR fields where it's the only thing that can free up oil, and we've integrated forward into enhanced oil recovery. And we've got expertise there, and we think we're good at it. So we like that business, and we're happy to keep running it. If you think about your question in terms of a transaction or a potential transaction, we are shareholder-directed company. And if there is a transaction to be done that will improve overall value for our shareholders, we are absolutely going to consider it and do it if it makes sense. The considerations around CO2 specifically is that it would probably slightly dilutive or somewhat dilutive. And then the question would have to be, is the multiple expansion that you get on the remaining EBITDA of the remaining business and the yield contraction on DCF that you get by having a better portfolio or a more stable portfolio of remaining businesses enough to offset that and produce real shareholder value? And certainly, there are theoretical numbers at which that would work. And so again, we are shareholder-directed company. We're going to do things that are going to make sense and create value for our shareholders.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the shareholder comment, do you think there's enough shareholder support of the sale of that asset to make it a more -- I guess, make the hurdle easier to jump over, knowing that shareholders support that type of decision?
componenttext: On the shareholder comment, do you think there's enough shareholder support of the sale of that asset to make it a more -- I guess, make the hurdle easier to jump over, knowing that shareholders support that type of decision?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's about the numbers for us, and it's about what's going to make economic sense. As I said, what would the dilution be and what would a multiple increase need to be to more than offset that. So at the other side of it, a shareholder is better of
componenttext: I think it's about the numbers for us, and it's about what's going to make economic sense. As I said, what would the dilution be and what would a multiple increase need to be to more than offset that. So at the other side of it, a shareholder is better off. That's the calculation we make.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then last question for me. Rich, you mentioned part of the opening remarks, essentially first priority for increased cash flow would be after, of course, you get to your debt metrics as I think you put a significant increase in the dividend ove
componenttext: Great. And then last question for me. Rich, you mentioned part of the opening remarks, essentially first priority for increased cash flow would be after, of course, you get to your debt metrics as I think you put a significant increase in the dividend over time. Clarify one thing for me. Are we getting to 5x before contemplating that? Or are we having visibility to get to 5x before that is a contemplation?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've always said we wanted to get to around 5x before we increase the dividend, and that's still our target. But again, I think it's important that we've got so many questions about this. We elected to lay out a little more detail on it. And our
componenttext: I think we've always said we wanted to get to around 5x before we increase the dividend, and that's still our target. But again, I think it's important that we've got so many questions about this. We elected to lay out a little more detail on it. And our game plan -- again, we would reserve the right to see what the facts on the ground are when we get to that point. But our game plan would be, we obviously have a lot of firepower, a lot of free cash flow. And to the extent we can substantially increase the dividend while still maintaining an adequate coverage ratio, and by that, I would mean that we would be able to fund the equity portion of our going rate of capital expenditures. We don't know exactly what that is, but we look back and you take out the pigs going through the boa constrictor like Trans Mountain, for example. You're kind of in that, I don't know, $2 billion, $2.5 billion, $3 billion in that range. And if you say once our balance sheet is where we want it, we're going to finance half of that out of retained cash and half of that back in the debt markets at that point in time, then you can get -- you can see your way clear to having a very nice dividend but with very nice coverage and maintaining a strong balance sheet. And that's really the trifecta that we're looking for. And I think, I mean, just look at this year, I think Kim emphasized this, we're right consistent, absent the SNG transaction, with where we told you in April and where we told you in July we're going to be. And that leaves the DCF of about $2 per share for this year, and we're paying out a $0.50 dividend. That's a whale of a spread between the 2. But at some point, when we get this balance sheet the way we want it, we're going to be able to take that dividend up substantially and still have adequate coverage. We're not going back to having $0.05 of coverage or something like that because we like to cover our portion -- the equity portion of a normalized CapEx program.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think, it's -- we talked about it in answer to a question, I think, on the last call. So it's consistent with it to that point, but we're getting closer now to some -- to decision point and resolution. And yes, there's been interest in the project as you'd expect. And so it's just the kind of, as I said, a little bit of ripening here from -- ripening in the process. In our thinking, there's a little ripening left to go in terms of getting some of these -- getting the clarity on the regulatory front which, again, appears to be getting closer.

componenttext: Okay. And probably as expected, the project screens are almost screens for a JV partner here. As you think about and kind of prioritize or rank potential partners and project promotes that accrue back to your part of the development, and this is a big open question, but how do you think through that process in terms of what you'd like to see in terms of getting paid for your development work here, in terms of reducing your capital requirements in '17, '18 and early '19 and being able to kind of return to getting cash back to shareholders? How do you balance all those pieces of that equation just conceptually?

componenttextpreview: Those are all 3 benefits, right, and agree with those. But we're really not foreclosing. We've got a lot of options in addition to having a good interest in it. We've got a lot of options on how to proceed and a fair amount of work to do to figure out wha
componenttext: Those are all 3 benefits, right, and agree with those. But we're really not foreclosing. We've got a lot of options in addition to having a good interest in it. We've got a lot of options on how to proceed and a fair amount of work to do to figure out what the best option is. So we're keeping those options open and not really ready to refine that any further for you right now.
