headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, if you think about where we were 12 months ago and where we are today, 12 months ago, we were at 5.6x debt-to-EBITDA and we had -- we were paying out substantially all of our cash flow in the form of dividends. Today, we're at 5.3x, and we a
componenttext: Sure. I mean, if you think about where we were 12 months ago and where we are today, 12 months ago, we were at 5.6x debt-to-EBITDA and we had -- we were paying out substantially all of our cash flow in the form of dividends. Today, we're at 5.3x, and we are paying out a very small portion of our cash flow in terms of dividends. And so I think we are in a very good shape in our current rating.

componenttext: Yes. We've just had some interest from various shippers and potentially looking at contracts when the contracts on MEP have expired or will expire. And based on those conversations, we felt like that the rates that we might get when the contracts expire don't support the carrying value that we have when we hold [ph] that asset.

componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones for me. So we've had a nice run in crude price recently, and services costs have come down a lot this year. headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we don't look at it that way. The way we look at it is we look at a discrete project by project, and we look at the returns on the projects that the CO2 group brings forward. And if those returns clear our hurdle and the minimum amount of tha
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we don't look at it that way. The way we look at it is we look at a discrete project by project, and we look at the returns on the projects that the CO2 group brings forward. And if those returns clear our hurdle and the minimum amount of that hurdle is 15% unlevered after tax right now and if they cleared that hurdle, then we generally proceed with it and if they don't clear that hurdle at a minimum, then generally, we aren't pursuing those projects.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understand, thank you. And then my second question. Exports to Mexico, as you guys have noted, had grown massively, 3.3 Bcfe I believe that you mentioned that the majority of that moves on Kinder Morgan pipeline. There are a bunch of New Mexico expo
componenttext: Okay, understand, thank you. And then my second question. Exports to Mexico, as you guys have noted, had grown massively, 3.3 Bcfe I believe that you mentioned that the majority of that moves on Kinder Morgan pipeline. There are a bunch of New Mexico export price I think 3 Bcfe coming in the first half of next year. Will that have a material impact on your physical flows or segment EBITDA?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given where our assets are positioned overall, growth in Mexico export volumes are going to benefit us even if other people are building pipelines. An example of that would be the NET pipeline that went into service, what, Tom, 2 [ph] years or so ago? And
componenttext: Given where our assets are positioned overall, growth in Mexico export volumes are going to benefit us even if other people are building pipelines. An example of that would be the NET pipeline that went into service, what, Tom, 2 [ph] years or so ago? And we delivered a substantial amount of gas into that pipeline. And the reason for that is we have the infrastructure in Texas. We have the infrastructure on EP&G from West Texas to -- through Arizona. And so it's part of a larger grid and our piece of event grid is well-positioned to benefit from the pulling into Mexico that's happening in increasing volumes over the years. So even if it's not us constructing in-country pipe, which we haven't gotten comfortable with from a risk-reward standpoint, the increase in demand and the looking it up increasingly to U.S. supply resources is going to benefit our system overall. Trans Mountain as well as storage and on the interest side of sales.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, this sounds like a broken record but we've said time and time again. This is one more demonstration of the strength that is inherent in having the kind of pipeline that work on the natural gas side that we have, which expand all the producing hor
componenttext: I think, this sounds like a broken record but we've said time and time again. This is one more demonstration of the strength that is inherent in having the kind of pipeline that work on the natural gas side that we have, which expand all the producing horizons and that interconnect with virtually all of the pipeline system in America. And that's going to pay dividends for many years to come.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've got roughly -- I don't think I can answer that question exactly. We've got 30% of what we call our gathering and processing that is under take-or-pay contracts. But with out looking at it kind of contract by contract, I couldn't tell you whethe
componenttext: Yes, we've got roughly -- I don't think I can answer that question exactly. We've got 30% of what we call our gathering and processing that is under take-or-pay contracts. But with out looking at it kind of contract by contract, I couldn't tell you whether -- well wait, short answer is -- if there's continued decline, we're not at the bottom. There will be a continued decline in our revenues. But we do have some floor in our revenue because we get this 30% of the contracts are take-or-pay.

componenttext: Yes, we have successfully increased our market share from where we were sitting in the first and second quarters and those incentive contract were a big part of that. And so we have if you will, restored the market share that we had at the end of '15 back to where we were. But if -- we're still in the Eagle Ford, it's a marketshare of a declining overall base. So the decline is still coming. But I think the program that Tom and his team initiated was successful in taking your market share back up.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well the FPP is not -- let me -- it's not revenue issue in terms of what the shippers are paying us because those are take-or-pay contracts and think that contracts goes through 2019 or 2020 on FPP. And I think it would just be as we figure out where we t
componenttext: Well the FPP is not -- let me -- it's not revenue issue in terms of what the shippers are paying us because those are take-or-pay contracts and think that contracts goes through 2019 or 2020 on FPP. And I think it would just be as we figure out where we think exactly the market is, whether you had a noncash impairment on those assets. So the customers are still paying. In fact, the largest customer on FPP is Southwestern. Think they've actually put a rig or 2 back into the Fayetteville and their credit situation I think, has improved dramatically over the last few months.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, coming back to Trans Mountain here. So maybe you can give us a little bit of a preview on this Ministerial Panels Report. I think it's due November 1 and kind of how that will impact the December decision and then also an update on the BC process, m
componenttext: Rich, coming back to Trans Mountain here. So maybe you can give us a little bit of a preview on this Ministerial Panels Report. I think it's due November 1 and kind of how that will impact the December decision and then also an update on the BC process, meeting the 5 conditions in particular. I think revenue is certainly one of the big ones there.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there were a couple if you will, additional federal processes. One was a federal consultation process where the federal government was directly out consulting with First Nations and communities. The one that you're specifically referring to is there
componenttext: Yes, there were a couple if you will, additional federal processes. One was a federal consultation process where the federal government was directly out consulting with First Nations and communities. The one that you're specifically referring to is there was a 3 -- a panel of 3 people appointed to go out and hear from the community up and down, the right-of-way and gather data or gather perspectives that hadn't been picked up in the NEB proceeding. That process is wrapped up in terms of hearing. And as you pointed out, there's a report that's due. It's a report that is cataloging, at least, as I understand it, everything that the group have heard while they were talking to people of communities along the rights-of-way. The federal of those things feed into, the federal decision, the Order In Council that comes out of the federal government, which is still scheduled for December 20. So that -- I don't know of anything, Ted, that's inconsistent with the December 20 date, certainly nothing that's associated with those two processes. We still expect to see on/or before December 20, a final Order In Council.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my other part of my questions, it was a long one, on the British Colombia process, [indiscernible] conditions and the [indiscernible]
componenttext: And then my other part of my questions, it was a long one, on the British Colombia process, [indiscernible] conditions and the [indiscernible]

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have been engaged with British Columbia on the five conditions. I think it's been constructive and productive engagement. We don't have anything final there. The other process that's going on in British Columbia is the EEA quarter that they are going t
componenttext: We have been engaged with British Columbia on the five conditions. I think it's been constructive and productive engagement. We don't have anything final there. The other process that's going on in British Columbia is the EEA quarter that they are going to issue around the same time as the federal decision. And at least in our thinking, we're assuming that's in January. But that's not going to be in December, that's going to be in January. And so I think what we're aiming for us to have the British Columbia conditions, as well as that Environmental Order resolved and complete early next year.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Budget returns are still in line. We're still working on the costs with the contractors. We've made very good progress, I would say. But we're not final yet and we're still, as you know, a complicated project. There's still work to be done there but I think we've made good progress.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I just wanted to confirm your response to one of the earlier questions. I think it was Brian's question about retaining distributable cash flow. I just wanted to make sure I understood it correctly. If, let's say, you're at a run rate of just usi
componenttext: I guess, I just wanted to confirm your response to one of the earlier questions. I think it was Brian's question about retaining distributable cash flow. I just wanted to make sure I understood it correctly. If, let's say, you're at a run rate of just using random numbers here, about $4.5 million [ph] in distributable cash flow. And I think if I heard you correctly, you talked about potentially holding back about $2 billion of that retained DCF to fund the equity portion of kind of the normalized growth CapEx budget.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, you didn't hear me correctly. Let me -- what I said was we would hold back and certainly, we will expect that $4.5 million [ph] run rate today to increase as new projects come online. What I said was we would hold back the amount necessary to fund the
componenttext: No, you didn't hear me correctly. Let me -- what I said was we would hold back and certainly, we will expect that $4.5 million [ph] run rate today to increase as new projects come online. What I said was we would hold back the amount necessary to fund the equity portion of normalized CapEx expenditure for the year. So for example, we would think that -- and that will depend on what kind of projects you have, that we think historically, that's between $2 billion and $3 billion a year. So the midpoint of that is $2.5 billion, you'd be withholding $1.25 billion out of that $4.5 billion or $5 billion of distributable cash flow. So it's not the whole thing because once we get to the level of the appropriate level of debt, we would intend to go back to financing half equity, half debt. But the difference is, we would not put -- we will not contemplate putting out new equity. We will be using retained cash flow from operations to fund the "equity portion" of that. Does that answer your question now?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're actually on the same page. So if I do my math correctly, I mean, it's a very significant increase in the dividend from where you are today which I think it's running at about $1.1 billion or $1.2 billion. Am I thinking about that correc
componenttext: Yes, I think we're actually on the same page. So if I do my math correctly, I mean, it's a very significant increase in the dividend from where you are today which I think it's running at about $1.1 billion or $1.2 billion. Am I thinking about that correctly and corresponds with your way of [indiscernible] comments earlier?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there will be of course, a significant difference there.
componenttext: Yes, I think there will be of course, a significant difference there.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, cool. Second question, I know that you've been asked this many different ways. But I realize that the company's made considerable progress of getting down to your stated goal of 5x net debt-to-EBITDA. I guess kind of two questions in one here. But h
componenttext: Okay, cool. Second question, I know that you've been asked this many different ways. But I realize that the company's made considerable progress of getting down to your stated goal of 5x net debt-to-EBITDA. I guess kind of two questions in one here. But has that leveraged goal impacted your ability to consider some growth projects? And then secondly, given all the questions about returning to a higher level of a dividend, is the board considering any options to accelerate the pace to this 5x leverage goal either through equity or preferred issuances or even asset sales or is the Board comfortable with the pace where you're at you'll get there when you expect to get there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so let me answer. And I think my answer to the first will address the answer to the second question, which is the reason that we decreased the dividend primarily a year ago had to do with inefficient capital markets and not wanting to fund expansion
componenttext: Okay, so let me answer. And I think my answer to the first will address the answer to the second question, which is the reason that we decreased the dividend primarily a year ago had to do with inefficient capital markets and not wanting to fund expansion CapEx in a market that wasn't rationally pricing debt and equity securities. And so I think that the debt market has changed. The equity market is still significantly different from where we were 12 months ago, 18 months ago. And so we are funding our CapEx program. So we -- in my mind, what we're constrained by, we do want to improve the balance sheet and that is the goal that we have. But what we're doing is that we're living within our cash flow, meaning that we want to be able to fund our equity -- our CapEx and our dividend from our cash flow. And so that is the constraint. And because -- and so -- because we have limited amount of capital, that is why we have the hurdle rates set at 15% unlevered after-tax IRR for projects. I fully anticipate that over time, as that CapEx comes down and also, as the balance sheet improves, that we would relax that standard. I don't know exactly what that number is going to be today. But it would be something less than the 15%. It probably won't be back at the 8% unlevered after-tax that we previously used for hurdle rate but we will have to make the assessment when that time comes.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so you're comfortable with the pace that you're at? Or would you consider options to accelerate getting there?
componenttext: And so you're comfortable with the pace that you're at? Or would you consider options to accelerate getting there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you mean assuming equity, we're not an equity issuer at these prices.
componenttext: Well, if you mean assuming equity, we're not an equity issuer at these prices.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's why we're living within cash flow given where the current equity prices are.
componenttext: That's why we're living within cash flow given where the current equity prices are.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: But look, we are -- we're going as fast as we can. If we can find ways to go faster, we will. And we're working on this all the time, as you might imagine. This is -- this is just a question, the particular method that you identified as distinguished from
componenttext: But look, we are -- we're going as fast as we can. If we can find ways to go faster, we will. And we're working on this all the time, as you might imagine. This is -- this is just a question, the particular method that you identified as distinguished from attractive joint ventures for example and other ways of accelerating us getting there. That approach that is issuing equity, is not attractive at today's prices.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And one final question. We've seen a spike in global coal prices recently and I know you've had some challenges at your Terminals over the last 2 years. Has there been any -- has there been any inquiries or increased inquiries in terms
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And one final question. We've seen a spike in global coal prices recently and I know you've had some challenges at your Terminals over the last 2 years. Has there been any -- has there been any inquiries or increased inquiries in terms of folks wanting to ship out coal in bulk out of the U.S.? Or is it still too early to see the benefit from the recent increases that we've seen in coal prices globally?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We saw actually a 13% uptick in the last quarter in our coal volumes, mostly on the export side. Now on a U.S. basis, exports were down 11.8%. That's just a drop in the bucket. We're still down 30% on a year-over-year basis. Pricing, we've seen some price
componenttext: We saw actually a 13% uptick in the last quarter in our coal volumes, mostly on the export side. Now on a U.S. basis, exports were down 11.8%. That's just a drop in the bucket. We're still down 30% on a year-over-year basis. Pricing, we've seen some price compression. Volumes did spike up. But we don't anticipate that going significantly higher. The forecast for this year is still tracking at about 59 million tonnes of export. And that's comparable to 74 million tonnes last year. It's not projected a lot higher than that.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've got some ground to make up.
componenttext: So we've got some ground to make up.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Darren Horowitz from Raymond James.
componenttext: Next question is from Darren Horowitz from Raymond James.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll be quick, Rich. You and Steve mentioned the permitting challenges and obviously, the Connecticut expansion of TGP comes to mind. I'm just thinking, systemically, what impact do you think these permitting challenges are going to have specifically on t
componenttext: I'll be quick, Rich. You and Steve mentioned the permitting challenges and obviously, the Connecticut expansion of TGP comes to mind. I'm just thinking, systemically, what impact do you think these permitting challenges are going to have specifically on the Northeast Gas market when you reconcile the amount of marketed pipe capacity versus what you've said you expect Marcellus and Utica production growth expectations to be? Do you think it's a rescaling of marketed pipe or a combination of pipes? And I'm most interested to know your thoughts on may be some basis differential expectations, more pressure in the non hub but most importantly, how you capitalize on it through the scaling of TGP?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, a lot loaded in there. But basically, I think our view is it's very hard to get big, newbuilds done into New England or into the Northeast. We've seen that not only with MEP which we talked about in the first quarter and discontinued. But also with
componenttext: Okay, a lot loaded in there. But basically, I think our view is it's very hard to get big, newbuilds done into New England or into the Northeast. We've seen that not only with MEP which we talked about in the first quarter and discontinued. But also with recent rulings that I think verified that decision. It's making it harder to get things done on a kind of a mega- scale call it. Now we have continued to engage with our customers on smaller scale projects and we'll continue to pursue those. But I think from the perspective of right now, today, it is hard to get new, significant gas infrastructure built into New England. And that would intend to increase the basis differentials for, between what's already lowest price for gas in Dominion South, call it, and the New England market, which is the few -- the highest priced in North America and it just a few hundred miles away. So borrowing some improvement on an overall permitting environment, I think it's difficult to do those. But I think we're looking at the smaller projects to do. The other thing I think New England is a perfect example of what Rich said at the very beginning which is that it does tend to make existing -- the existing network more valuable. The other thing I'd add to Tom throw them what everyone's. With that TGP system is a system that is continuing to produce project opportunities for us. A lot of our backlog on TGP, a lot of our backlog on gas is on TGP. I mean, is the biggest home for us outside of the Elba project right now. And what a lot of the project capital is directed at now is getting the gas, as you know, Darren, South from the Marcellus and Utica to the new market, the new market area, which is now the Gulf Coast of the United States. And we are proceeding along very well with those. We're building on our existing footprint, that again, goes to the need to make distinctions between projects out there and infrastructure projects, building off of your existing footprint, adding compression, maybe laying some parallel pipe, things like that. That create a difference -- that's a different, in a federally certificated process, that's a different context in which to be doing your project expansions. So I think you'll see basis widen too in New England to the Northeast and I think we'll find plenty of things to invest in and [indiscernible] to invest in, on TGP, to get that gas someplace else.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Jeremy Tonet from JP MC.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Going back to TMX here. I was wondering if you help me think through some things here as far as if there's any target as far as what the right ownership would be for this? I was wondering if you can help me think through that.

componenttext: Okay, a number of things in there. I think yes, the project -- the project is hard to separate from the underlying asset to answer the simplest rate of your questions there. On the approach on what the ownership percentage would be and more of the details, I'll go back to the earlier answer, which is we have a lot of options and we're going to pursue the most valuable one. That's the easiest way I can characterize it. And we don't have to do anything, which is, a great position to be in. But we are going to evaluate it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, got you, that's helpful. And then, if I heard you correctly, let know if I'm wrong, as far as where the regulatory process might make sense to proceed with the JVs if the terms make sense, is kind of early next year, when you see things progress to s
componenttext: Yes, got you, that's helpful. And then, if I heard you correctly, let know if I'm wrong, as far as where the regulatory process might make sense to proceed with the JVs if the terms make sense, is kind of early next year, when you see things progress to schedule? That can kind of come to fruition at that point?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good point to be looking at it. When we see the regulatory clarity. Because I think investors would like to see that too. So I think that's a reasonable point for us to be examining it.
componenttext: Yes, that's a good point to be looking at it. When we see the regulatory clarity. Because I think investors would like to see that too. So I think that's a reasonable point for us to be examining it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Craig Shere from Julie Brothers.
componenttext: Next question is from Craig Shere from Julie Brothers.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions here. One, Rich, you commented about the historical, annual run rate, call it, about $2.5 billion a year. I know we have some taken that Python issues with Trans Mountain but other such items that may be JV-ed. But I guess my ques
componenttext: So a couple of questions here. One, Rich, you commented about the historical, annual run rate, call it, about $2.5 billion a year. I know we have some taken that Python issues with Trans Mountain but other such items that may be JV-ed. But I guess my question is, as you think about lowering the hurdle rate for new projects from 15%, perhaps to the very low double digits, do you see the capacity in this current market to really fill for that kind of ongoing investment opportunity, when year-to-date, you only filled in $575 million?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, again, we just have to look at what the environment is at that particular point in time. These things do vary from year-to-year. But we look back over several years and it's our thought at this time, and again, it's our preliminary outside,
componenttext: Well, I think, again, we just have to look at what the environment is at that particular point in time. These things do vary from year-to-year. But we look back over several years and it's our thought at this time, and again, it's our preliminary outside, as I've stressed. But that annual burn rate commercial, of expansion CapEx is something in the range we talked about. And that's what we would want to use as providing enough coverage to pay for the "equity portion" of that burn rate. And I think under almost any scenario, that leaves a lot of money to pay dividends. But we'll just look at the exact circumstances when we reach that point.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Is there any color about how much you've left on the table? Because it didn't meet your hurdle rate because of the significant balance sheet management that that's really helped a lot in the last 2, 3, 4 quarters. Any kind of color on what you
componenttext: Understood. Is there any color about how much you've left on the table? Because it didn't meet your hurdle rate because of the significant balance sheet management that that's really helped a lot in the last 2, 3, 4 quarters. Any kind of color on what you've already left on the table because of that discipline that may be when, in a better market, might be there in the future?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we left anything on the table, Craig. We did elevate our return -- our hurdle criteria. But we have continued to say, look, if there's something that our business units thinks makes sense, we got a good customer, good counter-party credi
componenttext: I don't know that we left anything on the table, Craig. We did elevate our return -- our hurdle criteria. But we have continued to say, look, if there's something that our business units thinks makes sense, we got a good customer, good counter-party credit, long-term contracts, confidence around execution, et cetera, we want to bring in and talk about it. And we continue to see those come forward. I think the one place that we took a close look at was CO2 and certainly, in the oil price environment we saw earlier in the year, we took projects off the table and now, we're adding those back as we see oil prices recover. So look, after some -- are there some things that we might have been able to do if you were at an 8% world that we're not doing when we're in a 15% world? Yes, maybe so. But I think what we're talking about in the longer-term is return hurdles that we will relax off of the 15%, as Kim said. And I think given the network that we have, we'll still find those opportunities off our network and we're finding some of them still today.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: If you're asking if we've had any changes on the underlying contract at MEP, no. There have been no underlying changes. This is based on -- the impairment is largely based on, informed by discussions with customers on rates that we can get when contracts expire.

componenttext: We have two ships that are not yet constructed. Those are the only two of the 14 that are currently not chartered -- the only 2 of the 16 that are not currently chartered. Everything else, as I said, there's one under a shorter term charter that's rolling into a long-term charter. Everything is chartered. We do have some coming off in one or two in 2017 -- 3 in 2017.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're having a really strong year here. We're up $12 million on the base mostly due to a less off hire and higher rates and then the expansion of another 25.7. If you kind of look going forward, the risk really is we've got 11 that are under long-term agr
componenttext: We're having a really strong year here. We're up $12 million on the base mostly due to a less off hire and higher rates and then the expansion of another 25.7. If you kind of look going forward, the risk really is we've got 11 that are under long-term agreement and then 5 that could be impacted at some point or another, that's about 15% of the total earnings for that group.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very good color, thank you. And then on -- there was the question about Trans Mountain costs. I just want to confirm. I mean, historically, all of said that if we bumped up against that upper limit of what the off takers were required to accept in
componenttext: That's very good color, thank you. And then on -- there was the question about Trans Mountain costs. I just want to confirm. I mean, historically, all of said that if we bumped up against that upper limit of what the off takers were required to accept in Canadian dollars, if we punched through that, there are still significant shipper interest. And if conditions were that you punch through that a little bit, that the expectation would be that there would be plenty of still interest and you wouldn't be too worried about that. Is that still the case that whatever comes, you're going to do your best to keep costs down but the shipper interest is there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is good strong shipper interest including outside of the current shippers. Yes, we still believe that. Now having said that, we're working very hard to keep our overall costs down and to be within the cap. And we are making good progress. But yes, w
componenttext: There is good strong shipper interest including outside of the current shippers. Yes, we still believe that. Now having said that, we're working very hard to keep our overall costs down and to be within the cap. And we are making good progress. But yes, we do believe that they're strong enough -- there is strong shipper interest outside of the existing shippers.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Great. And then last question for me, kind of a bigger picture. headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think is the same general comment which is that we had to take all of those kinds of things into account in scheduling and costing our projects and it includes additional public outreach. It also includes taking into account security measures that may b
componenttext: I think is the same general comment which is that we had to take all of those kinds of things into account in scheduling and costing our projects and it includes additional public outreach. It also includes taking into account security measures that may be needed. So it's about adapting to that new environment and that's what we are actively doing.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think we've been targeting about 5x leverage as a decision point. When we get to that point, we will, as Rich said, we will look at the dividend, we will look at whether we want to pay down additional debt and we will look at what we think
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think we've been targeting about 5x leverage as a decision point. When we get to that point, we will, as Rich said, we will look at the dividend, we will look at whether we want to pay down additional debt and we will look at what we think the right, long-term run rate is for the business, whether it is the 5x or whether it is something improved from there. And so I think in terms of, you can expect that it would be at 5x or potentially, better, depending on what decision we make when we get to that point.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
