componenttext: I guess, let's start with Trans Mountain again. Steve, you are pretty clear or, I'd say, very clear in your messaging around JV potential for Trans Mountain. I guess, one question is, has anything changed quarter-over-quarter that caused you to be more clear about that messaging? Was it counter-party interest? Or has this been kind of the plan all along?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, it's -- we talked about it in answer to a question, I think, on the last call. So it's consistent with it to that point, but we're getting closer now to some -- to decision point and resolution. And yes, there's been interest in the project
componenttext: Well, I think, it's -- we talked about it in answer to a question, I think, on the last call. So it's consistent with it to that point, but we're getting closer now to some -- to decision point and resolution. And yes, there's been interest in the project as you'd expect. And so it's just the kind of, as I said, a little bit of ripening here from -- ripening in the process. In our thinking, there's a little ripening left to go in terms of getting some of these -- getting the clarity on the regulatory front which, again, appears to be getting closer.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And probably as expected, the project screens are almost screens for a JV partner here. As you think about and kind of prioritize or rank potential partners and project promotes that accrue back to your part of the development, and this is a big ope
componenttext: Okay. And probably as expected, the project screens are almost screens for a JV partner here. As you think about and kind of prioritize or rank potential partners and project promotes that accrue back to your part of the development, and this is a big open question, but how do you think through that process in terms of what you'd like to see in terms of getting paid for your development work here, in terms of reducing your capital requirements in '17, '18 and early '19 and being able to kind of return to getting cash back to shareholders? How do you balance all those pieces of that equation just conceptually?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Those are all 3 benefits, right, and agree with those. But we're really not foreclosing. We've got a lot of options in addition to having a good interest in it. We've got a lot of options on how to proceed and a fair amount of work to do to figure out wha
componenttext: Those are all 3 benefits, right, and agree with those. But we're really not foreclosing. We've got a lot of options in addition to having a good interest in it. We've got a lot of options on how to proceed and a fair amount of work to do to figure out what the best option is. So we're keeping those options open and not really ready to refine that any further for you right now.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. But probably just noting the potential there and the opportunity to create some real value near term rather than longer term. Okay, I'll leave that one to rest. Another broad question. So surprises about 12 months ago from the ratings a
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. But probably just noting the potential there and the opportunity to create some real value near term rather than longer term. Okay, I'll leave that one to rest. Another broad question. So surprises about 12 months ago from the ratings agencies. How have those conversations kind of evolve over the last 12 months in terms of just level of comfort on the other side of the table as you continue to have those conversations with the rating agencies?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, if you think about where we were 12 months ago and where we are today, 12 months ago, we were at 5.6x debt-to-EBITDA and we had -- we were paying out substantially all of our cash flow in the form of dividends. Today we're at 5.3x and we a
componenttext:
Sure. I mean, if you think about where we were 12 months ago and where we are today, 12 months ago, we were at 5.6x debt-to-EBITDA and we had -- we were paying out substantially all of our cash flow in the form of dividends. 
Today we're at 5.3x and we are paying out a very small portion of our cash flow in terms of dividends. And so I think we are in very good shape in our current rating.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Understood. And then last question for me. The MEP write-down, what triggered that process or that consideration?
componenttext: Okay. Understood. And then last question for me. The MEP write-down, what triggered that process or that consideration?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've just had some interest from various shippers and potentially looking at contracts when the contracts on MEP have expired or will expire. And based on those conversations, we felt like that the rates that we might get when the contracts expire d
componenttext: Yes. We've just had some interest from various shippers and potentially looking at contracts when the contracts on MEP have expired or will expire. And based on those conversations, we felt like that the rates that we might get when the contracts expire don't support the carrying value that we have where we have that asset.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Next question is from Jean Salisbury from Bernstein.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones for me. So we've had a nice run in crude price recently and services cost have come down a lot this year. At these new lower services cost, can you give a range of oil price at which you would be able to book new crude reserves
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones for me. So we've had a nice run in crude price recently and services cost have come down a lot this year. At these new lower services cost, can you give a range of oil price at which you would be able to book new crude reserves at a level that approximates replacing production? I assume that, that number has actually gotten much better than last year.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jesse, you want to...
componenttext: Jesse, you want to...

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we've added projects throughout the year. So as prices improve, I'd say we're adding reserves today.
componenttext: Yes. I think we've added projects throughout the year. So as prices improve, I'd say we're adding reserves today.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Do you have a sense of, if you wanted to actually replace 100% of your production this year, what prices would have to be or even a range?
componenttext: Okay. Do you have a sense of, if you wanted to actually replace 100% of your production this year, what prices would have to be or even a range?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we don't look at it that way. The way we look at it is we look at a discrete project by project, and we look at the returns on the projects that the CO2 group brings forward. And if those returns clear our hurdle -- and the minimum amount of
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we don't look at it that way. The way we look at it is we look at a discrete project by project, and we look at the returns on the projects that the CO2 group brings forward. And if those returns clear our hurdle -- and the minimum amount of that hurdle is 15% unlevered after tax right now. And if they clear that hurdle, then we generally proceed with it. And if they don't clear that hurdle at a minimum, then generally, we aren't pursuing those projects.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Understand. And then my second question. Exports to Mexico, as you guys have noted, have grown massively, 3.3 Bcfe. And I believe that you mentioned that the majority of that moves on Kinder Morgan pipelines. There are a bunch of new Mexico export p
componenttext: Okay. Understand. And then my second question. Exports to Mexico, as you guys have noted, have grown massively, 3.3 Bcfe. And I believe that you mentioned that the majority of that moves on Kinder Morgan pipelines. There are a bunch of new Mexico export price, I think 3 Bcfe coming on in the first half of next year. Will that have a material impact on your physical flows or segment EBITDA?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that given where our assets are positioned overall, growth in Mexico export volumes are going to benefit us even if other people are building pipelines. An example of that would be the NET pipeline that went into service, what, Tom, 2 years or so
componenttext: I think that given where our assets are positioned overall, growth in Mexico export volumes are going to benefit us even if other people are building pipelines. An example of that would be the NET pipeline that went into service, what, Tom, 2 years or so ago? And we deliver a substantial amount of gas into that pipeline. And the reason for that is we have the infrastructure in Texas. We have the infrastructure on EPNG from West Texas to -- through Arizona. And so it's part of a -- is part of a larger grid, and our piece of that grid is well positioned to benefit from the pulling into Mexico that's happening in increasing volumes over the years. So even if it's not us constructing in-country pipe, which we haven't gotten comfortable with from a risk/reward standpoint, the increase in demand and the hooking it up increasingly to U.S. supply resources is going to benefit our system overall, transport as well as storage and on the intrastate side sales.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think this sounds like a broken record, but we've said it time and time again. This is one more demonstration of the strength that is inherent in having the kind of pipeline network on the natural gas side that we have, which spans all the producing
componenttext: And I think this sounds like a broken record, but we've said it time and time again. This is one more demonstration of the strength that is inherent in having the kind of pipeline network on the natural gas side that we have, which spans all the producing horizons and interconnects with virtually every other pipeline system in America. And that's going to pay dividends for many years to come.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. And then lastly, are we close to contract minimums on gas gathering? So another way of saying is, if Eagle Ford production continues to decline, there actually won't be much impact on Kinder Morgan?
componenttext: That's really helpful. And then lastly, are we close to contract minimums on gas gathering? So another way of saying is, if Eagle Ford production continues to decline, there actually won't be much impact on Kinder Morgan?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've got roughly -- I don't think I can answer that question exactly, but we've got 30% of what we call our gathering and processing that's under take-or-pay contracts. But without looking at it kind of contract by contract, I couldn't tell you whet
componenttext: Yes, we've got roughly -- I don't think I can answer that question exactly, but we've got 30% of what we call our gathering and processing that's under take-or-pay contracts. But without looking at it kind of contract by contract, I couldn't tell you whether -- well, wait, short answer is -- if there's continued decline, then we're not at the bottom. There would be a continued decline in our revenues, but we do have some floor in our revenue because we've got this 30% of the contracts are take-or-pay.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been hit. I did have one very quick follow-up on the Eagle Ford volumes -- gathering volumes in general. You mentioned last quarter that you've signed some incentive agreements that hopefully would have gotten some volumes in you
componenttext: Most of my questions have been hit. I did have one very quick follow-up on the Eagle Ford volumes -- gathering volumes in general. You mentioned last quarter that you've signed some incentive agreements that hopefully would have gotten some volumes in your system. Was that supposed to be imminent here or is that something we expect to sort of be reflected in your volumes over time?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have successfully increased our market share from where we were sitting in the first and second quarters, and those incentive contracts were a big part of that. And so we have, if you will, restored the market share that we had at the end of '15 b
componenttext: Yes, we have successfully increased our market share from where we were sitting in the first and second quarters, and those incentive contracts were a big part of that. And so we have, if you will, restored the market share that we had at the end of '15 back to where we were. But we're still in the Eagle Ford, it's a market share of a declining overall base. And so the declines still come, but I think the program that Tom and his team initiated was successful in taking our market share back up.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And with respect to the issues that you had with MEP. Are you seeing anything similar for other pipelines within your system?
componenttext: Got you. And with respect to the issues that you had with MEP. Are you seeing anything similar for other pipelines within your system?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have -- yes, we have other pipes that are kind of what you would call basis pipes. FEP is another example. And so pipes that are kind of point-to-point that have long-term contracts that underwrote them when they were expanded as those contracts roll o
componenttext: We have -- yes, we have other pipes that are kind of what you would call basis pipes. FEP is another example. And so pipes that are kind of point-to-point that have long-term contracts that underwrote them when they were expanded as those contracts roll off and basis has come in, they would -- that would present the same kind of phenomenon.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you guys have a sort of magnitude of what the revenue impact or EBITDA impact would be going forward here?
componenttext: Do you guys have a sort of magnitude of what the revenue impact or EBITDA impact would be going forward here?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the FEP is not -- let me -- it's not a revenue issue in terms of what the shippers are paying us because those are take-or-pay contracts. And I think the contracts go through 2019 or 2020 on FEP. I think it would just be as we figure out where we th
componenttext: Well, the FEP is not -- let me -- it's not a revenue issue in terms of what the shippers are paying us because those are take-or-pay contracts. And I think the contracts go through 2019 or 2020 on FEP. I think it would just be as we figure out where we think exactly the market is, whether you had a noncash impairment on those assets. So the customers are still paying. In fact, the largest customer on FEP is Southwestern. I think they've actually put a rig or 2 back into the Fayetteville and their credit situation, I think, has improved dramatically over the last few months.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last question for me. Is the CO2 CapEx still trending at about $50 million or so quarterly?
componenttext: Last question for me. Is the CO2 CapEx still trending at about $50 million or so quarterly?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh. Yes, we had -- it's up a little bit from where we were. I think we were at about $210 million for the year, we're now about $249 million, $250 million. Yes, $250 million.
componenttext: Oh. Yes, we had -- it's up a little bit from where we were. I think we were at about $210 million for the year, we're now about $249 million, $250 million. Yes, $250 million.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Ted Durbin from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question is from Ted Durbin from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Coming back to Trans Mountain here. So maybe you can give us a little bit of a preview on this Ministerial Panel's report. I think it's due November 1 and kind of how that will impact the December decision and then also an update on the BC process, meetin
componenttext: Coming back to Trans Mountain here. So maybe you can give us a little bit of a preview on this Ministerial Panel's report. I think it's due November 1 and kind of how that will impact the December decision and then also an update on the BC process, meeting the 5 conditions in particular. I think revenue sharing is one of the big ones there.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the -- there were a couple of, if you will, additional federal processes. One was a federal consultation process where the federal government was directly out consulting with First Nations and communities. The one that you're specifically referrin
componenttext: Yes, so the -- there were a couple of, if you will, additional federal processes. One was a federal consultation process where the federal government was directly out consulting with First Nations and communities. The one that you're specifically referring to is there was a 3 -- a panel of 3 people appointed to go out and hear from the community, up and down the right-of-way and gather data or gather perspectives that hadn't been picked up in the NEB proceeding. That process is wrapped up in terms of hearing. And as you pointed out, there's a report that's due. It's a report that is cataloging, at least as I understand it, everything that the group of 3 heard while they were talking to people and the communities along the rights-of-way. The federal -- so those things feed into the federal decision, the Order In Council, that comes out of the federal government, which is still scheduled for December 20. So that I don't know of anything, Ted, that's inconsistent with the December 20 date, certainly nothing that's associated with those 2 processes. We still expect to see on/or before December 20 a final Order In Council.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my other part of my question, it was a long one, on the British Colombia process, meeting the 5 conditions and the revenue sharing.
componenttext: And then my other part of my question, it was a long one, on the British Colombia process, meeting the 5 conditions and the revenue sharing.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have been engaged with British Columbia on the 5 conditions. I think it's been constructive and productive engagement. We don't have anything final there. The other process that's going on in British Columbia is the EA order that they are going to issu
componenttext: We have been engaged with British Columbia on the 5 conditions. I think it's been constructive and productive engagement. We don't have anything final there. The other process that's going on in British Columbia is the EA order that they are going to issue around the same time as the federal decision. And at least in our thinking, we're assuming that's in January. That, that's not going to be in December. That, that's going to be in January. And so I think what we're aiming for is to have the British Columbia conditions as well as that environmental order resolved and complete early next year.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then I know you've been back and forth with the contractors. Just any updates on the cost side and overall sort of project returns still in line with what you had originally budgeted?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then I know you've been back and forth with the contractors. Just any updates on the cost side and overall sort of project returns still in line with what you had originally budgeted?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Project returns are still in line. We're still working on the costs with the contractors. We've made very good progress, I would say, but we're not final yet and we're still, as you know, a complicated project. There's still work to be done there, but I t
componenttext: Project returns are still in line. We're still working on the costs with the contractors. We've made very good progress, I would say, but we're not final yet and we're still, as you know, a complicated project. There's still work to be done there, but I think we've made good progress.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Shneur Gershuni from UBS.
componenttext: Next question is from Shneur Gershuni from UBS.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to confirm your response to one of the earlier questions. I think it was Brian's question about retained distributable cash flow. I just wanted to make sure I understood it correctly. If, let's say, you're at a run rate of -- and just usi
componenttext: I guess I wanted to confirm your response to one of the earlier questions. I think it was Brian's question about retained distributable cash flow. I just wanted to make sure I understood it correctly. If, let's say, you're at a run rate of -- and just using round numbers here, about $4.5 billion in distributable cash flow. And I think if I heard you correctly, you had talked about potentially holding back about $2 billion of that retained DCF to fund the equity portion of kind of a normalized growth CapEx budget.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, you didn't hear me correctly. Let me -- what I said was, we would hold back and certainly, we will expect to have $4.5 billion run rate today to increase as new projects come online. But what I said was, we would hold back the amount necessary to fund
componenttext: No, you didn't hear me correctly. Let me -- what I said was, we would hold back and certainly, we will expect to have $4.5 billion run rate today to increase as new projects come online. But what I said was, we would hold back the amount necessary to fund the equity portion of a normalized CapEx expenditure for the year. So for example, we would think -- and that will depend on what kind of projects you have, but we would think historically, that's been between $2 billion and $3 billion a year. So if you pick the midpoint of that, it's $2.5 billion, you would be withholding $1.25 billion out of that $4.5 billion or $5 billion of distributable cash flow. So it's not the whole thing because once we get to the level of -- the appropriate level of debt, we would intend to go back to financing half equity, half debt. But the difference is, we would not put -- would not contemplate putting out new equity. We would be using retained cash flow from operations to fund the "equity portion" of that. Does that answer your question now?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're actually on the same page. So if I did my math correctly, it means that's a very significant increase in the dividend from where you are today, which I think is running at about $1.1 billion or $1.2 billion. Am I thinking about that cor
componenttext: Yes, I think we're actually on the same page. So if I did my math correctly, it means that's a very significant increase in the dividend from where you are today, which I think is running at about $1.1 billion or $1.2 billion. Am I thinking about that correctly and corresponds with your whale of a difference comment earlier?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that would be, of course, a significant difference, right.
componenttext: Yes, that would be, of course, a significant difference, right.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, cool. Second question, I know that you've been asked this many different ways. But I realize that the company's made considerable progress of getting down to your stated goal of 5x net debt-to-EBITDA. I guess kind of 2 questions in 1 here, but has t
componenttext: Okay, cool. Second question, I know that you've been asked this many different ways. But I realize that the company's made considerable progress of getting down to your stated goal of 5x net debt-to-EBITDA. I guess kind of 2 questions in 1 here, but has that leverage goal impacted your ability to consider some growth projects? And then secondly, given all the questions about returning to a higher level of dividend, is the board considering any options to accelerate the pace to the 5x leverage goal either through equity or preferred issuances or even asset sales? Or is the board comfortable with the pace where you're at and you'll get there when you expect to get there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so let me answer. And I think my answer to the first will address the answer to the second question, which is the -- the reason that we decreased the dividend primarily a year ago had to do with inefficient capital markets and not wanting to fund ex
componenttext: Okay, so let me answer. And I think my answer to the first will address the answer to the second question, which is the -- the reason that we decreased the dividend primarily a year ago had to do with inefficient capital markets and not wanting to fund expansion CapEx in a market that wasn't rationally pricing debt and equity securities. And so I think that the debt market has changed. The equity market is still significantly different from where we were 12 months ago, 18 months ago. And so we are funding our CapEx program. So we -- in my mind, what we are constrained by -- we do want to improve the balance sheet, and that is a goal that we have. But what we are doing is we are living within our cash flow, meaning that we want to be able to fund our equity -- our CapEx and our dividend from our cash flow. And so that is the constraint. And so because we have limited amount of capital, that is why we have the hurdle rate set at 15% unlevered after-tax IRR for projects. I fully anticipate that over time, as the CapEx comes down and also as the balance sheet improves, that we would relax that standard. I don't know exactly what that number is going to be today, but it would be something less than the 15%. It probably won't be back at the 8% unlevered after-tax that we previously used for a hurdle rate, but we will have to make the assessment when that time comes.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so you're comfortable with the pace that you're at or would you consider options to accelerate getting there?
componenttext: And so you're comfortable with the pace that you're at or would you consider options to accelerate getting there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you mean including [ph] equity, we're not an equity issuer at these prices.
componenttext: Well, if you mean including [ph] equity, we're not an equity issuer at these prices.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that was why that we're living within cash flow given where the current equity prices are.
componenttext: And that was why that we're living within cash flow given where the current equity prices are.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: But look, we are -- we're going as fast as we can. If we can find ways to go faster, we will. And we're working on this all the time, as you might imagine. This is -- but it's just a question -- the particular method that you identified as distinguished f
componenttext: But look, we are -- we're going as fast as we can. If we can find ways to go faster, we will. And we're working on this all the time, as you might imagine. This is -- but it's just a question -- the particular method that you identified as distinguished from attractive joint ventures, for example, and other ways of accelerating us getting there, that approach, that is issuing equity, is not attractive at today's prices.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And one final question. We've seen a spike in global coal prices recently and I know you've had some challenges at your terminals over the last 2 years. Has there been any -- has there been any inquiries or increased inquiries in terms
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And one final question. We've seen a spike in global coal prices recently and I know you've had some challenges at your terminals over the last 2 years. Has there been any -- has there been any inquiries or increased inquiries in terms of folks wanting to ship out coal in bulk out of the U.S.? Or is it still too early to see the benefit from the recent increases that we've seen in coal prices globally?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We saw actually a 13% uptick last quarter in our coal volumes, mostly on the export side. Now on a U.S. basis, exports were down 11.8%. That's just a drop in the bucket. We're still down 30% on a year-over-year basis. Price, we've seen some price compress
componenttext: We saw actually a 13% uptick last quarter in our coal volumes, mostly on the export side. Now on a U.S. basis, exports were down 11.8%. That's just a drop in the bucket. We're still down 30% on a year-over-year basis. Price, we've seen some price compression. Volumes did spike up, but we don't anticipate that going significantly higher. The forecast for this year is still tracking at about 59 million tons of export. And that's comparable to 74 million tons last year. It's not projected a lot higher than that. So we've got some ground to make up, yes.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Darren Horowitz from Raymond James.
componenttext: Next question is from Darren Horowitz from Raymond James.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll be quick, Rich. You and Steve mentioned the permitting challenges. And obviously, the Connecticut expansion of TGP comes to mind. I'm just thinking systemically, what impact do you think these permitting challenges are going to have specifically on t
componenttext: I'll be quick, Rich. You and Steve mentioned the permitting challenges. And obviously, the Connecticut expansion of TGP comes to mind. I'm just thinking systemically, what impact do you think these permitting challenges are going to have specifically on the Northeast gas market when you reconcile the amount of marketed pipe capacity versus what you said you expect Marcellus and Utica production growth expectations to be? Do you think it's a rescaling of marketed pipe or a combination of pipes? And I'm most interested to know your thoughts on maybe some basis differential expectations, more pressure in the Dawn Hub, but most importantly, how you capitalize on it through scaling up TGP.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. A lot loaded in there. But basically, I think our view is, it's very hard to get big newbuilds done into New England or into the Northeast. We've seen that not only with NED, which we talked about in the first quarter and discontinued, but also with
componenttext: Okay. A lot loaded in there. But basically, I think our view is, it's very hard to get big newbuilds done into New England or into the Northeast. We've seen that not only with NED, which we talked about in the first quarter and discontinued, but also with recent rulings that, I think, verified that decision. It's making it harder to get things done on a kind of a mega-scale, call it. Now we have continued to engage with our customers on smaller scale projects and we'll continue to pursue those. But I think from the perspective of right now, today, it is hard to get new, significant gas infrastructure built into New England. And that would in -- tend to increase the basis differentials between what's already the lowest-price gas at Dominion South, call it, and the New England market, which is just a few -- the highest-priced in North America and just a few hundred miles away. So barring some improvement in an overall permitting environment, I think it's difficult to do those, but we'll keep looking for the smaller projects to do. The other thing, I think New England is a perfect example of what Rich said at the very beginning, which is that it does tend to make existing -- the existing network more valuable. The other thing I'd add and I'll let Tom throw in whatever he wants. But the TGP system is a system that is continuing to produce project opportunities for us. A lot of our backlog on TGP -- a lot of our backlog in gas is on TGP. I mean, it's the biggest home for it outside of the Elba project right now. And what a lot of that project capital is directed at now is getting the gas, as you know, Darren, south from the Marcellus and Utica to the new market, the new market area, which is now the Gulf Coast of the United States. And we are proceeding along very well with those. We're building on our existing footprint. That again goes to the need to make distinctions between projects out there and infrastructure projects, building off of your existing footprint, adding compression, maybe laying some parallel pipe, things like that. That create a different -- that's a different -- in a federally certificated process, that's a different context in which to be doing your project expansions. So I think you will see basis widen to New England, to the Northeast, and I think we'll find plenty of things to invest in and our -- plenty of things to invest in on TGP to get that gas someplace else.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Jeremy Tonet from JPMC.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Going back to TMX here. I was just wondering if you could help me think through some things here as far as if there's any target as far as what the right ownership would be for this? And when you're talking about the JV here, is this just the expansion or the expansion of the existing pipe? I guess what it comes back to is when I'm thinking, trying to model 5x debt-to-EBITDA, the spend on TMX and the drag associated with when the cash flows materialize is a pretty big variable in that equation. So I'm just wondering if you can help me think through that.

componenttext: Okay. A number of things in there, but I think, yes, the project is hard to separate from the underlying asset to answer the simplest one of your questions there. On the approach on what the ownership percentage would be and more of the details, I'll go back to the earlier answer which is, we have a lot of options and we're going to pursue the most valuable one. That's the easiest way I can characterize it. And we don't have to do anything, which is a great position to be in, but we are going to evaluate it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Got you. That's helpful. And then, if I heard you correctly, let know if I'm wrong, as far as when in the regulatory process it might make sense to proceed with the JV if the terms make sense? It's kind of earlier next year when you see things progress to schedule that could kind of come to fruition at that point?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Yes, that's a good point to be looking at it, when we see the regulatory clarity because I think investors would like to see that too. And so I think that's a reasonable point for us to be examining it.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Craig Shere from Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: Next question is from Craig Shere from Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions here. One, Rich, you commented about the historical annual run rate, call it, about $2.5 billion a year. I know we have some taking the python issues with the Trans Mountain and other such items that may be JV-ed. But I guess my q
componenttext: So a couple of questions here. One, Rich, you commented about the historical annual run rate, call it, about $2.5 billion a year. I know we have some taking the python issues with the Trans Mountain and other such items that may be JV-ed. But I guess my question is, as we think about lowering the hurdle rate for new projects, from 15% perhaps to the very low double digits, do you see the capacity in this current market to really fill in for that kind of ongoing investment opportunity when year-to-date you've only filled in $575 million?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, again, we would just have to look at what the environment is at that particular point in time. And these things do vary from year to year. But we look back over several years, and it's our thought at this time, and again, it's a preliminary
componenttext: Well, I think, again, we would just have to look at what the environment is at that particular point in time. And these things do vary from year to year. But we look back over several years, and it's our thought at this time, and again, it's a preliminary outlook, as I stressed. But that annual burn rate, if you will, of expansion CapEx is something in the range we talked about. And that's what we would want to use as providing enough coverage to pay for the "equity portion" of that burn rate. And I think under almost any scenario, that leaves a lot of money to pay dividends, but we'll just look at the exact circumstances when we reach that point.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Is there any color about how much you've left on the table because it didn't meet your hurdle rate because of the significant balance sheet management that, that's really helped a lot in the last 2, 3, 4 quarters? Any kind of color on what you
componenttext: Understood. Is there any color about how much you've left on the table because it didn't meet your hurdle rate because of the significant balance sheet management that, that's really helped a lot in the last 2, 3, 4 quarters? Any kind of color on what you've already left on the table because of that discipline that may be when, in a better market, might be there in the future?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know that we left anything on the table, Craig. We did elevate our return -- our hurdle criteria. But we have continued to say, look, if there's something that our business units think makes sense, we got a good customer, good counterparty cr
componenttext: Yes, I don't know that we left anything on the table, Craig. We did elevate our return -- our hurdle criteria. But we have continued to say, look, if there's something that our business units think makes sense, we got a good customer, good counterparty credit, long-term contracts, confidence around execution, et cetera, we want to bring it in and talk about it. And we continue to see those come forward. I think the one place that we took a close look at was CO2. And we -- and certainly, in the oil price environment we saw earlier in the year, we took projects off the table and now we're adding those back as we see oil prices recover. So look, is there some -- are there some things that we might have been able to do if we were in an 8% world that we're not doing when we're in a 15% world, then yes, maybe so. But I think what we're talking about in the longer term is return hurdles that we will relax off of the 15%, as Kim said. And I think given the network that we have, we'll still find those opportunities off our network and we're finding some of them still today.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: If you're asking if we've had any changes on the underlying contracts at MEP, no. There have been no underlying changes. This is based on -- the impairment is largely based on -- informed by discussions with customers at rates that we can get when contracts expire.

I think you still have American Liberty and American Pride yet to contract, is that correct? And any update about charters rolling over the next couple of years?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have 2 ships that are not yet constructed. Those are the only 2 of the 14 that are currently not chartered -- the only 2 of the 16 that are not currently chartered. Everything else is at -- there's one that's under a shorter-term charter that's rolling
componenttext: We have 2 ships that are not yet constructed. Those are the only 2 of the 14 that are currently not chartered -- the only 2 of the 16 that are not currently chartered. Everything else is at -- there's one that's under a shorter-term charter that's rolling into a long-term charter. Everything is chartered. We do have some coming off in, 1 or 2 in 2017 -- 3, 3 in 2017. We're having a really strong year there. We're up $12 million on the base mostly due to less off hire and higher rates and then the expansions are another $25.7 million. If you look kind of going forward, the risk really is we've got 11 that are under long-term agreement and then 5 that could be impacted at some point or another. That's about 15% of the total earnings for that group.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: That's very good color. And then on -- there was the question about Trans Mountain costs. I just want to confirm, I mean, historically, you all have said that if we bumped up against that upper limit of what the offtakers were required to accept in Canadian dollars, if we punched through that, that there was still significant shipper interest. And if conditions were that you punched through that a little bit, that the expectation would be that there would be plenty of still interest and you wouldn't be too worried about that. Is that still the case that whatever comes, you're going to do your best to keep costs down but the shipper interest is there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is good strong shipper interest, including outside of the current shippers. And so, yes, we still believe that. Now having said that, we are working very hard to keep our overall costs down and to be within the cap. And we're making good progress. B
componenttext: There is good strong shipper interest, including outside of the current shippers. And so, yes, we still believe that. Now having said that, we are working very hard to keep our overall costs down and to be within the cap. And we're making good progress. But yes, we do believe that there's strong enough -- there is strong shipper interest outside of the existing shippers.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Great. headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: I think it's the same general comment, which is we have to take all of those kinds of things into account in scheduling and costing our projects and it includes additional public outreach. It also includes taking into account security measures that may be needed. So it's about adapting to that new environment, and that's what we are actively doing.

componenttext: Yes, it's several other counties. And we've -- as is typical of all of our projects, we tried to avoid use of eminent domain. We negotiate with respect with landowners. componenttext: Okay. And then the increased contribution that you talked about from the quarter from the Hiland midstream assets, what exactly was that associated with? Was that associated with higher volumes? Or was there something else going on in there?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Yes, it was shifting contracts from commodity-sensitive contract structures where we were getting a percentage of proceeds to locking in the fee and giving the producer the commodity upside. And so the producer was happy with the commodity upside and we were happy to lock in and secure a stable cash flow.

componenttextpreview: Canadian, yes. But keep in mind that we -- that's a gross number and we collect what we call firm 50 fees. This is firm capacity across the dock and there's $250 million worth of firm 50 fees that go to offset that development cost. So the net number -- a
componenttext: Canadian, yes. But keep in mind that we -- that's a gross number and we collect what we call firm 50 fees. This is firm capacity across the dock and there's $250 million worth of firm 50 fees that go to offset that development cost. So the net number -- and now that doesn't all match up in time. That's extended over a 10-year period. But $250 million worth of development cost is funded through the firm 50 fees.

componenttext: And then beyond that as, of course, we've explained before, we have commitments from the shippers for a portion of this in the event that the project would not go forward. So it's not like all of this is on our nickel. I think Steve's explained that in the past.

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then -- okay, and then the December 20 -- is that -- do you expect that to be -- is that literally a go, no go? Or is there some other decision that could come out of that?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a decision. And we don't know if it's going to have additional conditions or affirm the NEB's existing 157 conditions or so. So it's not a -- but it will be -- it is expected to be, as for example, in the Northern Gateway case, the Order In Council i
componenttext: It's a decision. And we don't know if it's going to have additional conditions or affirm the NEB's existing 157 conditions or so. So it's not a -- but it will be -- it is expected to be, as for example, in the Northern Gateway case, the Order In Council is a definitive decision about whether they view the project as being in the public convenience and necessity. So it will be definitive from that standpoint, we would expect, unless there's something very different here. We'd expect them to make that determination definitively.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So that becomes effectively the go, no go is the public...

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, you get a decision, I mean, does that mean, if they, for example, they did not find it's in the public -- it's not a project found in the interest of the public for convenience and necessity, would you in effect, at that point have to cancel the p
componenttext: I mean, you get a decision, I mean, does that mean, if they, for example, they did not find it's in the public -- it's not a project found in the interest of the public for convenience and necessity, would you in effect, at that point have to cancel the project? Now if they find you'll get a certificate of public convenience and necessity, but they add some conditions, I'm presuming then the project for all practical purposes definitely goes forward. That's what I'm just trying to figure out.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so on the going forward decision though, the other elements that I spoke to, we've got to get the BC resolution go through the final contractor and customer communications, all of which we expect to happen fairly shortly after the federal order. The f
componenttext: And so on the going forward decision though, the other elements that I spoke to, we've got to get the BC resolution go through the final contractor and customer communications, all of which we expect to happen fairly shortly after the federal order. The federal order could be a range of things. I mean, naturally, we think we've made a very good case and we think we've done better even than past applications in terms of meeting the requirements that the government has laid out. So we're certainly advocating for and expecting we'll find a determination that it is in the public convenience and necessity. But it could also have additional conditions and we'd have to examine what those conditions are and what impact they have on the project. And to your point, yes, they could determine that it's not and then we'd have to decide what our next steps were from that point.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones for me. Just trying to think 6 to, say, 18 months ahead, you've got your leverage to below 5x and then raise the dividends to higher levels. How should we think about leverage from that point going forward because presumably yo
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones for me. Just trying to think 6 to, say, 18 months ahead, you've got your leverage to below 5x and then raise the dividends to higher levels. How should we think about leverage from that point going forward because presumably you're looking to finance some of the future projects with the additional debt. Is there a target, kind of a level that you will still be aiming for, especially considering that you may get credit for that future capital -- for that capital spend for future leverage?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think we've been targeting about 5x leverage as a decision point. When we get to that point, we will, as Rich said, we will look at the dividend, we will look at whether we want to pay down additional debt and we will look at what we think
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think we've been targeting about 5x leverage as a decision point. When we get to that point, we will, as Rich said, we will look at the dividend, we will look at whether we want to pay down additional debt and we will look at what we think the right long term run rate is for the business, whether it is the 5x or whether it is something improved from there. And so I think in terms of, you can expect that it would be at 5x or potentially better depending on what decision we make when we get to that point.

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one clarification with regard to your interstate pipelines. I was wondering what kind of interest you are seeing on some of the recontracting for those pipelines. I think NGPL especially had some contracts which were coming up for rene
componenttext: Okay. And then just one clarification with regard to your interstate pipelines. I was wondering what kind of interest you are seeing on some of the recontracting for those pipelines. I think NGPL especially had some contracts which were coming up for renewal, any color on that?

headline: Kinder Morgan, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I would say, overall, we've had good interest and good rates. Our contract tenor really has gone, increased over the course of the year. And the right way to think about NGPL is it really has -- it touches all of the major demand and supply a
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I would say, overall, we've had good interest and good rates. Our contract tenor really has gone, increased over the course of the year. And the right way to think about NGPL is it really has -- it touches all of the major demand and supply areas that are engaged in the market right now, whether it be LNG, whether it be Mexico exports, whether it be the petrochemical growth in the Gulf Coast, whether it be certainly Marcellus/Utica and even the Permian, we're seeing some action out West as well. So good prospects along NGPL.
